DOC.HEAD: Law Will Allow Foreign Terrorists To Be Tried In Greece
DOC.TEXT: A new law will allow Greece to try a Palestinian the United States wants extradited in connection with the bombing of an American airliner, a member of Parliament says. The bill was approved unanimously by an all-party parliamentary committee Friday and will become law after a debate in Parliament next week, said the lawmaker, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The legislation appeared designed to prevent the extradition of Palestinian Mohammed Rashid, wanted by the United Sates for allegedly planting a bomb that exploded in a Pan Am airliner flying over Hawaii in 1982. A Japanese teenager was killed by the blast and 15 other passengers were wounded. The Rashid affair has become a sensitive issue between Greece and the United States since his arrest at Athens Airport in 1988. He has been awaiting extradition since May 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Prime Minister Accuses Soviets Of Unreasonable Demands
DOC.TEXT: Hungary's Prime Minister Josef Antall says Soviet compensation demands for withdrawing troops from his country are unreasonable. Antall on Friday also threatened that Hungary would leave the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact if it remained a military organization. ``We want to abolish the military structure of the Warsaw Pact. If this doesn't happen we will leave it by the end of next year,'' Antall said in an interview broadcast on Finnish national radio. Antall said the Soviet Union demanded over $4 million for facilities and equipment left behind by 50,000 Soviet soldiers who have begun withdrawing from Hungary, which elected a non-communist government in March. ``We think these demands are unreasonable as they (the soldiers) have used old Hungarian buildings, damaged them and polluted the environment,'' said Antall, in Helsinki for a meeting of conservative European leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Renews Debate on Sweden's Neutrality
DOC.TEXT: The detention of Swedes in Iraq has revived the debate over Stockholm's traditional policy of neutrality. Some Swedes, angry after seeing their captive countrymen on TV, are demanding military action. A few young men have even called the U.S. Embassy in Stockholm, volunteering to join international forces blockading Iraq. Other Swedes suggest their country contribute forces to the military buildup in the Persian Gulf. Successive Swedish governments have argued in favor of neutrality, allowing the country to play a mediating role in some conflicts. It has also protected Swedes. Often citizens of neutral countries have been allowed to leave hot spots while other nationalities are detained. Pehr G. Gyllenhammar, head of the Volvo car manufacturing empire, is one of those calling for a reevaluation of the politics of neutrality. ``The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait ... has shown a new unity between countries which earlier were in conflict with each other,'' he wrote in the Dagens Nyheter newspaper. ``In this situation Sweden passes, as usual. As usual we refer to our policy of neutrality,'' he said. ``As usual we indicate a `special role of mediator' which has influenced (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein's decision to release Swedes, while holding as hostages the citizens of nations which protest and are willing to take risks.'' Iraq has seemed to take neutrality into account in its treatment of foreigners. When Saddam said Wednesday that Western women and children would be allowed to leave, Finns were the first to go. In addition, groups of Finns, Swedes and Austrians were released from Iraq last week, while most other Westerners remained captive. But the exodus was suddenly stopped. More than 100 Swedes, many male employees of Swedish firms, were being held in Iraq. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Anita Matejovsky said some of about 50 Swedish women and children in Iraq received exit visas Friday and that the rest were promised theirs on Saturday, she said. Government officials say Swedes have been held because the country supports U.N. sanctions against Iraq. They reject suggestions that their policy toward Saddam is milder than that of other Western nations. ``We are not neutral in this crisis,'' Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson said Tuesday. Finland and Sweden say they, like other nations, are refusing to close their embassies in occupied Kuwait, as Iraq has demanded. But the embassy buildings have actually been emptied. Carlsson endured tough questioning on the subject during a nationally televised news conference Tuesday. He was asked whether $8.7 million in aid to Persian Gulf refugees was intended as compensation for the absence of Swedish military help. Journalists also asked whether Sweden was not acting sharply against Iraq because it still hoped to get its citizens out. ``We have acted sharply already. We are not proceeding mildly in this question,'' said Carlsson, barely containing his anger. But he said Sweden would not send military forces unless the United Nations specifically requests them. Sweden, which has not fought a war in 176 years, has contributed more than 55,000 men to U.N. peacekeeping operations. Swedes have been debating the ramifications of their neutrality policy since World War II. At that time, Nazi troops were allowed to cross Swedish territory into occupied Norway, but Allied forces were not given access to help Finland in its Winter War with the Soviet Union. Independence-minded Lithuanians, Estonians and Latvians are still bitter about Sweden's acceptance of the Soviet Union's annexation of the Baltic states in 1940. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, on a trip through Nordic countries during the past week, has been comparing Iraq's annexation of Kuwait to his country's fate. In one appearance, he asked ``whether Sweden, in the name of realist politics, would be willing to hand Kuwait to Iraq after a year of annexation.'' ``Because of today's international situation (of East-West detente), there is a tendency to question the dogma of neutrality,'' said Wilhelm Agrell, an associate professor of peace and conflict studies at the University of Lund. ``The Iraq crisis tests a new international position for Sweden, and also for many other countries,'' said Agrell. ``Sweden has answered with confusion and delay and crouches down behind the fact that it is a small country.''

DOC.HEAD: Stranded Kuwaiti Students Do More Worrying Than Studying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Homesick and heartsick over the Iraqi invasion of their country, stranded Kuwaiti students are doing more worrying than studying, and some have dropped out to join the fight. ``Studying comes second now,'' said Osamah Al-Tuwairesh, one of 14 Kuwaiti students at the University of Southern California last semester. ``The first thing we think about is getting our country back.'' Students and other Kuwaiti nationals began gathering in Washington, D.C., on Friday for a conference to discuss their country's situation. The meeting, expected to draw up to 1,500 people, ends on Sunday. ``Ever since the first day of August all my friends have talked about going back and joining the resistance,'' said Al-Tuwairesh, president of the 110-member Southern California branch of the National Union of Kuwaiti Students. He said he knows at least a dozen students who have traveled to Saudi Arabia since the invasion. ``The first day this happened, some students started collecting names of people saying they were ready to go,'' said Abdul-Hamid Khudada, a graduate architectural engineering student at Penn State. ``That's the least we could do. It's not fair the Americans and others go to fight for our country, and we don't fight.'' The Kuwaiti embassy has tried to encourage the more than 1,200 students at U.S. universities and colleges to stay in school, despite possible financial hardships caused by a cut-off of funds from their oil-rich government, which had supplied many with scholarships and living stipends. ``They don't want people just to back there and get killed,'' Al-Tuwairesh said. ``The students really don't have any military training.'' The embassy is working on ways to pay the students' bills, and many schools have agreed to defer tuition, dormitory and book costs for the moment. Others are offering loans and helping the Kuwaitis find jobs; the Immigration and Naturalization Service is allowing them to work 20 hours a week during the crisis. ``The university did everything possible to help,'' said Univeristy of New Mexico architecture student Jamal Al-Hajji. ``They told me, `If you want a job in school we can arrange it for you.' And they can give me a loan.'' Central Michigan University also has agreed to defer payments for its 15 Kuwaiti students, said Sharon George, director of the International Student Services. ``In return, the Kuwaiti students are very, very thankful,'' she said. ``They are a gracious people and a proud country. They are not used to being cared for.'' Saif Abdullah of the Kuwaiti embassy in Washington said they are collecting donations and have reduced the usual stipends by about 40 percent. ``The students will go through some hardship until everything is OK,'' he said. But financial worries pale next to family ones. Many students have not heard from relatives since the Aug. 2 invasion. ``I'm so worried,'' said Saud Abdullaziz, a senior at the University of San Francisco who last spoke to his parents and brother in Kuwait City the day before the Iraqis moved in. ``I'm thinkng of canceling this semester and going back to check on my family. I am just thinking all the time about home.'' Anwar Al-Mudhat, a doctoral candidate in finance and investment at Claremont Graduate School, said his fellow students can do more for their country by staying here than by returning home. ``It's a noble thing to do, but most of these people aren't trained,'' Al-Mudhat said. ``Besides, we need these people here in the United States to present our people's case to case to the American public. And this by itself is a noble thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Schwarzkopf Tries Softer Approach in Visit to Troops
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: When the airmen yelled ``Go get 'em Gen'rul!'' H. Norman Schwarzkopf couldn't resist. ``We'll get 'em all right,'' he said. Then he turned quickly to correct himself, mindful of his mission, and the group of reporters trailing him. ``We're going to get them _ when they come across the border,'' said the commander of the U.S. forces marshalling in Saudi Arabia south of the border with Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Schwarzkopf, who set up his command post in Saudi Arabia just days ago, paid his first visit to the troops in the field Friday. His nickname is ``Bear'' and he can be blunt and gruff. But on Friday he tried a more grandfatherly approach, putting his arm around troops and commanders alike. He assured them of the world's support, and promised to make their stay in the desert as comfortable as possible as they face off against the Iraqis who invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. He had a simple message to the troops. ``Our job is to get it over as fast as we can,'' he told a group of airmen. After Air Force A-10 pilots told him their tank-killing jets could exact a heavy toll on the Iraqi armored divisions, Schwarzkopf nooded in approval before fighting good-naturedly for his branch of the service. ``Try and leave a few for the army, will you?'' he quipped as he left. Schwarzkopf spoke softly when telling a group of Marines about the crash of one of the huge C-5 Galaxy transports in West Germany on Wednesday in the Operation Desert Shield airlift. Thirteen of the 17 Americans aboard were killed. He can shift gears quickly. At the news conference, he was asked if the United States was getting military help from Israel, the enemy of the Arab world. ``No,'' was the answer. Next question. He said he wasn't worried about U.S. troops adjusting to the desert climate, where temperatures can shoot up to 120 degrees. ``They're not potted plants or greenhouse shrubs,'' he chided. For Iraqi forces, Schwarzkopf had nothing but bad wishes. But he delivered them in an animated exchange with reporters. ``I hope they're hungry. And I hope they're thirsty. And I hope they're out of ammo,'' he said. ``And I hope they feel bad about what they did, because they should.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan Still Unwilling to Take On Responsibilities of Global Leadership
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Japan's reaction to the Persian Gulf crisis reveals a nation still not ready to take on the responsibilities of global leadership despite its status as an economic superpower. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu announced Wednesday, nearly one month after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, an aid package of nearly $1 billion for the U.S.-led force arrayed against Iraq and further assistance to Middle East countries hurt by the embargo on Baghdad. Robert Orr, director of the Stanford Japan Center in Kyoto, says Japan's policy formulation was largely a matter of deciding what could be done to placate Washington. ``I don't think that's the way a great power should be operating,'' Orr said Friday. ``The Japanese still really do not have a global perspective.'' Japanese bureaucrats can expect further pressure from the United States, which had applauded the package as an initial contribution to the gulf forces. Washington has urged Tokyo to provide transportation for military cargo. The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 has shown that the Japanese political system is ill-equipped to cope with the quick decision-making required in responding to international crises. Bureaucratic infighting between powerful ministries has made it difficult to reach a consensus, a cherished goal of political life here. ``In effect, they were arguing when they should have taken action,'' The Japan Times newspaper said in an editorial. And Kaifu, despite strong showings in public opinion polls, does not have the power base within the governing Liberal Democratic Party to easily push through his own agenda. ``Throughout the process of determining its contribution to the Middle East, (Japan) has never made clear what its basic policy is,'' the newspaper Mainichi Shimbun wrote Friday. Kaifu has acknowledged the country's ``growing responsibility'' in the world and awareness of growing impatience with the pace of Tokyo's response. ``If our response was delayed any further, I was afraid we would give the impression to the world that Japan is not doing anything about this serious problem,'' he said after unveiling the package. Behind the weeks of waiting for a Japanese aid program to emerge was a heated debate over what could be done under the post-World War II constitution that bars the use of force in settling international disputes. There is strong public opinion in Japan and throughout Asia against any action that could lead to Japanese military activity overseas. Triggered by the U.S. pressure, bureaucrats and politicians are debating a change of the country's laws that would make it easier for Japan to respond to future crises in a decisive matter, but which critics charge could led to a violation of the constitution. A government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the legal review was unprecedented and indicates that Japan's reaction to the Middle East tension is charting new ground for the country. Any proposed revisions are sure to meet with strong opposition in the Parliament, where the Japan Socialist Party is the largest opposition group. A senior Socialist recently said of the crisis: ``It is an ideal time for Japan to show the spirit of our peace constitution.''

DOC.HEAD: Banks Have To Give Quicker Access To Deposits Under New Law Today
DOC.TEXT: Bank customers, beginning today, will be guaranteed quicker access to their deposits under the final installment of a 3-year-old federal law that the banking industry is trying to get changed. At issue is the Expected Funds Availability Act, legislation passed by Congress in 1987 to prevent banks from imposing lengthy delays before customers were allowed access to deposited funds. Beginning Sept. 1, banks will be required to meet shorter time limits for making funds available on deposited checks. Local checks must be cleared by the bank in two business days, down from three days currently. Non-local checks must be cleared in five business days, down from the current seven business days. A local check is defined as one written on an institution in the same metropolitan area or within the same Federal Reserve check processing region. The previous three-day and seven-day limits had been in effect for the past two years and were instituted as interim standards to give banks time to prepare for the more stringent final regulations. Many banks are already processing checks in the shorter time periods going into effect today. Those banks that have been using the longer interim standards will be required to notify their customers within the next 30 days that their funds will be available more quickly. In addition to the changes affecting regular checks, money deposited in the form of cashiers' checks, certified checks and government checks must be available to depositors by 9 a.m. the next business day. This represents no change from the interim regulations. The law guaranteeing bank customers quicker access to their money was passed after a long lobbying campaign in which consumer groups presented examples of banks freezing funds for as long as two or three weeks, a practice banks referred to as putting a ``hold'' on deposited checks. The U.S. Public Interest Research Group, which lobbied aggressively for the 1987 law, said banks were making $290 million annually in interest on the money withheld from customers during the so-called ``float period,'' the time between when the bank got credit for the funds and when it released the money for use by the depositor. The consumer research group charged that banks were collecting another $145 million a year in bounced-check fees because funds weren't released faster for depositors' use. In the two years in which the interim regulations have been in effect, consumer groups contend the law has allowed depositors with interest-bearing accounts to make millions of dollars more because of the shorter ``hold'' periods on checks. ``We think the law is working well to make the holdup at the bank a thing of the past,'' said Ed Mierzwinski, consumer advocate at the U.S. Public Interest Research Group. However, banking groups have been lobbying Congress to make changes in the law. A bill giving banks more leeway was approved by the Senate Banking Committee in July. Under that measure, which is expected to be taken up by the full Senate in September, banks for the next four years would be given a longer processing time for certain checks deposited at automated teller machines. Mark Serepca, a spokesman for the American Bankers' Association, said a recent survey by his organization found that 20 percent of banks will just stop accepting deposits at teller machines unless the customer has an account at the bank whose teller machine he is using. ``Many banks are telling us they won't offer the expanded service any more because they fear the risk of too many bad checks,'' Serepca said. While consumer groups said they would be willing to accept longer processing time for certain automated teller deposits, they vowed to fight another proposal that would keep the processing time for all local checks at three days instead of the two-day limit taking effect today. Mierzwinski said such a change isn't necessary because surveys done by the Federal Reserve, which administers the law, showed that up to 75 percent of banks are already processing local checks without difficulties within the two-day limit.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast Crisis Helps Forge New World of Cooperating Nations
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush calls it ``the shape of the post-postwar world.'' To a degree unknown for generations, the nations of the world are working together in the interest of peace, not only in the Persian Gulf but in bloodstained Cambodia as well. Gone, at least for the moment, are the superpower rivalries that often blocked cooperation to settle regional conflicts during the post World War II era that came to be tagged the ``Cold War.'' But the new world Bush talks about is sure to contain its own chills and frustrations for the United States. For example, a world in which international cooperation is the norm is one in which unilateral action is condemned. How much has the world changed in the nine months since Bush's unilateral decision to remove Manuel Antonio Noriega from power in Panama? Or since Ronald Reagan's decision to invade Grenada? Or Leonid Brezhnev's decision to send Soviet troops into Afghanistan? Does the swift mobilizing of an international force to block Saddam Hussein give reason to think prospects are heightened for an international effort to finally bring peace to the Middle East? ``What is at stake here is truly significant,'' Bush said Thursday. He cited ``the dependability of America's commitments to its friends and allies, the shape of the post-postwar world, opposition to aggression, the potential domination of the energy resources that are crucial to the entire world.'' He spoke in the context of announcing that he was asking Japan, West Germany, Korea, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and free Kuwait for financial and energy resources to support the Persian Gulf mobilization. That request opens another area of international involvement. Presumably, nations that agree to pay part of the cost will also want a role in the decision making. At this time of widespread agreement on how to proceed in response to the Iraqi aggression, that wouldn't seem much of a problem. But suppose Saddam Hussein is able to hold out, resist the blockade and keep his troops in Kuwait indefinitely? Will the world's unanimity continue? Should Iraq yield to international pressure and withdraw from Kuwait, will there be unanimity on the shape of the post-invasion Persian Gulf? Would a return to the status quo, a Kuwait governed by the Emir and his family, be acceptable to all nations? There also is the question of whether an Iraqi withdrawal would now be enough. Influential members of Congress, such as Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., a senior member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, are urging Bush to hold out for the removal of Saddam Hussein from power. They argue that as long as he is in control of Iraq, it would only be a matter of time before he struck again. More broadly, any attempt to look ahead to the post-Cold War world runs into the question of whether the response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait will be the exception or the rule. After all, the Persian Gulf with its oil resources is a region so vital to so many of the world's industrial nations that it provided unique incentive for governments to set aside interests that divide them and unite behind an effort to roll back the Iraqi aggression. Less than 24 hours after Bush cited with obvious satisfaction the number of nations cooperating with the U.S. in the Persian Gulf, the Vietnamese-installed government of Cambodia announced its willingness to accept a major U.N. role in moving that nation toward free elections. While the announcement leaves Cambodia still a long way from an end to a 20-year period in which hundreds of thousands of people have died, it does represent substantial progress toward an international solution. For years, the world stood by, apparently helpless, as Cambodia was ravaged by civil war and the savagery of the Khmer Rouge regime when thousands died in execution chambers and slave labor camps. The prospect of a return to power of the Khmer Rouge may have provided enough incentive for the compromise that is leading to a United Nations role. The Persian Gulf and Cambodia _ both areas on which it was relatively easy to find international agreement on the need for action to halt further violence. The leaders who now are cooperating need only look back on the response to the start of the Iran-Iraq war, to see a different sort of response. There was no concerted effort to halt the fighting between two evenly matched nations widely viewed as pariahs. The only concern during the years that war dragged on was over whether it would cause an interruption of oil shipments.

DOC.HEAD: Death Threats Over Marine Mammals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The idea of a floating hospital for injured seals and sea lions seemed like a good one to Dan Deuel and Mary Crumley. But it smacked of harboring the enemy to some people, who have made death threats against the couple. ``Man is pretty possessive,'' said Neal Langbehn, a National Marine Fisheries Service special agent, whose job includes tracking down people who shoot marine mammals. ``If a critter causes him any problems, all his natural instinct seems to be to get rid of the critter. As man takes up more and more of the Earth, there are going to be more conflicts.'' Deuel and Crumley and some volunteers run Free Flight Bird and Marine Mammal Rehabilitation Ltd. from their home on a bluff overlooking the Pacific Ocean. Earlier this year, Deuel suggested to the Bandon Port Commission that he could move his operation to a barge in the harbor. That would make it more accessible to the public and more mobile in case of an oil spill. The commission said OK, but the reaction from some nameless people was different. ``My old man says you will be so ticked off when that Mary gets dead, just like our fish. . . . No Barge. Or she's dead,'' read one letter. The man's voice on the telephone answering machine was choked with anger: ``Bring one sea lion into the port of Bandon and I'll kill him right along with you, buddy.'' The threats have been turned over to the Oregon State Police, which called in the FBI to help. ``They sound maybe crazy enough to do it,'' Crumley said. ``If we get a death threat here, we feel it is not just a death threat towards us,'' said Deuel. ``It is a death threat against anyone who cares about peace on this planet.'' Free Flight, which Deuel started 13 years ago, is caring for an orphaned Steller sea lion pup and three injured harbor seal pups. One was shot, one was attacked by a dog and one was hit by rocks thrown by children. ``Because of the hostility, I don't release any of them around certain coastal communities,'' Deuel said. The law allows fishermen to shoot harbor seals and California sea lions if they steal fish and won't be driven away, but not Steller sea lions. They were listed this year as a threatened species because of dwindling numbers in Alaskan waters. Though their population is stable in Oregon, a fisherman who shoots one here is still liable for a $25,000 federal fine. ``There's an awful lot of hard feelings on the entire coast, from California clear up to Alaska, about the seals and sea lions and their predation onto salmon,'' said Melvin Erdman, who has fished out of Bandon for 48 years. When a sea lion comes across a salmon troller, it will dog the boat for hours, taking the fish right off the hook as the fisherman winches it in. Bitterness runs deep among fishermen who have watched the government cut and complicate the salmon season to conserve dwindling stocks, then protect a predator. Erdman said there is no shortage of people who would happily kill the seals and sea lions Deuel and Crumley care for, though he hasn't heard anyone threaten the couple directly. Despite the threats, Deuel said he won't give up on his project. ``It is all dependent on how our fund raising goes and right now it is not going too bad,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Passengers Without Air Bags More Vulnerable, Tests Show
With PM-Crash Tests-List
DOC.TEXT: Front-seat passengers of the 1990 Chrysler LeBaron are nearly seven times more vulnerable to head injury in crashes than the car's drivers, who are protected by air bags, government tests show. A Chrysler spokesman, however, said the tests were unreliable because they were based on conditions that exceed government safety standards. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on Friday released its final round of crash test results for 1990 automobiles. For the year, the agency tested 34 vehicles ranging from subcompacts to luxury sedans and light trucks. The tests showed that most drivers protected by air bags were significantly less likely to sustain head injury than unprotected front-seat passengers in the same vehicles. In the Chrysler Imperial four-door sedan, for example, the passenger is four times as vulnerable as the driver. Chrysler spokesman Steve Harris said the tests were based on crashes of cars into fixed objects at 35 miles per hour. But government regulations require only that vehicles have safety belts or air bags that perform satisfactorily in tests conducted at 30 mph. Also, the tests were not repeated to ensure that initial results were free from external factors such as the weather or equipment failure, he said. But Harris acknowledged air bags have a major impact on safety and are needed for passengers as well as drivers. ``Everybody (in the auto industry) has indicated that's the direction they're going,'' he said. ``We'll be moving air bags into the minivans next year and start working toward passenger air bags shortly thereafter.'' The NHTSA tests, under the same conditions as a frontal collision between two identical vehicles driving at 35 mph, are equivalent to a car moving at 70 mph striking an identical parked car. Tests are conducted using dummies that represent an average-sized adult male. The dummies wear seat belts. According to the NHTSA index, a score of 750 or lower means head injury is unlikely; 750-1,250 means head injury is possible; and anything higher means head injury is likely. A separate scale records the possibility of chest injury, which is considered likely when the score tops 60. The lower the numbers, the lower the potential for injury. But for purposes of comparison, vehicles have to be of the same type and weigh within 500 pounds of each other. The Chrysler LeBaron's score for driver head injury was 298, well below the threshold for likely injury. But the front-seat passenger score was 2,043. Chest injury scores were 40 for the driver and 46 for the passenger. In the Imperial, the driver head injury score was 517 while the passenger head injury score was 2,132. Rated highest of all vehicles tested for potential driver head injury was the Ford Club Wagon van, with a score of 2,613. Its passenger score was 1,896. The Isuzu Trooper II had the highest potential injury score for the front-seat passenger _ 1,952. The Chevrolet S-10 Blazer had the highest driver chest injury score _ 74. The highest passenger injury score was the Trooper II's 64.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor to Face Second Trial in Identity-Switch Murder
DOC.TEXT: A doctor convicted of an identity-switch murder in an insurance fraud case will be retried after jurors deadlocked on whether he should be sent to the gas chamber, prosecutors said. A judge on Friday allowed a new penalty phase trial for Dr. Richard Pryde Boggs and scheduled a Sept. 13 hearing to set the trial date. Boggs, 57, was convicted July 12 of murder, grand theft, assault and insurance fraud. On Aug. 8, the jury deadlocked 10-2 in favor of sending him to the gas chamber for the 1988 death of Ellis Henry Greene. Boggs was silent on Friday as Deputy District Attorney Al Mackenzie asked the judge for a retrial on the penalty phase -- an effort defense attorney Dale Rubin termed ``a waste of taxpayers' money.'' No jury would condemn Boggs to death on the strength of the evidence presented at trial, Rubin told Superior Court Judge Florence Marie Cooper. ``It is not in the furtherance of justice to retry this case,'' said Rubin. But Cooper ruled the law gives her no such discretion. ``I believe the decision lies with the prosecution authority, not the court,'' she said. The prosecution said Boggs lured Greene from a North Hollywood bar to his medical office in April 1988 and suffocated him, although the cause of death was never conclusively proved through medical evidence. The prosecution alleged that Boggs and the owners of the troubled Just Sweats sports apparel company of Ohio conspired to switch Greene's identity in an effort to collect life insurance on one of the business partners. Melvin E. Hanson, principal in the clothing firm, awaits trial in the case. His partner, John B. Hawkins, remains a fugitive. Boggs misidentified the body as Hanson and Hawkins had the body cremated the following day. Hanson's credit cards and birth certificate were found with the body. Hawkins, who is still missing, received $1 million in life insurance benefits and Boggs got $6,500, prosecutors said. Rubin acknowledged at trial that Boggs participated in an insurance fraud scheme, but said his client never killed anyone. He said Boggs' conviction was influenced by testimony about his homosexual lifestyle and suggested that would be an issue on appeal of his conviction. Boggs wore bright orange jail coveralls to court, indicating he is being held in the Los Angeles County Jail's ``alternative lifestyle'' section.

DOC.HEAD: Man Tries to Break In to Police HQ
DOC.TEXT: Burglary suspects have been known to break out of police stations, but in Beaver County, one allegedly tried to break in. Brian H. Walker, 19, of Ambridge near Pittsburgh was charged Thursday with burglary and criminal mischief for allegedly trying to break into the Harmony Township municipal building to retrieve his friend's impounded car keys. Walker shimmied up a pole and climbed a ladder to the roof, got in through a vent and crashed through the ceiling of the township secretary's office, police said. Then he walked down the hall to the police department. ``I look at it as stupid more than daring,'' Harmony Police Chief Jack Lively said. Police later found scrapes on the police department door, where the alleged burglar finally was stymied. The township's sole late-night officer was on patrol. Police said Walker was trying to help a friend whose car had been towed to the municipal parking lot after his arrest on charges of drunken driving and assault.

DOC.HEAD: White House Task Force Postpones Spotted Owl Advice
DOC.TEXT: A report on how to save the rare spotted owl is not on the president's desk as planned today, and at least one scientist says advice offered on this issue should be made public anyway. The report is being prepared by a task force chaired by two Cabinet secretaries, Clayton Yeutter of Agriculture and Manuel Lujan Jr. of Interior. At stake is the survival of the endangered owl and the financial health of the Northwest timber industry, which environmentalists say is contributing to the bird's problems. Officials for the Agriculture Department refused official comment on Friday. But a department official who spoke on the condition of anonymity said, ``The task force has not come back with a finding yet. ``The Sept. 1 deadline was an internal goal. They are looking at next week,'' the source said. Officials for the Fish and Wildlife Service also refused comment on the task force this week. David Klinger, press officer for the service's regional office in Portland, said the service ``is not privy'' to the task force meetings. ``It's going to be news to us right along with the rest of the world,'' he said. White House spokesman Stephen Hart said in a telephone interview from Kennebunkport, Maine that it was not yet decided what role Bush will play in the final decision about protecting the owl on federal lands. ``It's unclear in that we are not sure what form the report will take. We are right now in a waiting mode to see what the task force delivers. I would expect any final decision will have to have the concurrence of the White House,'' he said. ``What we have said in the past is that we are seeking a balance,'' Hart said. Meanwhile, a scientist who appeared before the task force in August is urging its leaders to make public the advice they have received from independent biologists and foresters. The scientist, former Texas A&M biologist John Teer, was among three who said this week that they endorsed a protection plan that the White House has resisted. Teer said they told Assistant Agriculture Secretary James Moseley the owl's survival would be jeopardized by any further compromise in the plan submitted by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas and a committee of government scientists. ``I think it would be to his advantage to let people know,'' Teer said. The administration has struggled to please both environmentalists and the Northwest's timber industry since the Thomas panel determined in April that the rare bird is headed for extinction unless logging stops on millions of acres of old-growth forests. The Fish and Wildlife Service declared the owl a threatened species on June 22, but the listing's impact remains unclear with a government blueprint for protection still in limbo. Environmentalists say the Republican administration is ignoring the advice of its own scientists while bending owl protection plans to lessen the impact on timber jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Studies Show Cocaine Use Declining
DOC.TEXT: New drug-use statistics confirm earlier surveys that indicate cocaine use is declining, according to officials at the National Institute on Drug Abuse. The new data show a continued drop in the number of cocaine-related emergency room visits in hospitals across the country _ 27 percent from the third quarter of 1989 through the first quarter of this year. ``We are finally beginning to see some progress in reaching those who are seriously affected by the cocaine epidemic,'' said Charles Schuster, director of the institute, which is in the Department of Health and Human Services. The figures from the Drug Abuse Warning Network, or DAWN, show the number of visits for the first quarter of this year was 8,135, a 4 percent reduction from the last quarter of 1989 when 8,507 visits were recorded. Visits in the third quarter of 1989 numbered 11,145. Despite the improvement, however, the number of cocaine-related deaths continued to increase last year, to 2,496, up from 2,254 in 1988. DAWN reports death data only on an annual basis. ``We're assuming deaths occur most often among the heaviest users, and that's the population you'd expect to see changes in last,'' said Edgar Adams, director of epidemiology at the institute. ``We're just beginning to see change in the emergency-room data, and if that continues, we would hope to see a downturn in the deaths next,'' he said. Heroin use followed the same trend as cocaine, both for hospital visits and for deaths. The DAWN data shows the number of emergency room visits related to the drug dropped 22 percent, from 3,933 in the third quarter of 1989, to 3,071 in the first quarter of this year. Heroin-related deaths, however, climbed from 1,884 in 1988 to 1,995 in 1989. Significant decreases in cocaine- and heroin-related emergency room visits were reported by hospitals in most of the cities included in the DAWN report, officials said. They said this confirms decreases in drug use reflected in two other surveys conducted by the institute, the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse and the High School Senior Survey. The decrease in cocaine-related emergency room visits began in September of last year after three quarters of holding steady and increasing 354 percent between the second quarter of 1985 and the last quarter of 1988. Adams said the pattern indicates that the downturn ``is not an aberration.'' ``It's important that we're looking at a period that extends through several quarters where there was a period of stability and six months of decreases,'' Adams said. The DAWN data is based on reports from 431 emergency rooms. Most of the facilities are located in 21 large metropolitan areas.

DOC.HEAD: Neil Bush Asks Judge to Dismiss Government's Case Against Him
DOC.TEXT: Neil Bush says he's no longer in a position to do the things banking regulators have accused him of doing, and he's asking an administrative law judge to dismiss the government's case against him. The president's son was an outside director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, a Denver thrift that collapsed in December 1988 at a cost to taxpayers estimated at $1 billion. Regulators have accused Bush, 35, of conflict of interest in his former role as a director. In written arguments submitted to Judge Daniel J. Davidson, Bush said there was no possibility that he could continue the alleged abuses since Silverado already has been taken over by the government. ``Silverado is in receivership,'' said his brief, which was made available Friday. ``No `intermediate step' taken now will prevent that, and nothing Bush could ever do in the future could pose abnormal risk, loss or damage to Silverado or its insured'' deposits. In a separate S&L development Friday, a spokeswoman for the Resolution Trust Corp. said that agency plans to hire a special group of employees to watch for possible corruption as it sells hundreds of failed thrifts. The RTC hopes to set up a team of 20 to 30 ``contractor cops'' this fall, spokeswoman Kate Spears said. The team, which will oversee the sale of billions of dollars of S&L assets, will be led by a new assistant director of the RTC to be named soon. The Office of Thrift Supervision has accused Bush of conflict of interest for not disclosing his business ties to two big Silverado borrowers, Kenneth M. Good and Bill L. Walters. The thrift agency is seeking an order against Bush which effectively would bar him from working for banks or S&Ls. Bush also could be a target of a negligence lawsuit that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. is considering filing against him and other former directors of Silverado. Bush has denied any wrongdoing and has insisted that the regulators' actions are politically motivated. He has been ordered to appear at a public hearing on Sept. 25 in Denver before Davidson, who will then make a recommendation to the director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, Timothy Ryan. A spokesman for the office, William Fulwider, said Friday the agency would have no comment on Bush's request to the judge. ``There's no authority for them (the regulators) to be doing what they're doing,'' Bush's attorney, James Nesland, said in a telephone interview from Denver. ``Why should we litigate an order that can't be issued?'' Bush's petition says the proposed order against him would be the first against an outside director after the institution has been closed. ``Plainly, the cease-and-desist proceeding against Bush cannot be characterized as an `intermediate sanction' to protect Silverado or its insured funds,'' the document says. ``The action here can only be characterized as a punitive proceeding, and that is not the purpose of a cease-and-desist proceeding.''

DOC.HEAD: Jackson a Veteran of Many Self-Appointed Diplomatic Missions
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson, who met this week with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on the Persian Gulf crisis, has traveled the world as a self-appointed diplomat to pursue a host of missions of his own making. The longtime civil rights activist and unsuccessful presidential candidate has visited dozens of countries and conferred with more than 60 heads of state. One of Jackson's biggest coups came in 1984, when he went to Syria to secure the release of Navy Lt. Robert O. Goodman Jr., whose jet bomber was shot down during a raid over Syrian antiaircraft positions in Lebanon's central mountains. Jackson, who at the time was running for the Democratic presidential nomination, brought Goodman home to the United States a month after the pilot was shot down. Jackson called on President Reagan to meet personally with Syrian President Hafez Assad to try to reduce tension between the two countries. Assad's assistance to Jackson was seen as a clever move to influence American public opinion to change Reagan's foreign policy in the region. Over the years, Jackson's efforts in international diplomacy have taken him around the globe and provoked controversy on more than one occasion. He has hugged Yasser Arafat in Lebanon, accepted a cigar from Fidel Castro in Cuba, conferred with Pope John Paul II in Rome and advocated anti-apartheid civil disobedience in South Africa. A photograph of Jackson embracing Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, during a 1979 visit to the Middle East still angers many American Jews and caused him trouble with Jewish voters during his presidential campaigns. At one point during the 1988 campaign, Jackson met with Jewish leaders in what he described as an ``a step toward healing the wounds.'' Jackson said earlier this week he hoped to keep adversaries in the gulf talking in order to avoid war in the Middle East but that he was making the trip as a journalist, and would not be engaged in diplomatic negotiations. Jackson, who flew to Iraq for the U.S. television show ``Inside Edition,'' met Thursday with Saddam and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. He met first with Aziz, who explained to him the reasons behind Iraq's annexation of Kuwait, and later with Saddam, Iraqi officials said. No details of the meeting with Saddam were released immediately. Jackson visited the Persian Gulf in 1987, meeting Saudi Arabian and Jordanian leaders and delivering 600 pounds of Christmas gifts for the crew of a U.S. warship. In 1984, Jackson visited Castro, who then released some two dozen Americans from his jails. He also traveled to Nicaragua, where he praised the Sandinista government, to Panama and to El Salvador, where he tried to mediate differences between Salvadoran rebels and then-President Napoleon Duarte. He paid his first visit to South Africa in more than a decade in February, when he met with black leader Nelson Mandela upon his release after 27 years in prison. Jackson had been refused a visa since 1979. A year earlier, he was in Moscow to promote aid to victims of the December 1988 earthquake in Armenia and to assess the economic and political reforms of Mikhail Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Deployment Tests Military's Counseling Resources
DOC.TEXT: When the tearful goodbye is over, a Navy wife is left to get on with life alone. Well, almost alone. The modern Navy, recognizing that reduced family worries make better sailors, is offering counseling services _ or just a shoulder to cry on _ to families of troops shipped to the Middle East. ``You know the old quote, `The Navy wife is the toughest job in the Navy?' It's true. What it is to love a sailor is letting him go,'' said a 36-year-old Navy wife with two teen-age children who identified herself only by her first name, Glory. In the past, families turned to chaplains. But in the late 1970s, the Navy and Marine Corps started offering counseling services. ``When I was in Vietnam in the '60s, who would have ever thought?'' said William J. Kelly, deputy director of the Newport Family Service Center, which opened in 1982. Newport has three counselors for its 8,000 military personnel. The Defense Department's decision to offer counseling, ``is not all selfless,'' Kelly said. Troops perform better when they don't have to worry about their families at home, he said. To ease stress on those left stateside, the military offers a variety of services. The chaplains are still around and are more sought-out during times when troops are deployed, said Cmdr. Willard James, a chaplain. James said the five chaplains at the Newport base often make referrals to the service center and to ``ombudsmen,'' spouses of military personnel who are trained in crisis management and familiar with the various resources available. Glory is one of Newport's 35 ombudsmen. Telephone calls come around the clock, she said. ``I get the crying calls. I get the happy calls. I get the birth calls,'' the 19-year Navy wife said. ``I am a listening ear.'' ``I think the hardest thing at this point is the uncertainty,'' she said. ``We don't have any answers for them.'' The USS Roberts is the only one of Newport's 12 ships to be deployed so far. For those with family on the Roberts, the biggest concern has been ensuring paychecks arrive on time. ``When the husband is deployed, life goes on. Dinner has to get on the table,'' she said. ``We are the anchors.''

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Exhausted Refugees Pour Into Turkey from Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of mostly Pakistani refugees, some suffering malnutrition and others bruised from beatings by Iraqi soldiers, crossed into southern Turkey through this border post one day this week. Few Westerners have escaped through Habur, the single border crossing between Iraq and Turkey, since 52 dependents of U.S. Embassy personnel stationed in Kuwait left Iraq on Monday. But on Friday a string of cars stretching more than seven miles long awaited entry into Turkay under scorching 104-degree heat. Among the refugees were 1,000 Pakistanis, more than 100 Chinese, 31 Sri Lankans and a few Finns. Many looked bedraggled and exhausted and all crossed on foot, clutching their belongings. ``We waited for seven days to enter Turkey,'' said one Pakistani who refused to give his name. Many of his countrymen worked on construction sites in Kuwait before Iraq invaded its oil-rich neighbor on Aug. 2, he said. Several travelers said Iraqi troops made many bureaucratic checks to verfify their nationality before allowing them to pass into Turkey. Most Westerners have been barred from leaving Iraq since the month-old crisis began. Some refugees were taken to the field hospital of the Turkish Red Crescent, the Moslem equivalent of the Red Cross. Dr. Nuri Polat of the Red Crescent said most were suffering from malnutrition and dehydration. Some travelers said they had trouble finding food in Iraq, which has suffered food shortages since the United Nations imposed a trade embargo to pressure Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. ``Some Pakistani nationals were beaten by Iraqi soldiers and we had to send them to hospitals nearby for treatment,'' Polat said. He would not elaborate. Two cars carrying three Finnish women, a boy and a Pakistani man also crossed the border Friday. Shaikh Mohammad Zubair Siddiqi of Lahore, Pakistan, his wife Asta Anneli Kyllikki of Keskisoumi, Finland, and their 18-year-old son arrived in one car. Siddiqi said they left all their belongings in Kuwait and drove 22 hours to reach the border. Two Finnish women traveling in a second car refused to talk to reporters. A Finnish official said their husbands had not been allowed to leave Iraq. Siddiqi, manager of Moto Cave, an air-conditioning company in Kuwait, said he and his family had to leave after his company closed and the Finnish community in Kuwait decided to depart. ``All the banks had closed, we could not get out money and there was a curfew,'' he said. Mrs. Siddiqi said people in Kuwait wait in long lines to buy bread and ``supermarket shelves were cleaned out in two days'' after the invasion. In one instance, she said, ``I saw Iraqi soldiers filling up their shopping cart at the supermarket and walking straight out without paying.'' Raimo Pahkasalo, the Finnish Embassy's charge d'affaires in Kuwait, crossed the border with 18 Finns Aug. 24, after he locked up the embassy. Nine Finns, all men, were not allowed to cross. Zhang Zheng, coordinating the departure of more than 100 Chinese, said Beijing asked the group to leave Iraq. Zhang said he rented buses to take the Chinese to Istanbul, where they would catch planes home. Since the Persian Gulf crisis began, about 16,000 people have left Iraq and Kuwait through Turkey. Iraq has distributed some Westerners among strategic sites to serve as human shields against any U.S. attack on the facilities. There are about 21,000 Westerners in Iraq and Kuwait, including 3,000 Americans. Iraq has also ordered embassies closed in Kuwait, which Baghdad annexed and now claims as part of its territory. But many foreign governments, including the United States, have refused to close their missions in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Frank Sinatra has signed an exclusive contract for nine shows over two years at the Sands Hotel Casino and County Club in Atlantic City, a hotel spokesman said. Sinatra will perform five shows in the 850-seat Sands Copa Room from Oct. 4 to 7, Sands spokesman Jim Wise said Friday. Sinatra, 74, also will perform twice both in 1991 and 1992 at the casino, Wise said. The contract precludes Sinatra from performing at any other Atlantic City casino, said Wise, who would not disclose how much the contract is worth. Sinatra, a New Jersey native, first performed in Atlantic City in 1939 when he sang with Harry James and his Orchestra, Stone said.

Irish singer Sinead O'Connor says the flap over ``The Star Spangled Banner'' has her on the testy side. During a 90-minute act an amusement park in this town 30 miles east of Buffalo, the 23-year-old O'Connor tried to hush some of the audience who talked while she sang. ``Is everyone going to be quiet now?'' she said Thursday night. ``If there's anyone that wants to sing the national anthem, can you wait until later?'' Later O'Connor apologized, and the crowd of 6,500 cheered. ``I hope I wasn't harsh before,'' she said. ``The last few days have been a strain and I've been irritable, so I hope I didn't appear rude.'' O'Connor threatened last week to walk out of the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., if the national anthem was played, as is the tradition there. Center staff relented and the show went on.

Teen-age tennis idol Jennifer Capriati, in town for the U.S. Open, showed off her singing talent at a Virginia Slims party. The 14-year-old Capriati recorded ``Wild Thing,'' ``Great Balls of Fire'' ``Under The Boardwalk'' and three other tunes at a video sing-along booth during the party Wednesday night. Among the other players who sany tunes were Martina Navratilova, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, Gigi Fernandez and Helen Kelesi.

Navajo leaders are satisfied that director Robert Redford is making an effort to employ Native Americans in his latest film, ``Dark Wind.'' The film's producers ``have assured us that Navajos and Hopis will work on the productions of the film,'' leaders of the Navajo nation said in a statement Friday. Some Navajos have objected to Redford offering the leading role of a Navajo policeman to Lou Diamond Phillips. Phillips, who says he is part Cherokee, has been selected to play Jim Chee, a fictitious Navajo policeman. The film is based on ``The Dark Wind,'' a novel by New Mexico author Tony Hillerman. Navajo leaders said they have no quarrel with a producer's right to capitalize on an actor's popularity. ``All we ask is that they be sensitive to our needs, culture and language in making films based on the Navajo,'' the statement said. Sammye Meadows, the film's Native American liason, said earlier this week that Redford and others searched coast to coast to find a Navajo actor to play Chee. Shooting for the film begins Sept. 10 on the Navajo and Hopi reservations.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega: Government Must Abandon Market Reform or Face Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Former President Daniel Ortega has told the conservative government it faces further social unrest unless it abandons its free market economic policies. The leftist Sandinista leader made the statement during a debate Friday at the national university on ``The Possible Nicaragua'' among representatives of the new and old governments, private enterprise and labor. Ortega, succeeded by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in April after losing free elections, said the only route to a ``truce'' between the Sandinistas and the new government would be cancellation of three decrees that pave the way for the transition to a market economy. President Chamorro's decrees were suspended after two violent Sandinista-led strikes. ``Those decrees would have to be forgotten,'' Ortega said. He accused the U.S.-backed government of ``retaliating'' against the Sandinistas by firing public servants, planning to privatize state enterprises and planning to return Sandinista-confiscated lands to previous owners. ``If this government takes destabilizing actions ... those governed have the right to question, to protest the government's action, to exercise their power, which they do not lose when they cast their vote,'' Ortega said. The Sandinistas _ who promised to ``govern from below'' after losing the Feb. 25 elections _ maintain that any attempt to dismantle the leftist state they built is a ``destabilizing'' action. Attempts by the Chamorro government to move to a market economy have provoked violent Sandinista reaction, including the two paralyzing strikes in May and July. Ortega insisted during the debate that workers have the right to strike for political reasons. Minister of the Presidency Antonio Lacayo announced during the debate that the government has created a $10 million emergency fund to create short-term jobs for those who become unemployed because of economic reforms. The announcement by Lacayo, considered the real power in the 4-month-old government, indicated how seriously Nicaragua's leadership takes threats of more Sandinista-led unrest. The strikes have already put much of the new government's economic program on hold. Lacayo, the president's son-in-law, rejected suggestions that the Sandinistas have intimidated the government into sharing power. He called for a constructive and cooperative attitude on all fronts to help rebuild Nicaragua and said everyone must ``share the sacrifices needed to revive the economy.'' Ortega said the conditions for such cooperation do not exist. ``Those conditions are created by not firing teachers ... (and) public employees,'' he said. Ortega said in the debate that 3,000 Sandinista sympathizers have been fired from government jobs and replaced with 2,000 people who support the new government. Lacayo disputed those figures but did not offer any of his own. Unemployment is estimated at more than 30 percent _ about what it was under the Sandinistas _ and is growing as the state tries to trim the public payroll. Inflation has been running at 80 percent a month since Mrs. Chamorro took office on April 25. The price of staples is out of reach for many Nicaraguans and foreign investment has been scared away by the Sandinista labor unrest.

DOC.HEAD: 200,000 Children Will Be Hurt on the Job, Group Says
DOC.TEXT: An estimated 200,000 children will be injured this year on the job, according to a report by the American Youth Work Center, a youth advocacy group. In a report released Friday, the American Youth Work Center predicted some 40,000 cases of child labor violations will be reported this year, almost double the number found in 1989. ``Deaths and injuries are increasing dramatically and yet are spread thinly across the country,'' said AYWC's William Treanor. ``And so all that people have are anecdotal stories. Everybody can think of one gruesome, horrible incident that they're aware of and they think that that's some sort of freak occurrence. '' The Department of Labor conducted a one-day sweep of businesses in June this year, uncovering 3,800 cases of child labor violation. Most of the cases involved youngsters working more hours than the laws allow, but many were using dangerous machinery. As a result of the sweep, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole announced that the administration would back legislation to increase fines from $1,000 to $10,000, the maximum penalty for violations. The legislation, co-sponsored by Reps. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., and Don Pease, D-Ohio, will go to the floor when Congress gets back to work this fall. One area not covered by proposed legislation is agricultural. An estimated 300 children are killed every year in farm work, and more than 23,000 are injured. In July this year, investigators from the Department of Labor found children as young as 3 years old working as migrant laborers in Northern California.
DOC.HEAD: Post Office to Keep the Color in Christmas
DOC.TEXT: Postal officials are red-faced about reports that they want Americans to have a white Christmas. Not so, says Richard J. Strasser, senior assistant postmaster general for marketing and customer service. Strasser's comments came after postal officials in Kansas City told area residents earlier this week that they should ``never use red, green or any dark colored envelopes.'' If people buy Christmas cards that come with envelopes that are red or green or some other color, the Postal Service will deliver them happily, Strasser said Friday. Americans send one another some 2 billion cards annually, millions in colored envelopes. White envelopes are easier for the agency's automated machinery to handle, Strasser admitted. Dark-colored backgrounds can make the addresses written on them very hard to read. ``They are a challenge, but we can handle it,'' he said. How did the misunderstanding start? Some postal workers may have been too enthusiastic in discussing the benefits of the new automatic letter sorting equipment, Strasser said. Strasser said the postal service and the makers of greeting cards have been working together to develop envelope colors that are attractive but can easily be handled by automatic sorting machinery. But in the meantime, no envelope that is sold will be rejected, he said.
DOC.HEAD: HHS proposes changing Medicare physician payment program
DOC.TEXT: Health Secretary Louis Sullivan is proposing to Congress a plan that will change the way physicians are paid by the Medicare program. The package sent to Congress on Friday includes a preliminary fee schedule covering about 1,400 physician services, shifting payments to primary care and away from procedure-based services like surgery. Under the new system, physician fees will be based on the time, skill level and resources needed to perform the service, as well as practice costs and malpractice insurance costs. More than 500,000 physicians will be affected by the change scheduled to be implemented Jan. 1, 1992. It will be the largest change in the Medicare program since its inception 25 years ago. In his letter to health committee and subcommittee chairmen and ranking members, Sullivan cautioned that the numbers in the fee schedule are ``very preliminary ... Many and perhaps all of these values will change.'' ``Important policy and technical questions ... are unresolved,'' he said. Under the current Medicare system, physicians are paid their actual charge, customary charge or the prevailing local charge for a service, whichever is lowest. The system has resulted in large variations in payments among localities and services. The new system will pay physicians either the actual charge or a fee based on the value scale, whichever is lower. A geographic adjustment will account for differences in practice costs, but overall payments will increase for many physicians in rural areas who are paid less than urban physicians under the current system. A spokesman for the American Medical Association said the group's officials were looking over the preliminary fee schedule but could not comment in detail on the proposal yet.

DOC.HEAD: Vacationing Mother Stranded in America, Can't Get Back to Husband in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: When is a vacation on the Southern California seashore no longer a vacation? For the American wife of a Kuwaiti engineer, vacation turned to exile when Iraq invaded her adopted country. Stacey Carpenter's husband remains in the occupied Middle East nation and has not been able to contact his wife and two children since Iraqi troops crossed the border on Aug. 2. Assurances from relatives that he is all right can only go so far. ``I'm worried about him. It is definitely a potentially dangerous situation over there,'' she said. Carpenter, 33, doesn't want her married name published because she considers her husband a hostage. As the Persian Gulf crisis moves into its fifth week, she says her status is uneasy. ``I'm not a widow, I'm not a divorcee, I'm nothing,'' she said. Carpenter, her 6-year-old son, Saad, and 10-month-old daughter, Layla, have been staying with her parents in this beach town about 15 miles southwest of downtown Los Angeles. They arrived for a one-month vacation in early July. She is looking for a job and her son will soon start school. ``My parents are helpful and generous, but I've invaded their home,'' said Carpenter. ``I'm an independent person who likes to do things my own way. I have to support my family. I have no access to money. All my money is in Kuwait.'' Carpenter's mother, Dixie, said her daughter's predicament is also a godsend. ``I'm glad she took the vacation when she did,'' she said. Carpenter said she fears it may be a year or two before she can return to Kuwait, where she was a physiologist and researcher at the University of Kuwait medical school. She watches television to keep track of Middle East developments. ``Last week, I thought the U.S. would move in and strike Iraq in an intense, short military action,'' she said. ``Now, it seems like everything will be stalemated.'' Carpenter and her husband, a chemical engineer, married in 1980 while they were students at the University of California, Santa Barbara. Carpenter became a Moslem. Adjusting to the prospect of spending a long time in the United States has been tough on Carpenter's son. ``I miss my dad and a few friends a lot. I miss Kuwait,'' said Saad.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Proposes ``One China, Two Regions'' Formula
DOC.TEXT: Premier Hau Pei-tsun today proposed a ``one country, two regions'' formula in another attempt to solve differences between Taiwan and the rival Communist government in China. Hau said the formula would respect the differing political systems of China and Taiwan, which has been governed by the Nationalists since they lost a civil war on the Chinese mainland in 1949. Both the Communists and Nationalists regard Taiwan as a Chinese province. Hau said the Nationalists would enact laws based on the new formula to govern trade, cultural and other civilian exchanges between Taiwan and China. Such exchanges have increased recently. Officials said one main area to be covered would be the repatriation of an increasing number of mainland Chinese who have entered Taiwan illegally to seek a better life. At present there are no laws covering them. More than 10,000 mainlanders have entered Taiwan illegally since 1987, when the Nationalists relaxed private contacts between Taiwanese and Chinese. The Nationalists, who maintain they are China's legitimate leaders, continue to reject any official contacts with the Chinese government. In the past, both sides have offered other formulas to solve their differences, but each solution has been rejected by the other. China proposed a ``one country, two systems'' formula, but this was rejected by the Nationalists who said it would have reduced them to the status of a local government. In turn, the Nationalists proposed a ``one country, two governments'' formula, but this was rejected by Beijing which said it would have created two Chinas. Hau proposed the latest formula in a written report to the lawmaking Legislative Yuan, which would have to approve the changes. There was no immediate indication of whether the proposal would be accepted. Legislator Huang Chu-wen, a member of the governing Nationalist Party, said Hau's proposal was an attempt to resolve the dispute over sovereignty and solve problems involving trade and other private exchanges between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEAD: International Meeting On Pollution Is Muddied By Independence Politics
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov joins other regional leaders Sunday in trying to agree on a plan to save the polluted Baltic Sea, but Soviet-Baltic independence politics was complicating the meeting. One-third of the sea floor, or about 40,000 square miles, is dead, according to reports released by the Baltic Commission and Greenpeace International in advance of the two-day conference in Ronneby, southern Sweden. Phosphates and nitrates from farms, factories and cars have created slimy algae floats along the coasts of the seven nations which surround the Baltic Sea, according to the scientific reports. Sweden and Poland are hosting the conference, which has been overshadowed by the problem of how to invite representatives of five Soviet republics without disavowing their struggle for independence or stepping on Moscow's toes. Invitations were finally sent last Wednesday to the heads of governments in Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Byelorussia and Russia. They are among Soviet republics that have passed sovereignty declarations of various degrees. They were given the right to make formal statements and display their flags at the conference, but are to be regarded as part of the Soviet delegation, Swedish officials said. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis declined the invitation Friday, saying it showed that Sweden was a ``Soviet satellite.'' ``It's a big pity that Sweden in this situation has actually taken the position of the Soviet Union,'' Landsbergis said in Oslo, Norway. He said Sweden was the only country in Europe which accepted Soviet annexation of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in 1940, and its current policy reinforced that decision. ``Sweden takes a satellite position, compared to Czechoslovakia and Hungary,'' said Landsbergis. ``The events that are connected with the negotiations in Ronneby stress the importance of what happened 50 years ago,'' he said through an interpreter. The international environmental organization, Greenpeace, called on the conference to immediately start reducing pollution of the Baltic. It said nitrates and phosphates entering the sea have increased 10 times over the past 20 years, producing the oxygen-consuming algal blooms. Greenpeace said a 1988 agreement by the Baltic nations to halve all emissions into the sea by 1995 was far from adequate. The Baltic Commission report said improvements have been made in some areas thanks to growing awareness during the 1970s and 1980s. The report said levels of mercury, lead, arsenic, DDT and other dangerous substances appeared to be falling. Swedish Cabinet Secretary Pierre Schori said Friday his government sees the conference ``as an embryo for a regional cooperation which would include other issues as well, for instance, science, culture and transportation questions.'' He said, ``I hope that we now shall see the first example of regional initiative in the new Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: Guardsmen of the 265th Tread Paperwork Road to Mideast
Laserphoto XSAV1
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for possible duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is following these 14 Guardsmen as they prepare for deployment overseas. To comply with security rules, the men's last names are not used.

Napoleon said an army marches on its stomach. But these days the 265th Quartermaster Detachment is treading a paperwork road on its way to the Mideast. There's record-keeping to bind the tiny unit of 14 guardsmen over to the regular Army: forms for new dog tags, forms for new green Army identification cards to replace their red South Carolina National Guard IDs, forms to draw their first Army pay. More ominous is the business of preparing for overseas deployment: The paperwork for inoculations against typhoid and meningitis; fittings for new gas masks; instructions to the Army on where to send their belongings if they don't return. ``I'm having them send my stuff to my mom and dad,'' Mark, a 20-year-old college student, said with an uncertain shrug. But even these grim reminders of their mission are muted by the boredom that accompanies each stop. Some doze while waiting on the long wooden benches, paying little attention to CNN news reports droning from the television suspended over the waiting area. A general is telling reporters in Saudi Arabia the triple digit temperatures of the desert are dropping and U.S. soldiers may be wearing field jackets on chilly nights. But the men of the 265th aren't listening as they go back out into the moist heat of Georgia in August and on to their next stop. The unit, which specializes in water purification, was put on alert last Sunday, a move that placed it in the regular Army. On Wednesday the unit traveled from its hometown of Allendale, S.C., to this huge Army base near Savannah to begin training for deployment. Little was said Friday, through the heat and boredom, about their eventual destination. Instead, they razzed each other, particularly Mark, the youngest member and the only white in the otherwise all-black unit. ``You better watch it over there in the desert,'' someone warned. ``You're going to come home as dark as us.'' A solution was suggested. Mark should wear his chemical warfare clothes at all time to avoid a sunburn. Another favorite joke: Mark's decision to leave his prized red sports car with his girlfriend, who quickly rolled up 600 new miles on the odometer. ``Hey, don't worry about it,'' said Bill, a veteran of 17 years in the Guard. ``If she put 600 miles on in two days, you know she didn't have any time to fool around on you.'' Among those laughing was Henry, who retired in June after 25 years of teaching. At a gentlemanly 51, he is the oldest in the unit. He was 34 when he joined and probably will stay until he has to leave when he turns 60. ``I always wanted to be in the Guard,'' he said. ``I couldn't for a long time because it was hard for blacks to get in.'' Limping slightly from the unit's predawn PT _ physical training _ Henry had little hesitation about going to the Mideast. ``I'm glad to have the chance to pay the Guard back,'' he said. Henry coached football at Ruffin High, which fielded teams of dubious distinction. Henry said his players would pump themselves up with the odd chant: ``I ain't staying with my Momma because she beats me; I ain't staying with my Daddy 'cause he beats me; I'm staying with Ruffin because it don't beat no one.'' Members of the unit used to tease him about the team until this year, when it beat Allendale. Then, said Henry, there was no mention of football. ``That's what the Guard is all about,'' he said. ``You work with the same people for years. You work with people you know and can trust.''
