DOC.HEAD: U.S. Diplomats in Kuwait Tell Jesse Jackson Most Americans in Hiding
DOC.TEXT: U.S. diplomats in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait told the Rev. Jesse Jackson the roughly 2,000 Americans left in the country are hiding from Iraqi troops in fear of being used as hostages, The New York Times reported today. An unknown number of Americans have been rounded up and taken to Iraq, where they are being held at strategic sites as human shields against possible attack. The diplomats, who have been resisting an order from Iraq to shut down the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City, said they are running out of water, their food is spoiling because they lack electricity and no air-conditioning means they sleep outside for some relief from the heat, the Times reported. ``I wouldn't say I'm terrified, but it isn't a very pleasant way,'' Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell said Friday through the locked gate of the embassy compound. A group of reporters accompanied Jackson into Kuwait on an Iraqi Airways jet that President Saddam Hussein provided for him. Jackson traveled to the Mideast in his new role as a television reporter and talked with Saddam Thursday night. The Western reporters were the first to be allowed into Kuwait since the Aug. 2 invasion. They were escorted through the quiet and nearly deserted city by armed Iraqi escorts, the newspaper said. After hours of negotiations with Iraqi officials, Jackson was allowed to visit the U.S. Embassy, it said. He spoke with Howell and deputy chief of mission Barbara Badine, who said Americans trapped in Iraq are staying out of sight. ``They're all in hiding because they know what the Iraqis are going to do to them,'' Badine said. ``They're going to round them up in their houses. They knock on the door at midnight and take people away. We never hear from them again and they are interned. ``For that reason, they don't come out of their apartments to be seen.'' Jackson said he would appeal on their behalf in an interview with Saddam scheduled for today. He said he is videotaping news segments for broadcast next week. Diplomats said 11 Americans in Kuwait outside the compound needed medical treatment and asked that an evacuation flight be arranged. They said they were with six colleagues in the compound and 42 other Americans who had sought refuge. ``We've got some soda and juices left, to keep from getting dehydrated,'' Badine said. ``We've built our own outhouse. We don't have any water to spare.''

DOC.HEAD: Foreigner Women, Children Begin Leaving; Flight Scheduled Saturday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf `He referred...' to UPDATE with Iraqi airliner to ferry foreigners out on Saturday. Pickup 5th graf `Britain did...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A few foreigners began trickling out of Iraq on Friday under Saddam Hussein's pledge to free women and children hostages, but Iraq made more requests in connection with the release of the remaining captives. Government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi said 237 hostages were waiting to be flown to London and Paris on Iraqi Airways. He said on the return leg, the flights should carry home Iraqis who he said were stranded abroad. ``This is a humanitarian request, and we hope the two governments will reply quickly and positively,'' al-Hadithi said at a news conference. He referred to Iraqis being stranded in London and Paris by ``brutal American sanctions.'' However, the sanctions imposed against Iraq by the United Nations do not restrict the movement of Iraqi nationals. On Saturday, a senior official with Iraqi Airways said one of the airline's Boeing 747s was scheduled later in the day to ferry scores of women and children out of the country. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he did not have precise figures on passengers or a breakdown on nationality but said the plane would fly to Amman, Jordan, Paris, London and Washington. He said it would pick up Iraqis stranded in Europe. Britain did not object to letting the Iraqi planes take Iraqis home. ``If a plane is coming out here with British nationals on it, and is going back to empty to Baghdad, Iraqi nationals want to go on it, of course they can go,'' a Foreign Office spokesman said, adding pointedly: ``We do not have hostages.'' French Foreign Ministry spokesman Daniel Bernard said France had not been officially informed of the demands and added that France ``will not give ourselves over to any negotiations, to any trading with anybody.'' Al-Hadithi said the request was not a precondition to allowing the foreign women and children to leave the country. But if it were denied, he said, they might have to travel overland. He said the foreign men still held in Iraq are being held at potential military targets all over the country. Baghdad has already said the captives would be used a human shields for key installations. ``Every place, every town that has a vital installation will host our guests,'' al-Hadithi said. Iraq refers to the captives as ``guests.'' ``We're relocating the foreign men all over the country at airports, air bases, military bases, industrial plants, communications centers, power centers and oil refineries _ wherever Iraq considers it has a vital installation, one exposed to the American threat in Saudi Arabia,'' he said. The United States has tens of thousands of troops deployed in Saudi Arabia, along with contingents from other nations. Some 21,000 Westerners were stranded in Kuwait and Iraq after Iraq invaded on Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil, money and land. On Tuesday, Saddam announced he would allow the foreign women and children to leave to preserve the ``Arabs' humanitarian image.'' Among the first to depart were 19 Italian women and children who crossed the desert and arrived in Jordan on Friday, and three Finnish women who crossed into Turkey. Britain's Foreign Office said Friday that Iraq has issued exit visas to 139 British women and children, but hundreds of others were waiting for theirs. The Foreign Ministry in Bonn said it expected 100 of its nationals to be among the evacuees. In Stockholm, Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Anita Matejovsky said some of about 50 Swedish women and children in Iraq received exit visas Friday and that the rest were promised theirs on Saturday, she said. Two dozen other Scandinavians were expected to be evacuated, along with 16 Spaniards, five Greeks and 17 Cypriots. The U.S. State Department had said that about one-third of the 3,000 Americans trapped in Kuwait and Iraq are women and children who should be allowed out. U.S. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Iraqi authorities rounded up five more Americans. She said one American woman was granted an exit visa and allowed to leave for Jordan. A U.S. diplomat in Baghdad said no American women and children had been granted exit permits by Friday. There was no explanation for the discrepancy. ``The Iraqis still have 100 percent control on the detainees,'' said the diplomat, who asked that his name was not used. On Thursday, the State Department criticized Iraq for dragging its feet in releasing the American women and children. A group of 316 Soviets left for Moscow Friday aboard an Aeroflot plane. Aeroflot is the only foreign airline that has been allowed to land in Baghdad since the invasion. A Soviet official in Baghdad said about 800 Soviet civilians have been airlifted in recent days, while hundreds of others traveled to Jordan across the desert. A senior Asian diplomat complained about the confusion over the evacuation procedure. ``It's a very confusing situation. One official says something, the other says the opposite,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Six Months Needed to Stabilize Soviet Economy
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said the government will choose from among four plans for major economic reform and will try to stabilize the faltering economy within six months. And in an indication of the urgency he attaches to fixing the country's economic woes, Gorbachev said he would cut back on foreign travel. The Soviet economy is wracked by shortages of everything from medicine to cigarettes and citizens are furious. Politicians are pushing for economic reforms of varying speed and scope. Four separate panels are currently working on widely different proposals to move the Soviet economy from a centrally planned, command system to one driven primarily by market forces. But speaking to reporters after a two-day session of government advisory bodies, Gorbachev said officials believe the country should settle on one blueprint for major economic reform. ``We must come out with one program,'' Gorbachev said. ``If we lose two or three months ... it will affect things in such a way that we will have to make corrections not only in tactics but strategy.'' The commissions include a group supervised by Gorbachev and Russian federation president Boris N. Yeltsin, who favors faster moves toward a market economy than Gorbachev and Kremlin leaders. They went to work after the national legislature, the Supreme Soviet, rejected Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov's blueprint for a transition to a market economy. The Supreme Soviet reconvenes Sept. 10 to take up the latest proposals, which Gorbachev said would not be ready for another week. Yeltsin has said that if the central Soviet government's plan is not to his liking he will implement radical and swift economic reform in Russia, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. That would be a major blow to unity of the Soviet Union, already fractured by bitter ethnic and political clashes. But Gorbachev said that at a joint meeting of the presidential and federation councils this week, participants came to a ``general understanding of the situation, its crucial nature and most importantly an understanding of the need to act together, cooperating.'' Gorbachev is scheduled to visit France in the fall but appeared to rule out another trip he had been expected to make, to Spain in order to push along the nation's economic reform. The Soviet president said serious measures would be taken in the next six months to cut off Soviets' ability to accumulate ``hot money,'' the term for income derived from black marketeering and other activities. The Soviet Union suffers from what economists call a ``ruble overhang,'' a supply of rubles far outstripping the supply of goods available for purchase. Gorbachev did not say exactly how ``hot money'' would be controlled and did not specify what other steps were under consideration to stabilize the economy. He said the next stage of economic reform would deal with prices, taxes, the government's budget and the earning, distribution and use of foreign currency. Once the central government agrees on one of the reform plans, he said, it wil be presented to the legislatures of the Soviet republics. He acknowledged the proposals could face resistance. ``Everything is subjected to doubt, to meticulous analysis,'' Gorbachev said. He said the national legislature would also review the economic reform plan and that afterward he would issue a presidential decree confirming it. Ryzhkov's initial program, presented in May, called for drastic price increases on bread and other items whose prices have remained basically unchanged for decades. The program fueled panic buying that made ill-stocked store shelves even barer.

DOC.HEAD: Hopeful Inventors Gather to Hawk Wares
DOC.TEXT: Is the world ready for a pyramid version of Rubik's Cube or a toilet-training seat that encourages toddlers with flashing lights and a few bars of the ``Hallelujah Chorus?'' Inventors who hope it is are gathering at conventions in Anaheim and Pasadena this weekend, showing off their products and dreaming of mass marketing and big profits. An electric tooth flosser shared space with Alaskan ``moose-nugget flowers'' _ gift-wrapped excretions _ and some 120 other exhibits at the Inventors & Entrepreneurs Expo 1990 at the Disneyland Hotel in Anaheim. ``There's still this idea in America that you'll have the opportunity to take a good idea and make millions,'' said Alan Tratner, president of the Inventors Workshop International, the co-sponsor of the trade show. The Small Business Administration is the other sponsor of the three-day expo. ``This is like a lottery. This is a gamble,'' said Joseph Bland of Santa Barbara on opening day Friday. Bland, a ``third-generation inventor'' whose grandfather created an early automatic transmission, is displaying a valved-cell engine that he says can improve fuel economy by 200 percent. The odds of a licensing agreement with a major auto firm are long, he said, but he might try marketing his design as an auto supply store kit. He said he has spent $5,000 over three years in legal fees to patent his design. Inventors are often ``a little nuts,'' but must be tenacious, too, Bland said. ``I can have the greatest idea in the world, but if I don't carry it through it will die,'' he said. Fred Roberts of Clarksville, Tenn., is confident there is a place in consumers' hearts for his toilet-training seat. ``With so many mothers working, there's no mommies to potty train kids. This motivates children and speeds training up,'' Roberts said. The wooden seats, decorated with the face of a dog, teddy bear or other animal, have an electronic microchip that allows parents to record words of encouragement for their child. After a successful session, the potty plays such tunes as ``Raindrops Keep Falling on My Head'' and the ``Hallelujah Chorus,'' the animal's lighted eyes flash and the wooden ears wag. Roberts said investors have put $1 million into his recently patented invention, which he said was a hit when tested in day-care centers. Another Anaheim exhibitor, Mike Hodson, traveled from Wasilla, Alaska, seeking exposure and a possible licensing agreement for a puzzle akin to a Rubik's Cube. ``Frustum'' is designed in a trendy New Age pyramid shape. At the Invention Convention in Pasadena, some 250 exhibitors are grouped by inventions to improve the planet, improve human life, and fad or fun creations, said spokeswoman Suzanne Milstead. A ``Turtle Pack,'' which converts from a backpack to sleeping tent to chair, is billed as a possible solution to the homeless problem. Another item being displayed is the ``Mini-Flush,'' which reduces the amount of water used in each flush of a toilet. The three-day convention opening today is intended to connect inventors with companies or people interested in buying, franchising or investing in new products, she said. But the independent tinkerer also plays an important social role. ``The inventor may be the person who will help save our planet'' as it runs out of resources, she said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Foreigners
Jackson a Veteran of Many Self-Appointed Diplomatic Missions
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson, who met this week with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on the Persian Gulf crisis, has traveled the world as a self-appointed diplomat to pursue a host of missions of his own making. The longtime civil rights activist and unsuccessful presidential candidate has visited dozens of countries and conferred with more than 60 heads of state. One of Jackson's biggest coups came in 1984, when he went to Syria to secure the release of Navy Lt. Robert O. Goodman Jr., whose jet bomber was shot down during a raid over Syrian antiaircraft positions in Lebanon's central mountains. Jackson, who at the time was running for the Democratic presidential nomination, brought Goodman home to the United States a month after the pilot was shot down. Jackson called on President Reagan to meet personally with Syrian President Hafez Assad to try to reduce tension between the two countries. Assad's assistance to Jackson was seen as a clever move to influence American public opinion to change Reagan's foreign policy in the region. Over the years, Jackson's efforts in international diplomacy have taken him around the globe and provoked controversy on more than one occasion. He has hugged Yasser Arafat in Lebanon, accepted a cigar from Fidel Castro in Cuba, conferred with Pope John Paul II in Rome and advocated anti-apartheid civil disobedience in South Africa. A photograph of Jackson embracing Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, during a 1979 visit to the Middle East still angers many American Jews and caused him trouble with Jewish voters during his presidential campaigns. At one point during the 1988 campaign, Jackson met with Jewish leaders in what he described as an ``a step toward healing the wounds.'' Jackson said earlier this week he hoped to keep adversaries in the gulf talking in order to avoid war in the Middle East but that he was making the trip as a journalist, and would not be engaged in diplomatic negotiations. Jackson, who flew to Iraq for the U.S. television show ``Inside Edition,'' met Thursday with Saddam and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. He met first with Aziz, who explained to him the reasons behind Iraq's annexation of Kuwait, and later with Saddam, Iraqi officials said. No details of the meeting with Saddam were released immediately. Jackson visited the Persian Gulf in 1987, meeting Saudi Arabian and Jordanian leaders and delivering 600 pounds of Christmas gifts for the crew of a U.S. warship. In 1984, Jackson visited Castro, who then released some two dozen Americans from his jails. He also traveled to Nicaragua, where he praised the Sandinista government, to Panama and to El Salvador, where he tried to mediate differences between Salvadoran rebels and then-President Napoleon Duarte. He paid his first visit to South Africa in more than a decade in February, when he met with black leader Nelson Mandela upon his release after 27 years in prison. Jackson had been refused a visa since 1979. A year earlier, he was in Moscow to promote aid to victims of the December 1988 earthquake in Armenia and to assess the economic and political reforms of Mikhail Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Bail Set at $1 Million for Man Held; No Serial Slaying Charges Filed
LaserPhoto CSB1
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of men were under scrutiny today in the slayings of five college students, but attention focused on an 18-year-old University of Florida freshman charged with assaulting his grandmother. Edward Louis Humphrey, 18, was jailed with bail set at $1 million bond and authorities acknowledged Friday he was being investigated over the slayings at off-campus apartments in this northern Florida town. Police sealed his apartment and searched for clues in the garbage. ``There's a lot of good information that we have received that seems to bear some credence that he may be a possible suspect,'' police Lt. Sadie Darnell said. Humphrey was among as many as 100 people being checked out by homicide detectives, Darnell said. About 600 law enforcement officials are involved in the hunt. Also mentioned was Warren Virgil Tinch, a fugitive wanted in an Ohio mutilation murder who was allegedly spotted in Gainesville and nearby Ocala about a week before the slayings. The victims _ students at either the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College in Gainesville _ were found stabbed to death on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday. Investigators said three of the four women were mutilated, and that the killer appeared to have a grudge against petite brunettes with shoulder-length hair. A woman who lived at the Gatorwood apartments where the bodies of the last two victims _ roommates Tracy Inez Paules and Manuel R. Taboada _ were found told the Sun-Sentinel in Fort Lauderdale that Humphrey had a ``major crush on Tracy.'' Humphrey lived at the apartment complex for a time this summer until he was evicted. ``He'd fall over himself to be near her or to help her,'' said Rachel Olivier, 22. ``He'd go and sit by the pool and watch when she'd come out.'' Investigators, who earlier took semen and blood samples from the crime scenes, took a blood sample from Humphrey, said his public defender, Randy Moore. In Sharpes, Brevard County Judge Kerry Evander ruled there was reason to hold Humphrey on $1 million bond pending trial in October on the assault charge. ``Innocent 'til proven guilty,'' Humphrey said in a clear voice at the hearing. Humphrey was arrested Thursday at his grandmother's home in Indialantic, some 180 miles southeast of Gainesville. He was charged with aggravated battery on a person over 65. Assistant State Attorney Michael Hunt said prosecutors sought the high bond because ``he would appear to be a threat to members of his family and the community.'' But Hunt confirmed state investigators had talked to prosecutors about a possible link to the slayings. Gainesville police sealed off Humphrey's apartment Thursday and questioned anyone attempting to enter the property, located about three miles west of campus. A Florida Department of Law Enforcement plane followed Humphrey, who had been under surveillance since Tuesday, as he drove from Gainesville to his grandmother's home Wednesday. Neighbors said he had emotional problems since he received a severe head injury in a traffic accident more than a year ago. Erik Bedesem, 19, who described himself as Humphrey's best friend, said Humphrey was injured after he jumped out of his brother's car in a failed suicide attempt. He said Humphrey was taking lithium, a medication prescribed to stabilize mental illness. Funerals were held Friday for four victims in their hometowns: Christina Powell, 17, of Jacksonville; Christa Hoyt, 18, of Newberry; and Ms. Paules and Taboada, both 23 and from the Miami area. Church services were held Thursday for Miss Powell's roommate, Sonja Larson, 18, of Deerfield Beach.

A State Department spokesman in Washington said the department had heard ``several rumors over the past few days'' about possible flights out for the hostages, but had no confirmation of today's possible departure. ``We're very hopeful,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The airline official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he was told by authorities to ready a Boeing 747 for the evacuation from Baghdad. The flight was expected to take off at 6 p.m. (10 a.m. EDT), he said. It was to stop first in Amman, the Jordanian capital, and then fly on to London, Paris and finally Washington, the airline official said. The airline official said he did not know how many people will be aboard the Boeing 747 after Jackson returns from Kuwait with more evacuees. Jumbo jets can carry more than 400 passengers. Iraq's flag carrier will bring home an unspecified number of Iraqis stranded in the European capitals and in the United States since the Iraqis invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the airline official said. DOC.HEAD: Child Rights Convention Comes Into Force
DOC.TEXT: An agreement guaranteeing children the right to a healthy environment free from abuse or exploitation comes into force this weekend. The United Global Convention on the Rights of the Child takes effect Sunday in the 29 nations that have ratified it. In addition, 105 nations including all of Europe and the Soviet Union have signed the convention, indicating their intention to ratify it, but the accord is not binding on them until they do. The United States has not yet signed. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said in a statement the convention ``addresses the needs of those who are humanity's most vulnerable as well as its most cherished resource.'' He said the speed with which states ratified the convention and its entry into force less than a year after its adoption, showed the international community's deep commitment to enhancing respect for the dignity, well-being and development of the child.'' The General Assembly unanimously adopted the convention last December. The U.N. Children's Fund and many governments and private agencies say the agreement sets new standards for fighting child neglect, sexual exploitation and other abuse. It wraps together all the international laws concerning the rights of minors that were scattered among more than 80 treaties and declarations drafted over the last 60 years. The convention, however, has engendered controversy because it allows anyone 15 years of age or older to be drafted into military service, a provision the U.S. administration supported. More than 95,000 child soldiers lost their lives in the Iran-Iraq war, and over 200,000 15-to-17-year-olds serve in various armed forces worldwide, officials said. Norway, Sweden, France, West Germany, Italy, Spain, Australia, Canada, Mexico and other nations wanted the draft age raised to at least 17, and the Soviet Union said it would go along with that standard. The United States, however, held out for keeping the draft age at 15, arguing that the 1949 Geneva Conventions on warfare and the 1977 Additional Protocols specify that age, and the new convention should conform. In another controversial issue, the accord sets the end of childhood at age 18, but does not say whether childhood begins at birth or at some point earlier. That had divided anti-abortion and pro-choice advocates. The convention glosses over abortion, stating only in the non-binding preamble that children deserve special protection ``before as well as after birth.'' The United States supported the inclusion of the reference to the rights of the unborn. Recognition of children as individuals with inalienable rights began under international law in 1924, when the League of Nations adopted the Geneva Declaration on children's rights. That abolished the common custom of treating children as the property of their fathers. The Convention on the Rights of the Child recognizes the right of free association and guarantees a child the right to enjoy a family life. It extends international legal protection to the adoption procedure. Ratifying governments are required to provide adoption services so orphans can have access to family life. Under another provision, the accord says children may not be separated from their parents, except for the child's well-being. They also cannot be sold into prostitution, slavery, or used as bonded laborers to pay off parents' debts. The convention, however, lets ratifying nations set the minimum age for child laborers and regulate working conditions. Nations signing the convention must report periodically to a new U.N. Committee on the Rights of the Child. The first ``World Summit for Children'' will be held in late September at U.N. Headquarters to mobilize the world's governments to save up to 100 million children from death by disease and malnutrition in the 1990s. Canada, Egypt, Mali, Mexico, Pakistan and Sweden are cosponsoring the event to push governments to redirect spending from military budgets and payments on their foreign debts in favor of health and nutrition. The global gathering will take place during the next General Assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Hopes to Refocus Attention on Poor in Trip to Africa
By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II began his seventh voyage to Africa today, a trip the Vatican hopes will refocus world attention on the plight of the poor when all eyes are turned to the Persian Gulf. The 70-year-old pontiff was flying by special Alitalia Airbus to Dar es Salaam, capital of the East African nation of Tanzania, the first leg of a 10-day tour that will also take him to Burundi, Rwanda and the Ivory Coast. The plane made an hourlong stopover on the Mediterranean island of Malta. Church bells pealed when the jet landed, and the pope, stepping onto the aircraft's stairs, waved to a crowd at the airport. John Paul visited the island for three days in May. John Paul's 49th foreign pilgrimage will wrap up Sept. 10 with the consecration of a huge controversial basilica in Ivory Coast that rivals St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano on Friday said the pope's trip will serve to remind the world of Africa's chronic poverty, noting that the poor stand to suffer most from the Middle East crisis, which began when Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The paper described the trip as ``a journey of peace to the land of the poor at a time when, before the marshalling of arms, the world seems to wince almost only at the fluctuations in the stock markets.'' ``What new price will African poverty have to pay as a result of this new crisis?'' L'Osservatore Romano said. ``If the developed world fears recession, then what about those who already live off the crumbs from the table of the rich?'' In all, the pope will travel 11,600 miles and deliver 41 speeches. Vatican officials say the pope will speak on AIDS, which is particularly widespread in Africa. The pope has expressed solidarity with AIDS sufferers, while condemning the sexual behavior that can transmit the disease and ruling out the use of condoms as a means of checking its spread. According to the latest church statistics, the number of Catholics in Africa has increased by 50 percent in the past 10 years _ to a total of about 75 million, or 13 percent of the continent's population. Moslems are Tanzania's largest religious group, representing about one-fourth of the population of 25 million. Catholics make up 21 percent, with Protestants, Anglicans and animists accounting for the rest. Islam and the Catholic Church, the two largest religious groups in the world, have sometimes been at odds as they compete for converts in Africa. In Tanzania, church officials describe an overall situation of harmony between the two faiths, although they see signs of potential conflict with fundamentalists favoring the imposition of the Sharia, or Islamic law. In Burundi, the pope's visit will mark the end of conflict between church and state. Only three years ago, all foreign missionaries had been expelled, local priests detained, weekday church services banned and religious education halted. But since President Pierre Buyoya took power in a 1987 coup, religious freedom has been restored and the church is working with the government to promote unity in a nation often torn by violence between the Tutsi and Hutu ethnic groups. The pope will spend two nights each in Burundi and Rwanda before traveling across the continent to the West African nation of Ivory Coast, where he will end his trip Sept. 10 by consecrating the Basilica of Our Lady of Peace. The basilica, modeled on St. Peter's and nearly as large, was built by President Felix Houphouet-Boigny in his hometown of Yamoussoukro at a cost put by the government at $133 million. The president says he is paying for the church with his own money. But critics have charged the cost may be twice as high and described the basilica as a display of opulence in a poor country facing severe economic crisis. The pope waited to consecrate the basilica until Houphouet-Boigny agreed to build a hospital on the grounds. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro said the Holy See is not embarrassed by the basilica, pointing out the money was not spent on weapons. He also wondered why there was no similar outcry over the construction of mosques in Morocco, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia and Rome that are even bigger.

DOC.HEAD: 13 Million People Join Disaster Drill
LaserPhoto TOK1
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen million Japanese took part in a nationwide disaster drill today, many of them being evacuated from smoke-filled department stores or airlifted from elevated expressways and rooftops. The drill in Tokyo and nine other cities, conducted annually since 1971, marked the 67th anniversary of the Great Kanto Earthquake The powerful temblor later estimated at 7.9 on the Richter scale hit Tokyo and surrounding areas in 1923 and killed 140,000 people. Following last October's San Francisco earthquake, National Land Agency officials decided the emphasis of this year's exercise would be on ways to cope with possible urban disasters. Officials said today's drill involved 13 million people. Drill organizers released smoke in department stores and train stations to replicate conditions during a fire. In Tokyo's Edogawa Ward, a seven-mile section of the elevated Metropolitan expressway was closed for about 30 minutes as a large helicopter used a rope to lift passengers from their cars in a rescue drill. It was the first such drill on an elevated expressway in Japan, the officials said. National Land Agency chief Moriyoshi Sato flew in another helicopter to inspect an airdrop of emergency supplies, simulations of rescues of people from a collapsed house and other evacuation drills. ``As our country is naturally subject to disasters caused by earthquakes, typhoons and volcanic eruptions, the (government) will strive further to strengthen anti-disaster measures,'' Kyodo News Service quoted Sato as telling about 10,000 people who participated in the drill. Experts say an earthquake similar to the one in 1923 could hit the Tokyo region at any time. The Japanese archipelago sits along a fault line between massive tectonic plates which slowly grind against each other.

DOC.HEAD: Solar-Powered Plane Heads Toward Kitty Hawk to Close Transcontinental Flight
DOC.TEXT: A solar-powered airplane is slowly nearing the end of its wind-tossed odyssey from California to Kitty Hawk, N.C., the birthplace of powered flight. After more than six weeks, sometimes being blown the wrong way, aviator Eric Raymond still has about 240 miles to go in his 198-pound plane, Sun Seeker. But strong headwinds appear to have dashed his hopes of reaching Kitty Hawk during the Labor Day weekend, said his wife, Aida. ``He's getting desperate to get there. He just wants to finish the flight,'' Mrs. Raymond said in a telephone interview Friday. Meanwhile, the welcome mat is out where Orville and Wilbur Wright piloted a motor-powered airplane for the first time in 1903. ``There's a lot of excitement here,'' said Nancy McWilliams, spokeswoman for Kitty Hawk Kites, a hang glider school planning a reception for Raymond's arrival. ``It's been the talk of the town for the last month. Wherever I go, people say, `Where's Eric? When's Eric arriving?''' Raymond, 33, a former national hang gliding champion had logged only 18 miles for the day when he landed Friday afternoon at Virginia Tech Airport at Blacksburg, Va., about 25 miles west of Roanoke, Va. ``We've been very upset because the delays we've had on this trip have had nothing to do with the plane, they were because of the weather,'' Mrs. Raymond said. ``We thought he was going to land at Kitty Hawk on Sunday,'' she said. ``Now the weather forecast is saying the strong headwinds will keep up for another four days after today and he may not be able to fly until they stop. ``The weather forecast has been so wrong all along, we're just hoping it'll be wrong again,'' she said. When Raymond took off from the New River Valley Airport in Virginia on Friday, he had 260 miles to go, and had logged 2,168 miles in 102 hours and 35 minutes in the air. On Thursday, he braved the Appalachians, gaining 132 miles before landing about 35 miles west of Roanoke. It was July 16 when Raymond first took off from Desert Center, beginning his quest to prove an ultralight aircraft partially powered by solar energy could cross the United States. Rather than set a flying record, Raymond wants to show solar power's usefulness, said trip spokesman Jack Whitehouse. The plane has solar cells on its surfaces to run an electrical motor that turns its propeller. The motor is used for takeoffs and landings. After takeoff, the motor is turned off and the plane rides the thermals like an ultralight glider. Two days after the sojourn began, the craft was seriously damaged in an aborted takeoff from Lordsburg, N.M. Raymond and his ground crew brought the craft back by land to Lake Elsinore for repairs. Raymond manufactured and sold hang gliding equipment there until six months ago, when he devoted himself to the Sun Seeker project. The Sun Seeker had better luck after taking off again from Desert Center on Aug. 2. Although the craft hasn't crashed since, strong headwinds and rain along the way have made for slow going. In the month since, the Sun Seeker has remained grounded on eight days because of bad weather. One day the craft was forced to land after strong headwinds pushed it backwards.

DOC.HEAD: Dry, Clear Skies Across Much of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Clear skies prevailed across much of the nation today, and the southern Plains braced for another day of record temperatures that are likely to scorch the region through Labor Day. Today's forecast called for sunshine and temperatures in the 80s from the Ohio Valley to New England. Rain was expected in the Carolinas, central Georgia, southern Alabama and south-coastal Texas. Denver had a touch of showers early today, and scattered rain was likely across the Rockies, from Wyoming southward. A stationary high pressure over north Texas was expected to hold the heat wave over the southern Plains and Mississippi River valley until Monday. On Friday, temperatures soared to 105 degrees and higher in Concordia, Kan., and the Texas towns of Austin, Fort Worth and Waco. The forecast in the far West called for dry weather, with temperatures in the 80s in the Northwest, 90s in central California and 100s in desert regions. The nation's high on Friday was 111 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. and Lake Havasu City and Yuma in Arizona. DOC.HEAD: Curfew Imposed in Three Northern Districts
LaserPhoto COL2
DOC.TEXT: The government imposed an indefinite curfew on three northern Tamil districts today to enable troops to conduct operations against Tamil separatist guerrillas, military officials said. The curfew took effect at early this morning in Vavuniya, Mullaitivu and Mannar, and was announced over state radio. A curfew also was imposed in Kilinochchi, a northern town. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, gave no details of the planned military operations. Sri Lankan forces control towns in the districts, but the countryside is under the control of the Tamil Tiger rebels fighting a 7-year-old war for independence. Four soldiers, six Tamil rebels and two civilians were killed Friday in the north and east of this Indian Ocean island off India's southern coast, officials said. The four soldiers were killed and five more wounded Friday when a foot patrol triggered a land mine on Mandaitivu Island, Jaffna Peninsula, officials said. The Sri Lankan army was stalled at Mandaitivu on the 11th day of an offensive to end a rebel siege of the 23-man army garrison in Jaffna Fort. The fort on the edge of Jaffna city is linked to the islands by a heavily mined causeway the troops have failed to cross. It has been cut off for 10 weeks. The six rebels were killed when troops opened fire at the guerrillas, who had torched two mosques and Moslem homes in Palamunai, eastern Batticaloa district Friday, the officials said. The two civilians _ a Moslem and a Tamil woman _ were killed by Tamil rebels in separate attacks in the east, the officials said. At least 14,000 people have been killed since Tamil rebels began their separatist rebellion in 1983. Tamils make up 18 percent of the island's 16 million population and allege discrimination by Sinhalese, who account for 75 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: California Quake Insurance Plan on Governor's Desk
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Deukmejian's plan to require California homeowners to pay up to $60 a year for mandatory earthquake coverage was approved by the Legislature. The bill was inspired by the October 1989 Northern California quake that killed 62 people, destroyed more than 1,000 homes and caused $7 billion in damage. It was sent to Deukmejian's desk Friday evening after votes of 28-3 in the Senate and 43-21 in the Assembly. The bill would provide about 6.5 million property owners with up to $15,000 of quake insurance for an annual surcharge of between $12 and $60. It would set up a state-backed insurance pool that would be used to partly recompense homeowners' losses in the event of a quake. It initially would provide up to $15,000 in money that a homeowner would use to bridge the gap left uncovered by the average deductible. Quake insurance deductibles average about 10 percent of the market value of a home. If a home is completely destroyed, a customer can replace the house by meeting the cost of the deductible, or about $15,000 on a $150,000 dwelling. But most of the 24,000 quake-damaged homes were not completely destroyed, suffering an average of $8,000 in losses each. That was usually far less than the deductible and had to be paid by the homeowner. Deukmejian has 10 days to sign the bill, veto it or let it become law without his signature.

DOC.HEAD: China And Soviet Union Insist on Diplomacy in Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The foreign ministers of China and the Soviet Union said today that peaceful means should be used to solve the Persian Gulf crisis. After three hours of talks with his Chinese counterpart, Qian Qichen, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze told journalists the two nations were willing to cooperate to peacefully resolve the standoff. ``We did not have any disagreements,'' Shevardnadze said. ``We both support peaceful means and peaceful channels to solve the gulf crisis.'' He stopped short, however, of directly condemning the use of force in the region. Both China and the Soviet Union reluctantly supported a United Nations resolution authorizing force to back economic sanctions against Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. China said from the start it was opposed to the use of force and the Soviet Union backed the U.S.-proposed U.N. Security Council initiative only after stalling for more than a week. Qian said Moscow and Beijing had ``nearly identical'' positions. ``The present task is that parties should avoid the use of force to prevent an acceleration into war,'' Qian said in a separate meeting with journalists. The United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and other nations have warships in the gulf region. U.S. vessels are searching ships transiting the region they suspect might be breaking the embargo. In addition, the United States has sent 60,000 troops and dozens of fighter planes to Saudi Arabia aimed at discouraging any move by Iraq to seize more territory. Both foreign ministers stressed the importance of an Arab settlement to the Middle East crisis. They did not say, however, what peaceful means they would be willing to pursue jointly toward resolving the Middle East crisis. They said they intended to keep open a triangle of communication between their nations and the United States. Shevardnadze said his talks with Qian raised Sino-Soviet relations to a ``unified new level in cooperation.'' The Communist powers split over ideological differences in 1960, but in the last decade relations steadily improved, culminating with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's May 1989 visit to Beijing to normalize ties. Shevaradnadze said the two sides would hold talks on their shared 4,300 mile border on Sept. 10 in Moscow. China and the Soviiet Union came close to going to war after several bloody border clashes in 1969. Gorbachev has pledged to withdraw 120,000 of the estimated 500,000 Soviet troops stationed along the border by year's end. Qian said a new atmosphere of trust now exists between the two nations. Shevardnadze, on an eight-day, three-nation tour, visits North Korea on Sunday and Monday before traveling to Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Novelty Merchant Peddles Saddam's Picture _ on Toilet Paper
DOC.TEXT: An enterprising novelty merchant said he wants to wipe out Iraq's Saddam Hussein _ with toilet paper. The bathroom tissue bearing Saddam's picture is selling fast, says Mark Polish, 49, president of the Philadelphia T-Shirt Museum, a downtown manufacturer and wholesale distributor of novelty items. So far, 2,700 rolls have been sold, he said Friday. ``Already my inventory has been wiped out,'' Polish quipped. When Iraq invaded Kuwait, Polish immediately had his Missouri supplier start printing up rolls of toilet paper bearing the Iraqi leader's picture and the message, ``Hussein's Insane.'' ``I'm always laughing,'' Polish said. ``My object is to make people smile. It makes life a little more enjoyable. Nothing's wrong with that, is there?'' He says stores nationwide have bought the Saddam roll, with retail prices running about $5 each. ``One New Jersey woman came into my place and bought three rolls, which she's going to send to her son stationed with an Army unit in Saudi Arabia,'' Polish said. ``She thinks he'll enjoy using it.''

DOC.HEAD: Labor Day Riot Anniversary: What If They Had A Party And No One Came?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf to CORRECT typo in clergymen.
DOC.TEXT: A year after a Labor Day marred by riots and looting, this resort city is trying to make people forget by putting on its finest. Many are staying away because they remember only the worst. ``The table is set. We've got our best linen, best china, best silver, best crystal,'' Andrew Fine, co-chairman of the Community Coordination Committee, said Friday. Lingering fears that the rioting of last year might be repeated are making some of the preparations unnecessary as the city's hotels _ full to capacity during the 1989 Labor Day holiday _ are less than half full today. City Manager Aubrey Watts said that hotels were at 48 percent occupancy Friday night, but: ``It appears to be rising.'' The end-of-summer party, which for the past 10 years has attracted students from predominantly black East Coast colleges, last year erupted in looting and violent confrontations between youths and police. Damage was estimated at more than $1.4 million. Many of the young people and civil rights leaders said the clashes were racially motivated and the city did not want black visitors. City officials said the problem was one of too many people in too small an area with too little to do. More than 100,000 young people jammed the city's beachfront strip for the 1989 Labor Day weekend. Early today, young people walked and rode bicycles along the oceanfront thoroughfare. City police officers and state troopers were out in force, walking in pairs and riding horses. Clergymen accompanied many of the patrols, ready to act as peacemakers. Police Chief Charles R. Wall declined to say how many officers were on patrol, but said the entire 607-member force is working 12-hour shifts over the weekend. Police said three men in a car fired into an unoccupied car eight blocks from the oceanfront early today. No one was injured, and there were no arrests. Police said they made only a handful of arrests for public drunkenness. ``I've never seen it this quiet on a Friday night or any other night for that matter,'' said Dot Keller, who works at Clarke's Pub. Last year, police backed by state troopers and the National Guard twice cleared the oceanfront after looting broke out. Hundreds of people were arrested or cited, and more than 50 were injured. Most of those arrested were local residents, not college students. This year the city appointed a biracial committee, including students, to plan the event _ dubbed Laborfest. Local merchants raised more than $100,000 to provide entertainment along the oceanfront. Despite local efforts, some black students at schools that previously frequented Virginia Beach called for a boycott. Mayor Meyera Oberndorf said she was confident the Labor Day weekend would be a successful contrast to last year's violence. ``We will be able to show a watching world that many things are possible when people trust and show respect,'' she said Friday night. But some merchants boarded up storefronts for the weekend. Norfolk State University helped book two nights of entertainment at a city park about four miles from the oceanfront, hoping to spread out crowds that used to congregate solely at the beach. The city also closed a section of the oceanfront to cars and set up satellite parking lots away from the beach serviced by shuttle buses.

DOC.HEAD: Researcher: New Clue in Amelia Earhart Disappearance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `More and...', to add time element.
DOC.TEXT: The sighting of a makeshift water-collection device on a South Pacific island could be a clue in the disappearance of U.S. aviator Amelia Earhart during a 1937 globe-circling flight, researchers said. The World War II-era sighting by a former Coast Guard serviceman was reported in a letter to Rick Gillespie, executive director of the International Group for Historic Aircraft Recovery in Wilmington, Del. ``More and more, it looks like we're closing in on learning exactly what happened,'' he said Wednesday. Richard Evans, 64, of Annville, Pa., wrote describing the rain-water collection apparatus he found while exploring an isolated section of Nikumaroro, about 1,000 miles northeast of Fiji. Investigators last year found another possible clue to the Earhart disappearance on the island, a navigator's bookcase that could have come from Earhart's two-engine Lockheed Electra airplane. Evans described the water-catching device as a canvas funnel draining into a 5-foot-by-2-foot metal container. ``We didn't build it and the natives didn't build it. If it's Earhart's, who knows? People are really getting excited about it, though,'' said Evans, who was assigned to the now-uninhabited island to help build a Coast Guard navigation and communications base. Gillespie said the dimensions of the canvas and container, as described by Evans, closely match the engine covers and one of the 149-gallon fuel tanks from Earhart's plane. It could suggest Ms. Earhart and her navigator, Fred Noonan, survived a landing there in July 1937 and waited in vain for rescue, Gillespie said. Evans said he wrote the letter to Gillespie after reading a news report on the hunt for Earhart's plane. ``The water-collection structure was on the windward side of the island. The water's rough and you can't land a boat. But it was a good spot if you were looking for a rescue plane,'' said Gillespie. Researchers theorize Earhart and Noonan landed on the island's coral reef flat, but waves and tides carried the plane into the 2,000-foot-deep trench surrounding the atoll. The team is scheduled to visit the island next summer and may conduct deep-water probes for the plane. ``If it's down there, the water is cold enough that it should be well preserved,'' Gillespie said. Earhart's possible route was tracked to the island by two retired military aviators who used 1930s navigation techniques to plot her likely course. Tom Willi and Tom Gannon of Fort Walton Beach, Fla., persuaded the aicraft recovery group to mount their $250,000 expedition last year.

DOC.HEAD: Syrian Troops Deploy Around Christian Enclave
DOC.TEXT: Syrian troops and Lebanese soldiers loyal to President Elias Hrawi today deployed around the gateways into the Christian enclave amid reports an offensive to crush rebel Gen. Michel Aoun was imminent. Security sources said hundreds of Syrians and mainly Moslem Lebanese troops were taking up positions along the western side of the Green Line dividing Beirut into Moslem and Christian sectors. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Syrians also were deploying in the hills to the north and east of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave north of Beirut. The enclave, in which an estimated 1 million Christians live, has been ringed by the Syrians and their militia allies since April, when Aoun declared a ``war of liberation'' to drive out the Syrians. The Moslem Voice of the Nation radio said Aoun has ringed his headquarters in the shell-wrecked presidential palace in Beirut's eastern Baabda suburb with tanks to confront any attack. The buildup followed a summit in Damascus Wednesday between Hrawi and Syrian President Hafez Assad, who pledged to provide the Lebanese government with ``any assisstance needed to extend its authority over the whole of Lebanon.'' Aoun controls about 40 percent of the enclave after an eight-month power struggle with Christian militia chieftain Samir Geagea for control of the territory. Aoun refuses to recognize Hrawi, who was elected Nov. 24 to implement an Arab League-brokered plan to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun rejects the plan because it does not guarantee the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops deployed in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab league peacekeeping mandate. He considers the Syrians, who have sided with the Moslems, an army of occupation. The peace plan, ratified by the Lebanese parliament in October, gives the Moslems, who make up about 55 percent of Lebanon's 4 million people, an eqaul share of power with the traditionally dominant Christians. Hrawi has sacked Aoun as interim prime minister and army commander. But the general refuses to step down or hand over the ruined presidential palace that is a symbol of constitutional authority in Lebanon. Voice of the Nation, along with other radio stations and Beirut newspapers, predicted that Hrawi's troops and Syrian forces would soon launch an assault to evict Aoun from Baabda if he refused to move out peacefully. The leftist As-Safir daily said civilians were fleeing Baabda and its Aoun-controlled environs because they feared an attack was likely. Aoun commands about 19,000 mainly Christian troops. It was not immediately clear how many troops the Syrians were deploying around the enclave. Hrawi's forces include 22,000 Moslem troops commanded by Gen. Emil Lahoud, but they are poorly equipped. Many have sat on the sidelines of the civil war for the last few years, and it was not clear whether they would participate in an assault on Aoun. Geagea, Aoun's Christian rival and commander of the Lebanese Forces militia, has at least 6,000 fighters and thousands of reservists. It was not clear whether Geagea, who has said he accepts the peace plan, would participate in an offensive against the general.

DOC.HEAD: Sources: Arab Peacekeeping Plan Discussed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with sources saying two discussed Arab buffer force, announcement possible Saturday. Pickup 6th, `Hassan is...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Iraq's foreign minister discussed a plan to deploy an Arab peacekeeping force as a buffer between U.S. and Iraqi troops, Jordanian officials said today. The senior officials declined to say how much of the plan needed to be cleared with the governments involved. But one official, speaking on condition of anonymity, hinted that there would be an announcement later today. Sources also said the Soviet Union might play a mediating role in working out a simultaneous withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and the multinational force in Saudi Arabia. The United States has repeatedly said its forces will not withdraw from the gulf region until Iraqi soldiers have left Kuwait. Perez de Cuellar, and the Iraqi foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, held a second day of talks on the Persian Gulf crisis today. Earlier, an official said both were optimistic. The two discussed prospects for freeing foreign hostages in Iraq and for a settlement in Kuwait, the sources said. ``The situation is very promising,'' said a senior Jordanian source with access to the talks. He refused to elaborate. Perez de Cuellar and Aziz are trying to find common ground to defuse the crisis that began with Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. They met today after conferring for 2{ hours with Crown Prince Hassan at the royal palace. Hassan is regent in the absence of King Hussein, who is on a foreign tour seeking support for an Arab solution of the crisis that began with Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and later annexation of its oil-rich neighbor. As Hussein continued his diplomatic mission, the Arab League concluded a two-day meeting in Egypt. The League hardened its position on the invasion by demanding Iraq pay war reparations to Kuwait after withdrawing its troops. The League also demanded that Iraq immediately free 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans, it has held hostage since overrunning Kuwait. Only 13 of the League's 21 members were present to adopt the new resolutions, indicating how the crisis has divided the Arab world. About 60,000 U.S. troops sent to Saudi Arabia face more than 200,000 Iraqi troops along the Saudi borders with Kuwait and Iraq. In addition, dozens of warships from the United States and other nations are patrolling the gulf region to back up U.N.-imposed economic sanctions on Iraq. Arab countries opposed to the invasion also have sent small contingents of soldiers to the multinational force led by the United States. Perez de Cuellar and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz met in the royal palace amid reports that Iraq would begin freeing foreign women and children. Perez de Cuellar late Friday hailed Baghdad's decision to release the women and children as ``an important step forward.'' ``But from my point of view, this is not enough,'' he said. ``I hope this first decision of the Iraqi government will be followed by other decisions which will allow all foreigners to leave the area.'' The U.N. leader said a decision by Iraq to release all foreigners would help reduce tension Middle East. Some of the Westerners held captive in Iraq and Kuwait have been moved to strategic installations to deter a U.S. attack. The U.N. chief has said he is not meeting Aziz to negotiate or make concessions on the U.N. Security Council resolutions demanding an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. He said his purpose was to discuss all aspects of the problem with Aziz in an effort to solve the crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Two Officers Wounded, Suspect Dead in Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A motorist who was stopped early today on suspicion of drunken driving grabbed an officer's gun, wounding the officer and a second policeman before shooting himself to death, authorities said. Pembina County Sheriff's Deputy Miles Nelson stopped the suspect on a possible charge of driving under the influence shortly after 1 a.m., according to Deputy Cal Cluchie. An ``altercation'' occurred in which the man took Nelson's service handgun and shot him, Cluchie said. Nelson managed to call for assistance as the man fled. Cavalier Police Chief James Johnson, responding to the call, was also wounded as he attempted to stop the man, Cluchie said. The suspect was later found nearby with a fatal gunshot wound, apparently self-inflicted, he said. Nelson was listed in critical condition at the United Hospital in Grand Forks, and Johnson is listed in stable condition at Pembina County Memorial Hospital. No other details were immediately available. Cavalier is located about 15 miles south of the Canadian border in northeastern North Dakota.
