DOC.HEAD: California Legislature Rejects Moving Up Primary
DOC.TEXT: A proposal to move up California's presidential primary from June to the first Tuesday in March, a week after the nation's leadoff primary in New Hampshire, has been defeated. Lawmakers could not agree on whether to let ballot measures share the election. Republicans argued that Democrats could benefit if voter initiatives were allowed to share the primary ballot. Democrats would likely post a higher voter turnout in their drive to restore their party to the White House, they said. Without ever voting on the proposed shift, the legislators killed it Friday by voting down a constitutional amendment tied to it by Ken Maddy, Republican leader of the state Senate. Such votes require a two-thirds majority to pass. Supporters said moving the primary forward would change the California election from an afterthought into the nation's dominant early primary. The early vote was intended only for electing presidential convention delegates, with primaries for congressional, legislative and other races in June. But California's constitution requires that any measure qualified for the ballot by voter initiative petitions must go on the next statewide ballot. State initiatives in recent years have included huge property tax cuts, a cigarette tax hike and major insurance, education and environmental measures, so the early ballot could have allowed voters of one party to decide major policy issues. The California primary, now one of the latest in the nation, has not had a strong impact on a presidential nomination race since 1972, when George McGovern's victory in California cleared the way for his nomination as the Democratic candidate.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev and Yeltsin Split on Economic Plans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with comments from Yeltsin. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: After collaborating on an economic reform proposal, rifts have developed between President Mikhail Gorbachev and the leader of the nation's largest republic over the final policy's scope and speed. The clash was a setback to reconciliation efforts between Gorbachev and Russian Federation President Boris Yeltsin, who indicated he could adopt an independent policy for his republic with a more market-oriented approach. Gorbachev said the government will choose from among four plans and will try to stabilize the faltering economy within six months. The Soviet economy is wracked by shortages of everything from medicine to cigarettes, and citizens are furious. Politicians are pushing for economic reforms of varying speed and scope. Four separate panels are currently working on widely different proposals to move the Soviet economy from a centrally planned, command system to one driven primarily by market forces. ``We must come out with one program,'' Gorbachev said Friday. ``If we lose two or three months ... it will affect things in such a way that we will have to make corrections not only in tactics but strategy.'' The commissions include a group supervised by Gorbachev and Yeltsin, who favors faster moves toward a market economy than Gorbachev and Kremlin leaders. They went to work after the national legislature, the Supreme Soviet, rejected Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov's blueprint for a transition to a market economy. The Supreme Soviet reconvenes Sept. 10 to take up the latest proposals, which Gorbachev said would not be ready for another week. But Yeltsin has said that if the central Soviet government's plan is not to his liking he will implement radical and swift economic reform in Russia, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. Yeltsin believes Ryzhkov's plan would maintain the central government's command system that he blames for causing the country's economic problems. ``If implemented, it would lead to a collapse,'' Yeltsin said. Gorbachev said serious measures would be taken in the next six months to cut off Soviets' ability to accumulate ``hot money,'' the term for income derived from black marketeering and other activities. The Soviet Union suffers from what economists call a ``ruble overhang,'' a supply of rubles far outstripping the supply of goods available for purchase. Gorbachev did not say exactly how ``hot money'' would be controlled and did not specify what other steps were under consideration to stabilize the economy. He said the next stage of economic reform would deal with prices, taxes, the government's budget and the earning, distribution and use of foreign currency. Once the central government agrees on one of the reform plans, he said, it wil be presented to the legislatures of the Soviet republics. He acknowledged the proposals could face resistance. ``Everything is subjected to doubt, to meticulous analysis,'' Gorbachev said. He said the national legislature would also review the economic reform plan and that afterward he would issue a presidential decree confirming it. Ryzhkov's initial program, presented in May, called for drastic price increases on bread and other items whose prices have remained basically unchanged for decades. The program fueled panic buying that made ill-stocked store shelves even barer.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis At-A-Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with report on Bush-Gorbachev summit, more on hostages, Perez de Cueller talks. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:

Bush administration sources said today that President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet soon to discuss the Middle East crisis, most likely in Helsinki, Finland. Details were sketchy, but the sources said the meeting could take place as early as next weekend. Although it has backed U.N. resolutions opposing Baghdad's invasion of Kuwait, Moscow has taken a relatively small role in trying to resolve the crisis.

U.N. chief Javier Perez de Cuellar held a second day of talks with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Amman, Jordan. Senior Jordanian officials said the two discussed the possible deployment of Arab troops as a buffer between U.S. and Iraqi forces, and the possibility of Moscow mediating a withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and the U.S.-led multinational force from Saudi Arabia. No details were disclosed, but one official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said an announcement was possible today.

An Iraqi Airways jumbo jet was expected to ferry scores of foreign women and children out of Iraq today. A source said the plane would stop first in Amman, Jordan, then fly to Paris, London and Washington. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein says all foreign women and children can leave, but red tape has delayed their departures, and Iraq continues to move foreign men to military installations to shield them from a U.S. attack.

U.S. diplomats in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait told the Rev. Jesse Jackson the roughly 2,000 Americans left there are hiding from Iraqi troops in fear of being used as hostages, The New York Times reported today. The diplomats, who have been resisting an order from Iraq to shut down the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City, said they are running out of water, their food is spoiling because they lack electricity and no air-conditioning means they sleep outside for some relief from the heat.

Iraq began rationing food today in an effort to outlast the U.N. embargo. Sources in Baghdad say coupon books have been issued and food distribution centers have been set up. Long lines have formed at bakeries in Baghdad, and at food shops in smaller towns, the sources said in telephone interviews. Flour, rice, dried beans, grain and powdered milk have disappeared from shops. Meat vanished days ago. Pharmacy shelves were empty of medicines, and hospital officials spoke of dwindling supplies of antibiotics and anesthesia, the sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Some Advocate Military Action In Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS one graf after 2nd pvs, Britain, Israel ..., to UPDATE with Bush-Gorbachev summit. ^By GEORGE GEDDA
DOC.TEXT: As the Iraqi takeover of Kuwait begins its second month, some experts from within and outside the government believe direct U.S. military action may be the best way to end the Persian Gulf crisis. Britain, Israel and Saudi Arabia are said to be recommending the military approach along with some members of Congress. Some within the administration are offering the same advice, although President Bush's spokesman dismissed such accounts as ``uninformed speculation.'' The crisis has prompted Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to hold a summit meeting, perhaps as early as next weekend in Helsinki, Finland, administration sources said. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, has urged military action against Iraq. But among lawmakers who left for the Persian Gulf Friday on a fact-finding mission, none advocated an attack in comments to reporters. The commander of the U.S. forces in the Middle East, Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, ruled out the possibility that the United States might initiate hostilities. ``There's not going to be any war unless the Iraqis attack,'' Schwarzkopf told reporters late Friday after spending the day visiting American troops in northeast Saudi Arabia. Still, military commanders in the area say the capability of attacking Iraq is there and growing by the day as more forces arrive. Alan Keyes, a former top State Department official in the Reagan administration, told the Cable News Network Friday, ``It may require that we'll have to hit him (Saddam) once militarily before he sees the light.'' Bush dispatched U.S. forces to the region three weeks ago, saying their mission was defensive. But Iraqi diplomats have noted that the presence of Stealth fighters gives the United States an offensive capability. The Washington Times reported Friday that Saudi Arabia, Britain and Israel were urging President Bush to resolve the crisis with military force. Leaders in those countries reason that the alternative would be to leave oil-rich countries of the Persian Gulf at the mercy of Iraq's conventional, chemical and nuclear weapons once U.S. and other foreign forces leave the region, the newspaper said. Some U.S. officials agree with this position, the Times said. Meanwhile, an Iraqi Airways jetliner was scheduled to ferry scores of Western women and children out of Iraq and occupied Kuwait today, Iraqi government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi said. It was not immediately clear how many would be on the first flight, but officials say 237 people already have been assembled in the Iraqi capital and have exit visas. Civil rights leader Jesse Jackson, who is visiting Baghdad, will accompany the evacuees on the trip, said al-Hadithi. Some 3,000 American women and children have been promised permission to leave Iraq. ``The Iraqis insist on stringing this out and putting all of these innocent people through this cruel ordeal,'' said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. She said the Iraqis have been adding layers of red tape to the departure process. Ms. Tutwiler also said the State Department is keeping track of possible war crimes by Iraq. ``We are, of course, very concerned about Iraq's violations of international law, including the taking of hostages and the use of civilians as a shield against military action,'' she said. She added it was ``normal policy'' for the U.S. government to maintain files on possible violations of the laws of war. Bush spoke to Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand in a series of morning phone calls, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. The president is sending Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady to visit allies next week. Brady's trip will take him to London, Paris, Seoul and Tokyo, according to an administration source who spoke on condition that he not be named.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LONDON
Prince Charles Recovering from Arm Surgery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last pvs, `Princess...' to CORRECT name to Clifton. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles was recovering today after a three-hour operation to repair a slow-healing break in his upper right arm, a hospital spokesman said. There were no complications and the prince's condition was ``excellent,'' said Nigel Clifton, general manager of the Queen's Medical Center in Nottingham. Surgeons installed a titanium plate to permanently hold the broken bone in place, and the grafted small pieces of bone from the prince's hip to stimulate healing of the fracture. The prince, who is first in line of succession to the throne, broke the arm in two places when he fell during a polo match two months ago. One fracture was healing naturally, but the other required surgery. Princess Diana was at the hospital during her husband's operation. He is expected to be up and walking within two days, but may be hospitalized for as long as 10 days, Clifton said.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam-U.S. Teams End Longest MIA Search
DOC.TEXT: U.S.-Vietnamese teams have finished their longest joint search ever for the remains of missing American servicemen, the official Vietnam News Agency said Saturday. The search Aug. 6-Aug. 31 involved more teams and specialists than ever before, said the report, monitored in Bangkok. U.S. forensic experts examined 70 sets of remains that the Vietnamese said they previously found on their own searches. The Vietnamese agency did not say what the outcome was. Any remains suspected to be those of Americans missing from the Vietnam War are flown to U.S. military laboratories. The U.S. experts are from the Joint Casualty Resolution Center and the Army Central Identification Laboratory, both Hawaii-based agencies that try to account for America's wartime missing. The Pentagon lists 2,300 Americans missing from the war that ended in Communist victories in 1975 in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. About 70 percent are missing in Vietnam. The latest joint search was the 11th since the first one in September-October 1988. The United States and Vietnam still do not have diplomatic relations, but on Friday they held their second round of talks seeking an end to the war in Cambodia between guerrillas and the Vietnamese-installed government.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Passengers Reported Missing in Bus Accident
DOC.TEXT: Authorities searched on Saturday for at least 20 passengers reportedmissing after a bus slid off a highway bridge into a river, a news agency reported. Four people managed to escape through windows after the bus plunged about 60 feet into the river near Yochon, about 35 miles southeast of Seoul, according to Yonhap, the South Korean news agency. The rescued passengers told Yonhap there were about 20 others missing. The accident occurred when the bus tried to maneuver around a car parked in the middle of the bridge. The bus was swept more than 300 yards downstream, Yonhap said. Police frogmen and two military helicopters were called to the scene.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Eastern Ethiopia Needs Drought Relief
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of thousands of people in eastern Ethiopia face famine conditions as a spreading drought enters its second year, officials say. Yilma Kassaye, head of the Relief and Rehabilitation Commission, said Friday that the drought wiped out crops in the eastern highlands and threatens the lives of livestock in the country's arid southeast. Yilma said 200,000 people in the highland region of eastern Harrar already were receiving assistance from the agency. Aid was was being organized for another 252,000 people in the western part of the region, he said. Drought also is threatening hundreds of thousands of people and livestock in the adjoining regions of Dire Dawa and Ogaden, he said. Yilma said the attention of international aid groups has been focused on the drought threatening an estimated 4.5 million people in northern Ethiopia.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Delays Columbia Launch Until Late Next Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with managers saying technicians will try replacing component in problem unit; Thursday launch possible. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Any time...'. SUBS 9-10th grafs, `NASA technicians...', with 3 grafs to add detail, UPDATE with second problematic instrument replaced. Picks up 11th graf, `Columbia's seven-member...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: NASA today delayed Columbia's astronomy mission until late next week to replace an electronic part used for a telescope inside the shuttle, grounded first by fuel leaks and now cargo problems. Columbia had been scheduled to lift off today with seven astronauts and the $150 million Astro observatory. The flight was called off Thursday night when the space agency discovered the fault. Workers entered the shuttle's cargo bay Friday to examine an electronic box at the base of Astro's X-ray telescope. Engineers later concluded a quick fix wouldn't be enough, saying a component in the unit or the entire unit will have to be replaced. That ruled out a launch attempt any earlier than Thursday or Friday. NASA had hoped to launch Columbia on Wednesday if the component could be fixed easily. Mission managers did not set a launch date at a meeting today, but were expected to make a decision sometime this weekend. ``Any time we get close and don't go, like a kid going to the carnival, we're frustrated and we're anxious to get going,'' said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. ``But we're not going until we're ready. I think we're getting awfully close to ready.'' The last shuttle flight was in April, when Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. Delays have brought the longest gap between missions since flights resumed after the 1986 Challenger accident. Columbia's first launch attempt on May 30 was scrubbed because of leaking hydrogen. A similar problem was found with Atlantis a month later, and its classified Pentagon flight was delayed from July to November. A beleaguered National Aeronautics and Space Administration has spent the summer also contending with Hubble's defective mirror and communications problems with the Venus-orbiting Magellan spacecraft. NASA technicians worked into the night testing a line driver, a component of an electronic box that routes electrical power and data between Columbia and the X-ray telescope. Engineers decided they could not restore communications by installing a new cable, but would try replacing a component that sends information to the line driver later today. If that doesn't work, then the whole box will be replaced. The launch also had been threatened by a problem with a middeck instrument that measures acceleration and vibration, launch director Bob Sieck said. The instrument failed to activate properly during the countdown and was replaced today. Columbia's seven-member crew planned to stay at Kennedy Space Center into the weekend. Four astronauts are astronomers who will operate Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes during the nine- to 10-day flight, probing some of the hottest objects in the universe. The X-ray telescope will be managed by ground controllers. The latest delay is not expected to affect Astro's observing schedule, said Lennard Fisk, NASA's chief scientist. Scientists had to choose new targets after the mission was delayed in 1986 by the Challenger explosion. Columbia has until Sept. 14 to lift off, otherwise it will be forced to wait until Discovery carries the sun-probing Ulysses satellite into orbit, Lenoir said. NASA must launch Discovery between Oct. 5 and 23 to take advantage of the alignment of Earth, the sun and Jupiter, whose gravitational field will slingshot Ulysses back to the sun. The next opportunity for launch would be in 13 months. Discovery's move to NASA's other shuttle launch pad was delayed until at least Tuesday because of frayed electrical connections, NASA said today. The shuttle was supposed to have been rolled out Sunday. NASA is confident Columbia will not leak excessively during fueling this time, Lenoir said. It now appears Atlantis has the same type of leaks as Columbia, which means it is a ``common problem'' more likely caused by contamination than a faulty design, he said. Columbia's new plumbing is from a different batch than the one that was removed and the one that leaked on Atlantis, and fared much better in acceptance tests, said shuttle director Robert Crippen. NASA will rely more on visual evidence of hydrogen leaks during fueling for future flights and use different criteria for sensors.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Hussein: Butcher in the West, Savior in Arab World
DOC.TEXT: To the West, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is the ``Butcher of Baghdad,'' the man who drops poison gas bombs on his own people, ruthlessly eliminates rivals _ or invades his neighbors. President Bush has questioned his sanity, and compared him to Adolf Hitler. But many in the Arab world regard him as a hero for standing up to the United States. In Iraq, crowds motivated both by fear and real admiration hail him as the savior of Arab nationalism. Whether he's portrayed as monster or messiah, nobody fascinates the world today like Saddam. In the United States, Saddam in less than a month has gone from being just another faraway despot to representing the embodiment of evil. Gas stations have put up targets with Saddam's face as the bulls eyes. T-shirts portray his face on spiders and read ``Iraqnophobia,'' a reference to a recent horror film. Tabloids such as the New York Daily News run headlines reading ``Butcher's Bargain.'' A recent Newsweek poll found that 43 percent would support Saddam's assassination. Those who have met Saddam are much in demand in the debate over whether he is a madman or fiend. ABC-TV broadcast tape of a pre-invasion interview with Sam Donaldson and Diane Sawyer in which Saddam was asked to confirm stories he had gunned down a disloyal aide. He denied it. Members of Congress spoke of Saddam wearing a gun in past meetings. Peyman Pejman, a writer for the Bismark (N.D.) Tribune who met Saddam in 1988, said the man ``has scary eyes.'' He reminded readers that ``the line between madness and genius is a thin one.'' Students of Saddam have found ample evidence to prove he is crazed, evil or both. A decade ago he presided over a firing squad that executed 20 officials for disloyalty. In 1982 he arrested an aide who questioned Iraq's invasion of Iran, and when the man's wife pleaded for his release, Saddam reportedly returned the body in a black bag, chopped into pieces. In 1981 he republished a pamphlet written by a favorite uncle titled ``Three Whom God Should Not Have Created: Persians, Jews and Flies.'' His most vicious act may have been his 1988 poison gas attack on Kurdish villages that left thousands dead. ``Psychologically, it is useful to have this incarnation of evil'' when a nation goes on a war footing against an adversary, said Dr. Jerrold M. Post, a George Washington University professor of psychiatry who has studied the psyche of Saddam and other world leaders. Yet this is a man who in his own country is referred to as ``father-leader,'' who is lionized in poems and nursery rhymes and whose portrait is hung in homes and on street corners everywhere. His personality cult is based partly on fear and intimidation, but his bold confrontation with the West has touched a chord of sympathy with millions in the Arab world. ``He wants to stand up to the bullies, rightly or wrongly,'' said Hussein Hammani, Jordan's ambassador to the United States. ``He wants the Arabs to have a sense of pride.'' Saddam's televised meeting with Western ``guests'' being held hostage in Iraq, which Bush dismissed as ``manipulative and cynical,'' may be getting better reviews in the Middle East, said Stephen Hess, an expert in politics and the media with Brookings Institute, a Washington think tank. ``I think he's playing to the rest of the Arab world, to people with longstanding grievances against Western democracies,'' Hess said last week. Saddam's also veered closely to the messianic, as when he referred to the invasion of Kuwait by saying a ``newborn child was born of a legitimate father and an immaculate mother. Greetings to the makers of the second of August, whose efforts God has blessed.'' It's such megalomania and savage use of power that have drawn comparisons to Hitler. Post, the George Washington University professor, said Saddam shares several psychological traits with Hitler, including paranoia, extreme self-absorption and lack of a conscience in the pursuit of power. ``His grandiose face masks underlying insecurity. While Hussein is not psychotic, he has a strong paranoid orientation,'' Post said. Saddam may even crave the bad publicity he is getting in the West, Post said. ``He needs the limelight, to be seen as one of the most important actors in this moment in history.'' But Post and others warned that the historical analogy to Hitler, who possessed far greater powers to destroy the international order, is flawed. Time magazine writer Strobe Talbott, in an article titled ``The Dangers of Demonization,'' writes that while comparisons to Hitler are far from preposterous, ``there is nonetheless something pernicious about the analogy.'' He said there is a danger many readers and listeners ``will, at least subliminally, take the point to its invidious extreme, Saddam equals Hitler, ergo Arabs equal Nazis.'' James Abourezk, a prominent Arab-American and former senator from South Dakota, shared such concerns. ``These kinds of overdrawn comparisons really damage the interests of Arab-Americans and our relations with all the Arab nations,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Village Cheers As U.S. Chemical Weapons Depart
DOC.TEXT: Citizens cheered as the last shipment of chemical weapons was removed Saturday from a U.S. Army depot that housed the canisters for more than 20 years. Balloons flew from some of the vehicles and ``The End'' was scrawled on the last shell of lethal gas taken by military convoy on the 30-mile trip from Clausen to Miseau, about 50 miles southwest of Frankfurt. The gas is scheduled to be carried by train to the North Sea port of Nordenham, where two U.S. ships are to transport it for disposal on the Johnston Atoll, 800 miles southwest of Hawaii. U.S. Army Gen. Dennis L. Benchoff said the chemical weapons should be out of the country within three weeks. The removal of 102,000 chemical weapon shells was conducted under a 1986 agreement. The heavily guarded convoy of 80 trucks made 28 trips between Clausen and Miesau since the project began July 26. West German and U.S. troops who took part in the transfer plan a party after the weapons are out of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Bush-Gorbachev Talks Reportedly Set; Some Hostages To Be Flown Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UDPATE with Scowcroft not confirming summit plan, Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `Also today...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4,5,DHA6,3,4,5,XSAV1,4
DOC.TEXT: In a surprise superpower bid to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis, President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet, Bush administration sources said today. Iraq, meanwhile, prepared today to fly out sick Americans and some Western women and children held for more than a month. The White House declined to immediately confirm the Bush-Gorbachev meeting. National security adviser Brent Scowcroft said ``I just don't have anything more to say at this time'' but said an announcement was scheduled for later. Also today, U.N. secretary-general Javier Perez de Cuellar held a second day of talks with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Amman, Jordan. Senior Jordanian officials said the two discussed the possible deployment of Arab troops as a buffer between U.S. and Iraqi forces. The sources also said Moscow might mediate the withdrawals of the U.S.-led multinational force from Saudi Arabia and the Iraqi army from Kuwait. No details were disclosed, but one official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said an announcement was possible today. Details were also in short supply regarding plans for the Bush-Gorbachev meeting. Sources said arrangements for the session were sketched out last week during White House Chief of Staff John Sununu's visit to Moscow, and the meeting will probably be Helsinki, Finland. Despite the diplomatic moves, Iraq said Friday it was sending more foreign men to strategic installations to deter a U.S. attack. They will replace the women and children moved to Baghdad for their impending release. ``We're relocating the foreign men all over the country at airports, air bases, military bases, industrial plants, communications centers, power centers and oil refineries _ wherever Iraq considers it has a vital installation, one exposed to the American threat in Saudi Arabia,'' said Iraqi government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi. About 21,000 Westerners _ including 3,000 Americans and 4,500 Britons _ have been prevented from leaving Iraq and Kuwait. An Iraqi Airways jetliner was scheduled to ferry scores of Western women and children out of Iraq and occupied Kuwait today, al-Hadithi said. It was not immediately clear how many would be on the first flight. The government spokesman said a Boeing 747 was expected to take off from Baghdad at 6 p.m. (10 a.m. EDT). It will stop first in Amman, the Jordanian capital, and then fly on to London, Paris and finally Washington, he said. American civil rights leader Jesse Jackson, who is visiting Baghdad, will accompany the evacuees on the trip, said al-Hadithi. Jackson flew to Kuwait this morning to pick up ``four or five'' seriously ill Americans and take them back to Baghdad, said al-Hadithi. Officials say 237 people already have been assembled in the Iraqi capital and have exit visas. Al-Hadithi did not say whether the ailing Americans were men or women or elaborate on their condition. The Americans apparently have been in hiding in Kuwait and al-Hadithi said Jackson appealed for their release on humanitarian grounds. Japan's Foreign Ministry said a plane chartered by the Japanese government left for this morning Jordan to pick up Japanese women and children allowed to leave. A Foreign Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a total of 80 Japanese, including 68 women and children and 12 dependents of Japanese Embassy personnel in Iraq, are to be flown to Japan. The West Germany Foreign Ministry said a commercial airliner flew from Frankfurt to Iraq today to pick up German women and children held. About 1,000 West Germans are among the stranded Westerners. In Kuwait, U.S. Embassy diplomats resisting Iraqi orders to close the mission said water was running low, food was spoiling and they were sleeping outdoors to escape the heat, according to today's New York Times. Power, and therefore air-conditioning, was cut off at many of the city's embassies. Four days after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Iraq annexed its oil-rich neighbor. Later, Iraq ordered the 60 Kuwait embassies moved to Baghdad. Iraqis were also reported suffering hardships because of the U.N.-imposed economic sanctions which are being backed up by U.S. and other foreign warships patrolling the Persian Gulf region. Iraq has issued coupon books to prepare for rationing, which began today, said sources in Baghdad speaking on condition of anonymity. They said food distribution centers have been set up. The coupons entitle each Iraqi to a monthly allocation of 13 pounds of flour, 3.3 pounds of rice, 2.2 pounds of sugar, 3.5 ounces of tea, 1.1 pounds of oil, 17 ounces of detergent and one bar of soap, the sources said. Children under one year of age receive three cans of powdered milk each month, but older children receive none. Fresh fruit and vegetables from summer crops remained plentiful, the sources said. A week ago, the United Nations authorized the growing armada in the gulf region to enforce the embargo, which has shut down Iraq's oil exports _ the country's main source of foreign exchange _ and prevented most imports. Last year, Iraq spent $2.9 billion to buy about 75 percent of its food from the United States, Canada, Australia, Turkey, Sri Lanka and elsewhere. Long lines have formed at bakeries in Baghdad, and at food shops in smaller towns, the sources said in telephone interviews. Flour, rice, dried beans, grain and powdered milk had disappeared from shops and meat vanished days ago. Pharmacy shelves were empty of medicines, and hospital officials spoke of dwindling supplies of antibiotics and anesthetics, the sources said. Iraq has a two- to four-month stock of staple food, according to U.S. government and trade estimates. Some experts speculate that Iraq could stretch its stocks to withstand a six-month siege. On Tuesday Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein promised to free women and children, but the releases had been held up by Iraq's requirement of an exit visa and other demands. Nineteen Italians _ 16 women and three children _ managed to get out of Iraq and arrive safely in Jordan on Friday. In other developments: _In Moscow, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday blamed Saddam for the ``very dangerous'' situation in the gulf but said his nation still favors a diplomatic soution. _Arab foreign ministers on Friday ended a two-day emergency session in Cairo, Egypt, with a new condemnation of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and a call for Iraq to immediately release foreign hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Deaths Reported in Floods, Landslides
DOC.TEXT: Landslides and flooding killed at least nine people Saturday in the second spell of torrential rains in Manila and surrounding provinces in eight days, officials said. In Pampanga province north of Manila, police said 274 houses were swept away by flash floods near the U.S. Clark Air Force Base. There were no immediate reports of casualties. On Aug. 24, floods killed 13 people in the Manila area and forced more than 150,000 people to flee their homes. The Office of Civil Defense said initial reports Saturday indicated seven people died during a landslide north of Manila. It said another person drowned in nearby Bulacan province. A 3-year-old girl drowned in the Manila suburb of Valenzuela and four others were reported missing, Mayor Santiago de Guzman said. The Office of Civil Defense said about 4,200 people were forced to flee their homes in suburban Quezon City and Kalookan. The U.S. military-run Far East Network said about eight inches of rain fell in some sections north of Manila during a 15-hour period Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Arabs Heading Back to Kuwait As Foreigners Struggle To Leave
DOC.TEXT: War-weary refugees are scrambling to leave Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, but George Karam was hurrying back Saturday to reopen the Show Biz Pizza Place and Sharalynn Health Club. ``Business,'' explained Karam, a Lebanese who has spent 23 years in Kuwait. ``I've got a big investment, and they need me there.'' He smiled at the prospects. Karam was among the growing tide of people going the other way. At first, it was just a trickle of Palestinians who supported Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Now, thousands each day are crossing from Jordan into Iraq en route to Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2 and later annexed. Those crossing have mixed motives. Many Jordanian Palestinians, most of whom lived in Kuwait before the invasion, see a chance to earn an honest dinar. Others have schemes to try. Some have gone out of political zeal. Following the invasion, Saddam decreed that anyone not returning to resume activities in Kuwait within two weeks would lose residence status. The deadline has passed, but people are still going back. ``I think there is stability coming to Kuwait but much to be done,'' said Karam, who owns nine businesses. He estimates that a quarter of his 800 employees have fled. A wealthy man, Karam flew back on an Iraqi Airways flight. Many more are headed back by road. ``All my friends will go back,'' said Mohammed Yusuf, a 19-year-old student whose T-shirt declared, ``I am proud to be a Palestinian.'' He was born in Kuwait, but was in Jordan when Iraq attacked. ``Now Palestinians will have freedom,'' he said, confident that Saddam would expand rights to Palestinians and other Arab foreigners that were denied them under the deposed Kuwaiti royal family. ``We love Saddam, we love him,'' repeated Yusuf's friend, Samir Mohammed, another Kuwaiti Palestinian who was about to head home. ``We is wonderful, he is our tiger of the Arab world,'' Mohammed said. Searching his English vocabulary for more words, he added: ``A gentleman.'' Some 300,000 Palestinians lived in Kuwait before the invasion. They made up the largest expatriate community. As the well-heeled refugees arrived in Amman, they found rooms in luxury hotels vacated by Jordanian Palestinians going back. ``They are all going, shopkeepers, engineers, people with businesses, everyone,'' said a Jordanian hotel executive who asked not to be named. A reporter at the Jordanian-Iraqi border last week saw two Palestinian student refugees alone in a hired van. Five days later, he saw the van returning to Kuwait, jammed with adults, children and luggage. The returning refugees, who often surpass 2,000 a day at the Ruweishid crossing, are joined by others coming across other land borders and on flights from Arab capitals. Refugees report that although Iraqi troops are closing in on foreigners in Kuwait, and some items are running short because of the international blockade on Iraq, the reduced population is living relatively normally. Karam said his motives were not political. He thought of Kuwait without pizza and exuded the air of a businessman who knows how to sniff the wind. ``I am going back,'' he said, rushing off to catch his plane.

DOC.HEAD: Klansmen Don Hoods While Mask Law Appeal is Pending
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with march and rally held, add law's penalty, change references to hoods sted masks; RESTORE first reference to Miller in 9th graf pvs, `This afternoon...'. Note contents of second graf.
DOC.TEXT: For the first time since 1951, police didn't stop members of the Ku Klux Klan from donning hoods this morning for a march in this northeastern Georgia city. About 100 Klan members and white supremacists marched through Gainesville today, carrying a banner reading ``Stop Colored Immigration.'' They held a 40- minute rally at the Hall County Courthouse before dispersing. About 40 marchers wore Klan robes and open-face hoods and 15 wore hoods covering their faces. About three dozen spectators gathered at the perimeter of the cordoned-off march route. Only marchers, police and reporters were allowed at the march route. The turnout was lower than the 250 expected. About 340 helmeted law enforcement officers flanked the marchers, who were expected to go to Lawrenceville, about 30 miles away, for another rally this afternoon. The state's 1951 anti-mask law, which prevents concealment of identity in public places, was ruled unconstitutional in May by a state court judge in Gwinnett County. Georgia Attorney General Michael Bowers told law enforcement officers not to enforce the law while an appeal is pending. The misdemeanor charge carries a maximum $1,000 fine or a year in prison. One of the first to put on a full hood this morning was Lewis Baxter of Sylvania, ``grand klaliff'' of the Confederate White Knights of the KKK. Baxter, who identified himself, said he was wearing his hood not to protect his identity but rather ``to celebrate a victory to us. They said we'd never wear them again and we're wearing them.'' Other masked Klansmen declined to identify themselves, but did not don their robes and hoods until they approached the march area. Downtown Gainesville was deserted except for several hundred law enforcement officers. Most shops were closed and shop doors carried orange ribbons signifying the town's protest against the Klan. Only police and reporters were allowed access to the supremacists' march and rally; spectators and counterdemonstrators were restricted to a designated space near the courthouse, said Gainesville Police Capt. Marion Darricott. This afternoon, supremacists were expected at the Lawrenceville courthouse where Klansman Shade Miller Jr. was arrested last year. Gwinnett State Court Judge Howard Cook, in declaring the law unconstitutional, agreed with Miller's contention that the law violated Klansmen's First Amendment right to anonymous free speech and expression. Klan members also planned an annual cross-burning ceremony tonight in Stone Mountain on the property of longtime Klan leader James Venable.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Kills 48, Injures 250
DOC.TEXT: Forty-eight people have been killed and 250 injured by Typhoon Abe, the sixth major storm to batter China's southeastern coast this summer, the official Xinhua News Agency reported Saturday. The typhoon, which hit coastal Zhejiang province Friday morning, left 41,000 people homeless and 45 missing, Xinhua and the China Daily said. The provincial meteorological station said Abe was the most severe typhoon to hit Zhejiang in 34 years, Xinhua said. More than 10 million people in Zhejiang have been affected by the storm, with 665,000 stranded by flooding, it said. The typhoon has destroyed 283 miles of dikes, 897 dams, 209 miles of canals and 589 bridges, the report said. Abe was headed north toward Jiangsu province and Shanghai, where it was expected to cause substantial damage, the China Daily reported. China's southern coast already has been hit by five typhoons this summer.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Nearly $250,000 For Negligent Handling of Man's Ashes
DOC.TEXT: A jury awarded more than $240,000 to the family and lover of a man whose ashes were mistakenly scattered at the entrance to the San Francisco Bay. A Superior Court jury found the Neptune Society, a crematorium, was negligent in handling the remains of Robert Saari and had breached its contract to return the ashes for a private service to Saari's lover, Patrick Hinrichsen. Saari died in January 1985 of AIDS. The Neptune Society, which specializes in scattering ashes at sea, was hired only to cremate Saari. The three-week trial ended Thursday. The $242,503 award gave Hinrichsen $175,000; Saari's mother, Tyme, $62,500; and Saari's sister, Peggy, $5,000. The panel also awarded each plaintiff $1 in punitive damages against the society. Richard Jongordon, former owner of the Neptune Society, was the target of the lawsuit. ``It was one of those things,'' he said. ``One of the employees made a mistake. It was totally unintentional.'' The current owners, who took over Neptune a year ago, weren't named in the lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Preparing New Aid for Egypt, Israel
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 9th and 10th grafs pvs, Asked what ..., with four grafs to include Scowcroft comments today.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has decided to make available more high-tech weapons for Israel and is considering forgiveness of Egypt's $6.7 billion military debt to the United States, a senior administration official says. Additional weapons for Israel would bolster that country's defense against Iraq and offset recent decisions to sell Saudi Arabia more tanks and jet fighters, officials said Friday. Wiping out the $6.7 billion debt owed by Egypt for past arms sales would reward an Arab country lined up with the United States in sending troops to Saudi Arabia and taking part in the international trade embargo against Iraq. Forgiving the debt would require congressional approval. The initiative for more aid to Israel came from Israeli officials, according to congressional, government and private sources who all spoke on condition they not be identified. Israel has kept a low profile in the Persian Gulf crisis, but has warned that it would consider an Iraqi movement of troops into Jordan a hostile act. Some Israeli officials broached the idea of taking over U.S. military equipment and ammunition in Europe that would eventually be withdrawn because of expected agreements with the Soviet Union. The New York Times said in today's editions that officials were considering providing Israel with F-16 and F-15 fighters, Apache anti-tank helicopters, Patriot ground-to-air missiles that could be used against attacking missiles, and M-60 tanks. The Times said the Israeli deal could amount to $1 billion worth of arms. Asked what would be made available and when, an administration official told The Associated Press, ``No decisions have been made.'' At a news briefing today in Kennebunkport, Maine, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft said the United States and Israel were in routine annual consultations about military aid. Addressing the report on Egypt's foreign debt, Scowcroft said, ``We are and have been worried some time about Egyptian debt.'' ``We are reviewing the situation for all the countries that are heavily impacted by the gulf situation,'' he said. The Egyptian military debt, consisting of $4.5 billion in principal with the remainder interest, was amassed from 1979 to 1985. In recent years, Egypt has been getting annual grants of about $1.3 billion from the United States for military purposes. It also has been receiving economic grants approaching $1 billion annually. Current law requires that any country more than a year in arrears on debt repayment be barred from further foreign aid. Federal officials had scheduled meetings on how to avoid that penalty when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Officials considered three options: outright cancellation of the debt, a ``buyback'' in which Egypt would repay some fraction of the face amount and a freeze on interest payments. The preferred option given to the president, officials said, was forgiveness, an option opposed by the Treasury Department on the grounds that it was too large a sum to wipe off the books in a time of U.S. budget stringency. The Washington Post said in today's editions Bush had decided on forgiveness, but the senior official said such a course was ``one of the options being reviewed by the administration.''

DOC.HEAD: Chiles Tries To Hold Off Nelson; GOP Governor Readies for General Election
With AM-Political Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Sen. Lawton Chiles came out of retirement with a high-minded pledge to revolutionize modern politics. But before Chiles can lead his envisioned reforms, he must hold off U.S. Rep. Bill Nelson's bid to defeat him in Tuesday's Democratic gubernatorial primary. Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, meanwhile, no longer looks like the easy mark Democrats hoped for in the November general elections that both parties say could be a watershed for Florida. The first-term governor has ignored four primary foes in a television blitz that portrays him as a family man who fights taxes and drugs, protects the environment and works hard to get convicts into the electric chair. Recent polls have indicated Martinez is running ahead of Nelson and, for the first time, within range of Chiles, whose negative ratings with voters have risen during the heated campaign. ``I've gotten what I need out of the Democratic primary,'' said Martinez campaign manager J.M. ``Mac'' Stipanovich. Chiles and Nelson both have promised to work for the winner of the Democratic primary, which Nelson describes as ``a family fight.'' Democrats are worried, though, because a bitter 1986 primary was widely blamed for enabling Martinez to defeat the battered nominee, Steve Pajcic, and become the state's second Republican governor since Reconstruction. The GOP believes it can re-elect Martinez, win the state Senate for its first legislative majority this century, and thus control redistricting that could bring Florida four new U.S. House seats in 1992. Martinez is expected to easily win the GOP nomination against maverick state Sen. Marlene Woodson Howard, who maintains Martinez is unelectable because of his support for a services tax that was later repealed and his anti-abortion activism. Three political unknowns also are on the GOP ballot. Chiles, 60, jumped into the governor's race in April, saying he wanted to stop the domination of big money in politics. His rejection of special-interest influence could spread around the nation, says Chiles, taking inspiration from the Eastern Europe revolts. ``Come join us in the plaza!'' he implores. Nelson, who has raised almost $6 million to the nearly $2 million Chiles has raised with a self-imposed $100 limit on individual contributions, would be beholden to special interests as governor, Chiles says. ``What we're saying is the way you campaign says a lot about the way you would govern,'' he says. Chiles' running mate is former three-term U.S. Rep. Kenneth ``Buddy'' MacKay, who also has a stellar ethics reputation. MacKay, who narrowly lost the 1988 election for Chiles' Senate seat to Republican Connie Mack, persuaded Chiles to join him in a last hurrah. ``If the voters don't respond to the way we're doing this campaign, we're history,'' says MacKay, 57. Nelson, 47, is a six-term congressman who was well on his way to the Democratic nomination before Chiles entered the race. Two other Democrats dropped out when Chiles dropped in. Nelson has tried to portray Chiles' image for pristine ethics as exaggerated and says Chiles has a double standard. Chiles' health, particularly his mid-campaign return to use of the anti-depressant Prozac, also has been raised, and Nelson has implied that Chiles is a quitter for retiring from the Senate when his term ended in January 1989. But recent polls indicated Chiles was pushing his lead over Nelson well past double digits and that Nelson was suffering a backlash. Nelson's running mate, state House Speaker Tom Gustafson, was widely criticized and finally apologized for suggesting Chiles could be suicidal. Chiles has chastised Nelson for negative politics. He also has charged that Nelson, with his slogan ``a new generation of leadership,'' is trying to pit young against old. Polls have indicated Chiles' strongest support comes from voters over 60. At the Century Village condominium community in Broward County's Deerfield Beach, veteran Democratic activist Charlie Goldstein expressed resentment at the Nelson campaign. ``Everybody over age 55 has health problems. That's not an issue,'' said Goldstein, organizing a Chiles rally for Sunday. His condo community has nearly 11,000 registered voters, and the predominantly Democratic retirees in such South Florida communities are known for higher turnouts than the general population. In a televised debate, Nelson criticized Chiles for retiring at a time when he chaired the Senate Budget Committee and had 18 years' seniority that put him in good position to help Florida and reduce the federal deficit. ``It was Casey at the bat, full count, and (Chiles) turned on his heel, he walked away and walked into the dressing room and he turned in his uniform,'' Nelson said. Chiles attributed his retirement decision to ``burnout,'' and frustration with the lack of commitment by both the president and Democratic leadership to reducing the deficit. He says he decided to run for governor because the job offers a hands-on chance to make changes. The two moderate Democrats have expressed few differences on the issues. Each time Nelson has raised an apparent distinction, Chiles has responded by embracing the same position. Chiles now says he is against government interference on abortion, would ban assault rifles and supports a seven-day handgun waiting period. Nelson says Chiles has been evasive and is running a ``trust-me campaign'' that will face much heavier fire in the general election campaign. MacKay says the primary has been more negative than Chiles has faced in the past, but that it may have been good practice. Martinez has raised more than $7 million and Stipanovich is known for killer political instincts. ``Some of the attacks we anticipated, but not in the primary campaign,'' MacKay said. ``It may turn out that it's better that way. We've been able to develop a quick-response mechanism.''

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners' Flights Delayed in Baghdad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UDPATES throughout with planes still on ground in Baghdad, State Department comment, Italians arriving in Rome. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi Airways jet scheduled to fly at least four ailing Americans and 146 U.S. and British women and children out of Iraq and Kuwait was delayed in Baghdad today, sources in the Iraqi capital said. A second jetliner also sat on the Baghdad runway, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. No reason was provided for the delay. The news agency, quoting an unidentified source at the Iraqi Ministry of Culture and Information, said British and U.S. authorities had agreed to a request from Iraq for the aircraft transporting the women and children to use landing facilities and refuel. But Iraqi officials were awaiting a response to a similar request made to French officials for the use of landing facilities in Paris, the news agency said. In Paris, the French Foreign Ministry said the plane was to stop at Orly Airport to drop off 20 French women and children before proceeding to London. The second Iraqi Airways jetliner was to carry 72 women and children to Amman, Jordan _ 66 Japanese, two Australians and four others of undetermined nationality, said government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi. The foreigners were among an estimated 21,000 Westerners and Japanese who were trapped when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, causing world economic and military pressure against the government of President Saddam Hussein. Both planes had been scheduled to take off from Baghdad today at about 6 p.m. (10 a.m. EDT), al-Hadithi said. He had said at a news conference that the plane carrying the British and U.S. nationals would fly to London, then Washington. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said today that seven British and three American women received exit visas from Iraqi officials today but that their husbands, who were accompanying them, were all detained. Officials have said 237 women and children have been assembled at a hotel in Baghdad since Tuesday, when Saddam said they would be allowed to leave. Red tape slowed the process, with the government requiring exit visas. American civil rights leader Jesse Jackson was aboard a plane that flew to Kuwait this morning to pick up ``four or five'' seriously ill Americans and bring them back to Baghdad, the government spokesman said. He did not say whether the ailing Americans were men or women, or elaborate on their condition. He said Baghdad had received word from the United States ``through diplomatic channels'' that some ailing Americans were among the foreigners stranded in Kuwait after Iraq's invasion. The Americans apparently were hiding to avoid internment by the Iraqis who have used many foreigners as human shields to fend off any attack by U.S.-led multinational forces based in Saudi Arabia. Al-Hadithi said when Jackson met with Saddam earlier this week he appealed for their release. A West German commercial airliner left from Frankfurt for Iraq today to pick up German women and children, the West German Foreign Ministry said. The ministry said the flight was arranged to pick up an estimated 100 West German women and children in Iraq but would likely include other Westerners as well. ``We expect the plane to be full,'' said the spokesman. The plane has 259 seats. About 450 West Germans are in Iraq and 260 are believed held in Kuwait, the ministry said. Japan's Foreign Ministry said a plane chartered by the Japanese government left this morning for Jordan to pick up Japanese women and children allowed to leave. A Foreign Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said a total of 80 Japanese, including 68 women and children and 12 dependents of Japanese Embassy personnel in Iraq, are to be flown to Japan. In Madrid, the Spanish Foreign Ministry said 52 Spaniards were to be evacuated aboard a Lufthansa plane. Al-Hadithi, who is director-general of the Ministry of Information, said Britain and the United States have granted the Iraqi Airways jetliner permission to land in London and Washington. ``But we are surprised that we still have not received a positive response from the French government,'' al-Hadithi said. He said the same plane is to bring back Iraqis stranded in Europe and the United States since the invasion, but again provided no numbers. Britain's Foreign Office said it would have no objection to Iraqis returning to Baghdad aboard flights airlifting people out. In France, 26 Iraqi military personnel and civilians connected with the defense program remain in the cities where they were undergoing training programs before the invasion. The French have not linked their departure to Westerners in Iraq. Meanwhile, 24 Italian women and children arrived in Rome today, a day after most of them left Iraq. Twelve of the women and all seven children had been in Kuwait City during the invasion, and traveled to Baghdad a week ago. Another Italian woman from Baghdad and four from the Iraqi city of Mosul joined the group in Amman, Jordan on Friday. ``Coming home is a beautiful feeling, even if the Iraqis were always very courteous to us,'' said Regina Garofalo, a singer who had been performing at a Kuwait hotel at the time of the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Disenchanted With Reform, Nationwide Poll Finds
DOC.TEXT:
The nation's teachers are disenchanted with reform, are dissatisfied with their work conditions and feel left out of decision making, according to a survey released Saturday. Three out of five _ 61 percent _ said teacher morale at their schools was just ``fair'' or ``poor,'' according to a nationwide poll of 21,389 elementary and secondary school teachers conducted by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. A startling 96 percent said lack of funds was forcing them to spend an average of $250 of their own money on supplies to support classroom activities. Just 18 percent gave school reform efforts a grade of ``A'' or ``B,'' compared with 31 percent in a 1987 Carnegie survey. And 28 percent graded the reform movement ``D'' or ``F,'' compared with 19 percent in the previous survey. The findings ``should cause the nation grave concern,'' said foundation President Ernest L. Boyer in a forward to the report, ``The Condition of Teaching, 1990.'' ``The signals are clear that teachers think reform has more to do with politics than with classrooms and student performance,'' Boyer said in an interview. ``Sadly, after nearly a decade of intense school reform, we find the majority of veteran teachers reporting `no change' or `decline' since 1983 on many of the conditions critical to a healthy climate for teaching and learning in their schools,'' the report concluded.
Four out of 10 teachers said they'd choose another profession if they had it to do over again. ``The conclusion is clear: Improved working conditions are essential if we hope to attract and hold outstanding teachers,'' Boyer said. On the other hand, half the nation's teachers say they are more enthusiastic about their profession than when they started their careers. And 55 percent said they subordinate all other aspects of their life to their jobs. The survey was conducted by mail last January and February, based on a random sample of public school teachers in each state. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 1 percentage point. Among results: _ Seventy-one percent said they are ``not at all'' or ``only slightly'' involved in student promotion and retention decisions _ the same percentage as three years ago. _ Just 1 percent said they have a major role in evaluating peers. _ Sixty-four percent said they have less than an hour a day of scheduled time to prepare for classes. _ Seventy percent said counseling services are ``fair'' or ``poor.'' _ Thirty-eight percent complain that classes are too big. The survey also found that 20 percent of elementary teachers said neglected students are a ``serious'' problem in their school, up from 9 percent three years ago. A secondary school teacher from Illinois wrote: ``Currently seven of my students' parents ... are getting divorces. One stepfather raped his daughter; two girls told me of sexual abuse when they were young; one boy killed himself; two boys related to me of suicide attempts; one girl ran away to Florida for two months and now has a child; one got pregnant, had an abortion and now has a 2-week-old child.'' Still, state data revealed a few bright spots. Thirty-seven percent of teachers nationwide said their salaries were ``good'' or ``excellent.'' But in Connecticut, where average pay ranked second nationally at $41,412 in 1989-90, 82 percent considered salaries good or excellent. Thirty-nine percent of teachers nationwide consider morale ``good'' or ``excellent,'' but 53 percent of teachers in Maine felt that way. Nearly six out of 10 teachers in Kansas and Wyoming said support services are good or excellent. Seventy percent of Vermont teachers said they are deeply involved in choosing texts and other instructional materials.
Copies of the survey are available for $12 each from Princeton University Press, 3175 Princeton Pike, Lawrenceville, N.J. 08648.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Search Businessman's Office for Secret Computer Files
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with search of Hayes' business, computers seized, quote from Hayes. Picks up 5rd graf pvs, `According to...'.
DOC.TEXT: A federal prosecutor's secret computer files, including sealed indictments and pending FBI investigations, mistakenly were sold for $45 to a businessman who thought he was buying only a broken computer system. Charles Hayes said government agents finished a nine-hour search of his office early today for the computer equipment with the secret files. They seized nine computer terminals, a computer memory device and other assorted equipment in their search, he said. Hayes, who sells government surplus equipment, said he would have handed over the computers anyway and was trying to get back the items he had already resold. He called the sale of the equipment Aug. 3 ``the worst case of bureaucracy I have ever seen. If it is this loose, I wonder what else is missing up there.'' ``What it amounts to is I am being punished for the inefficiency in (the prosecutor's office),'' said Hayes. He said about nine people, including federal marshals and staff from the U.S. attorney's office in Lexington, took part in the search on his business Friday night. They had a search warran, Hayes said. In a lawsuit filed Thursday, the U.S. Justice Department demanded that Hayes, of rural Pulaski County, return the computers immediately. The government also wants him to tell who bought the equipment or had access to the data. Court documents said a technician failed to erase the memory of the computer at the U.S. attorney's office in Lexington before the government sold the system in July to Hayes. According to the lawsuit, the computer's memory and backup storage tapes contain sensitive details about FBI informants, federally protected witnesses, sealed indictments and personal information about employees in U.S. Attorney Louis DeFalaise' office. ``The U.S. attorney's office used some or all of the computer equipment ... to prepare and store virtually every document and record generated by both the civil and criminal divisions of the office from 1983 to 1989,'' the lawsuit said. If made public, the files could ruin criminal investigations and cause ``great harm and irreparable injury'' to the work of U.S. prosecutors. ``The seriousness of the injury to the United States of America cannot be understated,'' the lawsuit said. Within hours of the lawsuit's filing, U.S. District Judge Eugene Siler Jr. ordered Hayes immediately to return the computer system to the government and not examine, copy or distribute the data. A hearing was set for Sept. 4. Hayes said the government told him the computers' memory had been wiped before he obtained it. He said a customer bought a computer storage device and several tapes presumably containing the secret files. He said he has asked the customer to return the items. In Washington, Justice Department spokesman Michael W. Robinson declined to comment on what effect, if any, release of the tapes would have on past and pending litigation or informants. ``We can't be sure what is on there until we see it,'' Robinson said. In Lexington, DeFalaise declined to comment, citing the pending lawsuit. In a deposition, DeFalaise's former secretary said she stored all final drafts of criminal and civil matters in the computer's memory. A technician for Harris-Lanier Corp., the computer's manufacturer, thought he erased the computer's memory in January, the lawsuit said. In July, Hayes bid $45 for the system: 13 computer terminals, two central memory units, two cartridge module drives and nine printers. The system had 93 megabytes of memory and could store hundreds of thousands of pages. After Hayes picked up the equipment on Aug. 3, the Harris-Lanier technician told government officials he didn't erase the memory after all. A magnetic probe used to scramble the data was too weak. Because the computers were broken, technicians couldn't purge the memory through normal computer commands. ``The information almost certainly remained stored within some parts of the computer equipment,'' the lawsuit said. Hayes said FBI agents who visited his business Aug. 17 treated him rudely and departed after a bitter exchange when they attempted to examine his office without a search warrant. The Justice Department contends in the lawsuit that Hayes hasn't been forthcoming. The officials also contend that Hayes, with the help of his computer technician Jim Freeman, can retrieve the data. Hayes denied he has looked at the sensitive information.

DOC.HEAD: Body of 10-Year-Old Girl Found in Crushed Remains of Auto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBs last graf to CORRECT spelling of boy's name to Covarrubias sted Cavarrubias
DOC.TEXT: Police found the body of a missing 10-year-old girl in the crushed remains of a car five hours after the auto was demolished in a collision and towed away. The accident occurred Thursday night on I-395 just south of Washington, D.C., when the car was hit from behind as it was stopped for a highway construction project. Police said the other vehicle was traveling 65 mph. Police were unaware that the child, Veronica Covarrubias, remained in the first car until after her parents, two sisters and a brother were taken to Fairfax Hospital. Virginia state troopers returned to the scene at 4:30 a.m. Friday, five hours after the collision, believing the girl may have been thrown from the car. They then went to a towing company's storage lot and found her in the rear hatchback area of the crumpled car. ``The metal had just rolled up'' over the child, trooper James L. Brinkley Jr. said. ``The rear trunk came up in the front seat. That's how bad it was.'' Authorities said an autopsy will be performed, but they added that the child appeared to have died on impact. Mohammed E. Islam, 20, of Stafford, Va., was charged with reckless driving after the crash. Jose Covarrubias, 32, his wife, Roxana, 37, were listed in serious condition at Fairfax Hospital. Paul Covarrubias, 1, was listed in stable condition. A 13-year-old daughter, Roxana, was listed in fair condition. A 3-year-old girl, Danitca, was treated and released.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 11-Year-Old After Dog Cooked Alive in Microwave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old boy was arrested Saturday in connection with the microwave death of a dog owned by a Humane Society worker. A white Maltese owned by Marlene Stephens was put to sleep after it was found in a microwave oven Thursday. The dog was cooked for an undetermined amount of time, said a Canton police officer who asked not to be identified. Police declined to release the name of the youth and would say only that his case will go before Stark County Juvenile Court. Someone broke into Ms. Stephens home Thursday and placed her dog, Jo Jo, into the microwave, police said. The oven was still running when she returned home from work that afternoon, officials said. She called police before rushing the dog to a veterinarian. The injuries were so severe, however, that the dog was put to sleep Friday. In addition, her other dog, a dachshund named Satin, suffered minor wounds in the belly when someone had tried to stab the animal with a screwdriver, police said. Ms. Stephens said she believed the dog killing was ``a form of recreation.'' ``He did it for kicks,'' she said. ``He took my little dog and put her in the microwave. ``I work all day with dogs and I love them dearly,'' she said. ``Then I come home and give my dogs twice as much love. These dogs are my kids.'' Ms. Stephens said the intruder broke into her home by tearing a screen off a window.

DOC.HEAD: Lewis Telethon Moves from Las Vegas to Hollywood
DOC.TEXT: After 17 years in Las Vegas, the Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon will try to shake its lounge lizard image this weekend, moving to Hollywood in search of trendier acts, lower costs and a fresher look. The 21{-hour long Muscular Dystrophy Association fund-raiser celebrates its 25th anniversary from the Star Search Theater on Sunset Boulevard, where Ed McMahon presents his glitzy talent show. The nationwide broadcast begins at 9 p.m. EDT Sunday and ends 6:30 p.m. Monday. Among the scheduled entertainers are such youth-oriented acts as rapper M.C. Hammer, Tony! Toni! Tone!, En Vogue, cast members from ``The Young Riders,'' Fred Savage of the ``The Wonder Years'' and Bob Saget of ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' Behind the scenes, Lewis no longer acts as one of the producers and will serve only as a host. Producer George Schlatter (``Real People'' and ``Rowan and Martin's Laugh-in'') takes sole producer credit. The MDA announced in January that Schlatter would be the executive producer for the show. Lewis later said the telethon had used five other producers over the years and he welcomed Schlatter's involvement. ``I just couldn't work that hard and keep going,'' said Lewis, 64. ``Come air time, I would be so exhausted, it was hard to continue at that pace.'' But the show hasn't entirely abandoned tradition. Bill Cosby will appear in a remote feed from Las Vegas, and the program still will have such telethon fixtures as Lewis, McMahon, Norm Crosby and Top 40 radio countdown king Casey Kasem. And, Schlatter says, Lewis will probably once again sing ``You'll Never Walk Alone'' to close the show. ``I'm not looking to redo the whole thing,'' Schlatter said Tuesday. ``It's been too successful for too long. We're celebrating the accomplishments of the last 25 years and kind of renewing the dedication to moving it into the '90s.'' Over the years, the telethon has raised more than half a billion dollars to fight neuromuscular diseases that kill and cripple thousand of people annually, most of them young. The Las Vegas shows were always successful in terms of pledges, with last year's tally a record $42.2 million. But even as pledges went up, viewership went down. From 1985 to 1989, the show drew increasingly smaller audiences. In addition, it was becoming increasingly more expensive to produce the telethon from there. The accommodations had to be converted into television studios, and entertainers and crew members were flown in, usually from Los Angeles, said telethon spokeswman Jim Brown. ``We don't know how much we'll save this year because we're right in the middle of it all,'' he said. ``But we hope to save something.'' In moving to Los Angeles, the telethon can use a working television studio and can tap a ready supply of talent, much of it the stars of choice for younger viewers. Among the newer groups on the bill, Tony! Toni! Tone! has been hot on the charts this summer with its single ``Feels Good'' and En Vogue's single ``Hold On,'' has gone platinum. M.C. Hammer's album ``Please Hammer Don't Hurt 'Em'' is credited with selling over 5 million copies, more than any other rap album. One drawback might be a shortage of walk-in fans: In Las Vegas, telethon coordinators could round up willing audience members at any hour because the gambling casinos are open round-the-clock. Finding charity-minded fans at 3 a.m. on Hollywood's Sunset Boulevard could prove more problematic. The Jerry Lewis telethon began in New York City in 1966, emanating from a single TV station and raising $1 million. It moved to Las Vegas in 1973 and raised $13.5 million that year. The telethon now is carried by 200 stations and is viewed annually by an estimated 100 million people. While Jerry Lewis does his shtick in Los Angeles this weekend, Jerry Lee Lewis is twisting and shouting in a rock benefit for muscular dystrophy in San Bernardino. The three days of rock music of the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s, which began Saturday, features performers such as Lewis, the Commodores, Fats Domino and Eddie Rabbitt.

DOC.HEAD: Military Chief Says No Attacks Can Be Initiated From Saudi Soil
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia's defense minister said Saturday that foreign troops in the kingdom would not be allowed to initiate attacks unless Iraqi forces cross into Saudi territory. ``The kingdom of Saudi Arabia is not a theater for any action that is not defensive for Saudi Arabia,'' Prince Sultan bin Abdul Aziz told a news conference. His comments appeared to rule out the use of Saudi Arabia as a base for possible efforts to strike inside Iraq or drive out occupation forces in Kuwait. U.S. Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of American forces here, said Friday there would be no war unless Iraqi President Saddam Hussein made the ``awfully stupid mistake'' of attacking Saudi Arabia. U.S. officials say more than 100,000 troops, including those aboard dozens of ships in the Persian Gulf and Red Sea, are in the region or on the way. The deployment could go as high as 250,000. The U.S.-led multinational force is facing more than 200,000 Iraqi troops poised along the Saudi borders with Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil and land, then annexed the small emirate. Prince Sultan, who met with reporters after delivering a speech to Saudi military cadets, said ``any peaceful solution would have in mind the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait.'' He was vague when asked how an Iraqi withdrawal could be achieved without military action. Be he said Saudi Arabia ``will not initiate hostilities against other Arab state.'' ``War should always be a last resort,'' said Prince Sultan, who spoke through an interpreter. The prince, a younger brother of King Fahd, condemned Iraq for placing foreigners at strategic sites to serve as human shields against attack.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Safety Group Lists Longest-Lasting Tires
With AM-Tire List
DOC.TEXT: The government isn't doing a good enough job informing the public about its automobile tire testing program, an auto safety group says. So in a report for release Sunday, it drew up its own list of the longest-lasting tires. Based on the government results, the Center for Auto Safety ranked the most popular tires manufactured by 26 radial tire companies ``to help consumers buy the safest and most long-lasting tire for their money.'' ``Without readily available ratings, consumers remain at the mercy of tire companies,'' the center's Clarence Ditlow said. Ditlow said the government should be disseminating the results of its extensive tire testing program. Right now, the government will give anyone who asks its test data on nearly 1,800 passenger car tires, free of charge. But Ditlow, in a letter to Jerry R. Curry, administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said a list of the best and worst tires would be more useful. The government responded that it doesn't want to pick winners and losers. ``We're not going to make judgments,'' NHTSA spokesman Kent Milton said. ``Some people want a lot of traction and some want more mileage. It's not in our purview to say which is the best vehicle, the best tire or the best headlight.'' The government rates tires according to three grades: tread wear, traction and temperature characteristics. For tread wear, the center's list shows the General AmeriClassic and Vogue CBR VI to be the best, with ratings of 400, which would carry them 80,000 miles under test conditions. Each rating point is worth about 200 miles. General also manufacturers one of the lowest-ranked tires in the center's list: the XP2000 ZG, which tied with Yokohama's 60 and 70-A001R@A0089 for a ``rock-bottom rating'' of 50, good for 10,000 miles. ``Inconsistencies in durability and quality between and among companies are rampant,'' the center report said. It said Sears produces tires such as the Road Handler that is rated for 62,000 miles, while it also makes tires with names that evoke safety, such as the Guardsman@Weatherman, which is rated at 140, good for 28,000 miles. The center recommends that consumers get the price of tires they want to buy and divide it into the mileage rating to compare costs of various tires per mile. Manufacturers are required to mold the ratings onto the tires. The grades for traction are either A, B or C, with A being the best and C being the minimum to meet government standards. Temperature grades of A, B or C measure the tire's ability to run at lower temperatures, which help reduce the possibility of blowouts or tread separation. A government pamphlet says even a C-graded tire is ``not unsafe'' and warns that under-inflation or overloading will overheat and damage any tire and greatly increase the chance of a blowout. The pamphlet also says personal driving style, characteristics of the car and how and where it is driven, as well as tire maintenance, can influence tire life more than brand name or the price paid. The tire industry accused the center of oversimplifying the government test results. Thomas E. Cole, chairman of the Tire Industry Safety Council, said numerical tread wear grades do not guarantee tire mileage. ``The best way to maximize tire performance and highway safety this holiday and throughout the year is through proper inflation, proper maintenance and frequent inspection for road damage,'' Cole said. Regardless of the tire grade, Cole said, the actual life of any tire depends primarily on road surface quality, driving habits, tire inflation, wheel alignment and rotation. He recommended that the buyers combine the federal testing information with personal driving considerations as well as dealer recommendations.
