DOC.HEAD: Bush, Gorbachev To Meet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines previous. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and President Bush will meet in Helsinki on Sept. 9, Soviet television announced on Saturday. The Soviet announcement came as President Bush said that he and Gorbachev would meet to discuss the Middle East crisis and other international matters. ``We have many matters to discuss,'' Bush told reporters in Kennebunkport, Maine. The Soviet evening television show Vremya read the following announcement, which was also transmitted by the state Tass news agency: ``It was officially announced here that the president of the U.S.S.R. Mikhail Gorbachev and the president of the U.S.A., George Bush, will meet on Sunday, Sept. 9, in Helsinki for a discussion of international and bilateral questions.'' It would be the eighth summit between Gorbachev and his American counterpart. Five were with Ronald Reagan. U.S. officials had said earlier Saturday that Bush proposed a summit, and that it likely would be a one-day affair, essentially a meeting over lunch. Bush said he was reluctant to say that the meeting was about the crisis in the Middle East, but acknowledged it would be among the issues discussed. He said he and Gorbachev would touch upon ``a wide array'' of issues, including the conventional forces treaty yet to be concluded to cover troop reductions in Europe. He said the one-day session would be a free-flowing discussion between he and Gorbachev, but dampened speculation that Moscow would play a role in mediating the crisis with Iraq. ``I don't see a mediating role at all'' for Gorbachev, Bush said. ``There are a lot of mediators out there.'' Arrangements for the Bush-Gorbachev summit were sketched out during White House Chief of Staff John Sununu's visit this week to Moscow, administration sources said. Bush and Gorbachev last held a summit May 30 to June 3 in the United States. They had met previously on the Mediterranean island of Malta in December 1989. At a Moscow news conference Friday night, Gorbachev did not mention the possibility of a meeting with Bush. But he said he is in ``constant contact'' with many world leaders, including Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Helsinki Meeting Will Be Summit No. 22
With AM-Gulf-Summit Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The one-day meeting Sept. 9 in Helsinki, Finland, between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be the 22nd superpower summit. Bush said the meeting would be held to discuss the Middle East crisis and other matters, including arms control. Summits began in World War II as the Allies debated the shape of the postwar world. Here is a list of past summits. Tehran, Iran, Nov. 28-Dec. 1, 1943 The Big Three - President Roosevelt, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Josef Stalin of the Soviet Union - discuss the war against Germany. Stalin presses for a second front to relieve Soviet armies. Yalta, Soviet Union, Feb. 4-11, 1945 Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin discuss the postwar world, granting Stalin influence over the nations that ultimately form the Soviet bloc. Potsdam, Germany, July 17-Aug. 2, 1945 President Truman and Clement Atlee, Churchill's successor, face Stalin. Truman tells Stalin the United States has a powerful new weapon, but doesn't say what it is. Geneva, July 18-23, 1955 President Eisenhower meets with Soviet Premier Nikolai Bulganin and the leaders of England and France to discuss occupied Germany. Camp David, Md., Sept. 25-27, 1959 Nikita Khrushchev, as Soviet premier, meets Eisenhower during a two-week visit to the United States. They agree to reopen talks on the status of Berlin and issue a communique calling disarmament an important issue. Paris, May 16, 1960 The meeting collapses on opening day when Khrushchev demands an apology for the American U-2 spy plane shot down over the Soviet Union. He withdraws an invitation for Eisenhower to visit the Soviet Union. Vienna, Austria, June 3-4, 1961 President Kennedy and Khrushchev meet, but talks on a nuclear test ban and arms control produce no agreement. They issue a joint communique affirming their support for a neutral Laos and willingness to maintain contact. Glassboro, N.J., June 23-25, 1967 President Johnson and Soviet Premier Alexei Kosygin meet but resolve no differences over the Vietnam War, the Arab-Israeli war and nuclear arms. Moscow, May 22-24, 1972 President Nixon and Soviet President Leonid Brezhnev meet, the first time a U.S. president has visited Moscow. They sign agreements on health, the environment and space and scientific cooperation. Washington, June 18-25, 1973 Brezhnev and Nixon sign a pledge to seek agreement to end the nuclear arms race in 1974 and a pledge to cooperate in avoiding confrontations. Moscow, June 27-July 3, 1974 Nixon and Brezhnev sign a number of documents on nuclear weapons, including one limiting underground nuclear explosions. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger says impeachment proceedings hamper Nixon. Vladivostok, U.S.S.R., Nov. 23-24, 1974 President Ford and Brezhnev reach tentative agreement to limit the number of strategic offensive nuclear weapons and delivery vehicles, including multiple-warhead missiles. Helsinki, Finland, July 30-Aug. 2, 1975 Ford and Brezhnev are among leaders of 35 nations meeting on European security. They report progress on strategic arms issues. Vienna, June 15-18, 1979 President Carter and Brezhnev conclude seven years of strategic arms limitation talks with the signing of the SALT II treaty. Geneva, Nov. 19-21, 1985 President Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev spend far more time in private sessions than planned but do not reach any breakthrough on major issues. Reagan calls it a ''fresh start'' in relations. Reykjavik, Iceland, Oct. 11-12, 1986 Reagan and Gorbachev hold detailed talks on eliminating nuclear weapons but disagree over the U.S. strategic defense initiative, known as Star Wars. Washington, Dec. 8-10, 1987 Reagan and Gorbachev sign a treaty to eliminate intermediate-range nuclear forces, but disagreement over Star Wars blocks progress on a strategic arms reduction treaty. Moscow, May 29-June 2, 1988 Reagan and Gorbachev exchange the ratified texts of the INF treaty, discuss strategic and conventional arms and stroll in Red Square. Reagan softens his criticism of Soviet human rights abuses; Gorbachev complains of missed opportunities. New York, Dec. 7, 1988 Reagan, Gorbachev and President-elect Bush meet on Governor's Island in New York harbor to discuss Gorbachev's announcement at the United Nations that the Soviet Union will reduce its armed forces by 500,000 men and withdraw 50,000 from Europe. Gorbachev rushes home to cope with the earthquake in Armenia. Marsaxlokk Bay, Malta, Dec. 2-3, 1989 Bush and Gorbachev meet aboard a Soviet cruise liner for dockside talks that produce no breakthroughs in superpower relations. They agree it is time to end the Cold War, and Bush pledges to take steps to ease U.S. tariffs on Soviet exports. Washington, May 30-June 3, 1990. Bush and Gorbachev seal agreements to slash long-range nuclear weapons, halt production of chemical weapons and lift trade barriers against Moscow. The two also discuss Lithuanian independence, German unity and other developments in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: White House Refocusing Its Gulf Strategy, Bracing for Lengthy War of Nerves
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, unable thus far to prod Iraq's Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait with a massive military buildup and international diplomacy, is bracing for a drawn-out and costly war of nerves. A month after President Bush ordered the biggest deployment of troops since the Vietnam War, the administration is refocusing its strategy for the long haul. In the short term, Bush's high-profile weekend meeting with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev is certain to emphasize Saddam's isolation. Administration officials say they still believe that the waiting game with Iraq can be won, but concede many questions remain about Saddam's ability to weather the economic embargo against his nation. Although a prolonged desert standoff always was deemed possible, administration officials say that until now most attention was focused on short-range goals _ and not the consequences of a $1-billion a month indefinite U.S. military presence in the Persian Gulf region. With the memory of last winter's successful Panama blitz still fresh, detailed long-term planning had been only sketchy, said officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity. Still, ``no one was under the impression that it was a quick-fix situation,'' said one official here with the president. ``Everyone knew it could take weeks _ or months.'' With the president himself now voicing open pessimism about prospects for a diplomatic solution, the administration is improvising a long-range policy. For the first time, the administration is considering proposing to Congress a delay of Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction targets because of the cost of the Persian Gulf operation, according to sources. The targets, pointing the way to a balanced budget by fiscal year 1993, could not have been met anyway. They call for reducing the federal deficit to $64 billion in the fiscal year that begins in just a month _ a herculean task that would have called for some $100 billion in spending cuts and-or tax increases even before the Persian Gulf operation. Congress returns from its summer recess this week, and Bush returns from his 25-day working Maine vacation. As budget talks resume, and Congress begins to take a look at the crisis, the long-range costs and consequences of the U.S. military buildup will take center stage. The issue of how long American troops can remain in Saudi Arabia is surely one that will be in the forefront. How long a U.S. presence can be maintained without draining the Treasury and losing American support is an open question. ``Americans are an impatient crowd,'' said Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., House minority whip. The U.S. military presence in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf ``will go on as long as it takes to have these United Nations sanctions fully implemented,'' Bush said. One senior administration official said that it is now clear that ``Saddam Hussein is feeling the impact of the embargo.'' The official said the Iraqi leader is desperately contacting other nations seeking to barter oil for commodities. Building on lessons learned in Panama, the administration acted decisively and quickly in sending forces to the Middle East and in rallying international condemnation of Iraq in the days after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq. But there is little in common between the Panama invasion and the Middle East buildup. The operation all but assured that Iraq would not invade Saudi Arabia, but thus far has done little toward dislodging Saddam from Kuwait. And the Iraqi leader raised the ante by refusing to allow thousands of foreigners, including about 3,000 Americans, to leave the country. The administration never really plotted a long range strategy for dealing with Saddam, officials conceded. There couldn't be a worse time for a drawn-out military expenditure, with a budget crisis brewing even before the crisis flared. Prospects of an administration shift of thinking on Gramm-Rudman targets was alluded to by White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``These are all matters to be considered by the negotiators when they meet (this week),'' he said. ``We will have a proposal to put on the table. We trust the Democrats will. And discussion of Gramm-Rudman targets would all be a part of those deliberations.'' The president himself has been vague on long-range strategy. ``It's difficult at this juncture to know fully what the impact will be. Clearly, it will have some budget implication,'' Bush said in his Thursday news conference. The United States is prepared to wage a long economic war of attrition against Iraq _ mindful that this strategy may impart a human toll on Iraqis. ``There's nothing that's painless,'' Bush asserted. By the same token, Iraqis are used to long periods of deprivation, having just emerged from an eight-year war with Iran. At the same time, administration officials say Saddam's invasion has changed some of the dynamics of the Middle East for good _ and the dynamics will be permanently altered even if Saddam is not toppled. ``I'd like to think that out of this dreary performance by Saddam Hussein there could be now an opportunity for peace all through the Middle East,'' Bush said. The only goal the United States has enunciated so far _ whether long range or short range _ is the complete withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait, restoration of the former leadership and freedom of movement for foreigners now stuck in either country. And, while the administration is now down playing the prospects of a diplomatic initiative, ``perhaps one will hit pay dirt,'' says Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders City To Allow Anti-Logging Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ordered a northern California city to let anti-logging groups hold a Labor Day march and rally at a lumber mill. U.S. District Judge Stanley Weigel issued a temporary restraining order after the city of Fortuna in Humboldt County took no action on the groups' request for a permit to hold activities outside Pacific Lumber Co. Weigel said if the demonstrators' lawsuit proceeded, they were likely to show that the denial of a permit violated freedom of expression. The march follows a summer of protests by activists against increased cutting of so-called ``old-growth'' trees _ trees from long-established stands _in Humboldt and Mendocino counties. Between 750 and 1,000 people plan to march through Fortuna to the lumber mill and lay wreaths to lament the ``death of the forest.'' Fortuna is about 260 miles north of San Francisco. Just two weeks before the scheduled march, Fortuna passed an ordinance increasing from 14 to 20 days the application time required for parade permits. Weigel said the change was suspiciously timed and appeared to be aimed at blocking the march, an assertion denied by a lawyer for the city. The judge urged the American Civil Liberties Union, which represented the demonstrators, and the city to reach an agreement that would allow the march. When that did not happen by midday Friday, he signed an order prohibiting the city from blocking a march of up to two hours.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush-Gorbachev to Meet on Middle-East Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, a0542, a0548, a0551, a0552; editing throughout
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that he and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet next Sunday in Helsinki, Finland, to discuss the Middle East crisis and other international issues. ``We have many matters to discuss,'' Bush told reporters. A simultaneous announcement of the one-day summit was made on the Soviet television show Vremya and transmitted by the state Tass news agency. It said the two leaders would discuss ``international and bilateral questions.'' In a brief session with reporters before an afternoon of golf, Bush said he was reluctant to say that the meeting was about the crisis in the Middle East, but acknowledged it would be on the agenda. He said he and Gorbachev would touch upon ``a wide array'' of issues, including the conventional forces treaty yet to be concluded to cover troop reductions in Europe. ``It will be free-flowing discussions,'' he said. Bush dampened speculation that Moscow would play a role in mediating the crisis with Iraq. ``I don't see a mediating role at all'' for Gorbachev, Bush said. ``There are a lot of mediators out there.'' Senior Jordanian officials in Amman had reported that Moscow might assume such a role. Bush said that he had not discussed the Persian Gulf crisis directly with Gorbachev by phone because he has known for some time that he would be seeing him. Bush asserted several times that it would not be a one-issue summit. ``I can't say the Middle East has nothing to do with this meeting. But it's not the whole thing,'' Bush said. The summit will be his third meeting as president with Gorbachev; Gorbachev also met five times with President Reagan. Bush said his wife Barbara would travel to Helsinki, and that Raisa Gorbachev would accompany the Soviet president. Bush said he does not see any more flexibility on the part of Iraq's Saddam Hussein than before. ``I don't want to mislead the American people'' by suggesting there is ``some breakthrough at hand,'' he said. The president accused Saddam of a ``tawdry'' and ``outrageous'' performance in posing with hostages in a series of television messages to the west. Bush said it was ``despicable'' On another subject, Bush said it was his ``gut instinct'' to recommend to Congress that it forgive some of Egypt's $7 billion military debt to the United States as a gesture of appreciation for its support in the current crisis. Just two hours before Bush's announcement, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft had refused to confirm that a summit would take place. But he told reporters that there was a lot for Bush and Gorbachev to talk about, from the Persian Gulf crisis to developments in Cambodia and Afghanistan. In the midst of the Scowcroft briefing, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater took a call from the secretary of state and then scribbled a note to the national security adviser. They whispered briefly together and then, turning back to reporters, Scowcroft said, ``Stay tuned, we'll have an announcement at 1 o'clock.'' Laughing, he added, ``I knew I shouldn't have done this'' briefing. Asked about the timing of the announcement, Scowcroft said there were certain issues of ``diplomatic niceties'' and ``an agreement on when these things are announced.'' On other gulf-related issues, Scowcroft said: _Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and a handful of diplomatic personnel would remain in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait as long as possible to assist the 2,500 Americans there. ``Where would they (citizens) turn? They are there to try to help Americans,'' he said. _Saddam is playing a game with hostages in which ``the ground rules change daily and sometimes hourly. We demand that he release all innocent civilians detained against their will.'' _U.N. Secretary-General Perez de Cuellar would remain in Iraq until Sunday. ``What he went there for was to impress upon Saddam Hussein that the world community has spoken. Unless Saddam Hussein is prepared to meet that framework, it's difficult to see how there would be successful negotiations,'' said Scowcroft, speaking of the U.N.-imposed sanctions against Iraq. _There is no difference between an ``Arab solution'' and an international solution to the crisis. But he also said ``the Arabs are and ought to be out in front on this.'' He said he did not want to single out the Arabs from ``the world community as expressed through the United Nations, which is taking a position against flagrant aggression.'' Arrangements for the Bush-Gorbachev summit were sketched out during White House Chief of Staff John Sununu's visit this week to Moscow, administration sources said. Bush and Gorbachev last held a summit May 30 to June 3 in the United States. They had met previously on the Mediterranean island of Malta in December 1989. At a Moscow news conference Friday night, Gorbachev did not mention the possibility of a meeting with Bush. But he said he is in ``constant contact'' with many world leaders, including Bush. Bush is spending the long holiday weekend with his wife Barbara and assorted children and grandchildren at their seaside vacation home on Walker's Point. The tension level among Bush and his aides appears to have eased, as administration officials said the situation in the Persian Gulf was ``settling'' a bit following the crisis mode that was sparked by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Bush appeared relaxed and jovial when he hosted a picnic Friday for the press corps covering his trip. Earlier in the day, he was on the telephone talking to King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Great Britain and French President Francois Mitterrand. Fitzwater said the president outlined his plans to raise money from wealthy nations to support the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf and to provide economic aid for poor countries suffering as a result of the trade embargo against Iraq. The foreign leaders, each of whom has had repeated contact with Bush since the Gulf crisis began, agreed ``to stay in close communication'' on the matter, Fitzwater said. Officials with Bush in Kennebunkport also said Friday that there was some pressure building from allies and members of Congress to move militarily against Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein. The sources spoke on condition of anonymity, and did not further identify those supporting a military move. The officials said the pressure by no means constituted a consensus. They indicated that mainstream opinion within the administration and the Congress and among U.S. allies was to stay with the current policy of using economic sanctions to force Saddam to roll back. Bush returns to Washington on Monday evening.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Criticizes Gorbachev On Economic Plans
LaserPhoto MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin, populist president of the Russian republic, sharply criticized Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev Saturday over plans to free the sinking economy of government control and let the market rule. He rejected Gorbachev's call of a day earlier for the merger of two vastly different blueprints for economic reform. Yeltsin told a news conference at the Russian federation headquarters: ``We won't go along with merging the two programs. That's completely unrealistic. That would be a brake not only on economic reform but also on the entire renewal of society and the political life of our country. ``The president is showing indecisiveness in this regard,'' he said. One plan, prepared by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, calls for the government to retain control over prices initially and for long-term denationalization of industries and property. The other, drafted by a governmental advisory board, outlines more rapid lifting of price controls and a quick switch to private control of most industries and private individual property. Yeltsin said the plan by Stanislav Shatalin, a member of Gorbachev's Presidential Council advisory group, should be presented to the legislatures of the nation and the 15 republics. The clash was the latest in a rocky, three-year relationship during which Gorbachev kicked Yeltsin out of the Soviet leadership for blasting reform plans as too timid, and Yeltsin staged a political comeback based on widespread popular support. A new poll, taken in July by the national Center for Socio-Political Studies, indicated that Yeltsin's popularity rose from 29.0 percent to 47.1 percent since last year and Gorbachev's fell from 36.2 percent to 18.4 percent. Ryzhkov's rating fell from 20.6 percent to 3.1 percent. A report on the poll by the independent news agency Interfax gave no margin of error, nor did it say how the survey was conducted. The latest dispute was a setback to the efforts of a 12-member committee of leading economists assembled jointly by Gorbachev and Yeltsin in July to develop a common policy on economic reform. Gorbachev told a news conference Friday night that the two plans must be merged into a ``document that reflects general agreement.'' Yeltsin believes the plans are so fundamentally different they cannot be combined. He said Shatalin's plan would be presented to the Russian Supreme Soviet at the session opening Monday. It closely follows a plan endorsed by Yeltsin earlier. The national Supreme Soviet convenes Sept. 10. ``People are tired of waiting,'' Yeltsin said, seated amid a sea of microphones in front of the blue-and-red Russian republic flag. ``People are at the limit of . . . patience. Therefore, they expressed such very sharp dissatisfaction with the actions of the union government, which for five years did practically nothing in economic reform.'' He said he got a sense of public reaction during a just-completed 22-day tour of 27 cities in the Russian republic. If the Russian federation goes its own way on economic reform, it would immensely complicate Gorbachev's efforts to unify a country already fractured by ethnic conflicts. Yeltsin's government already has moved to seize control of banking in Russia from Soviet authorities, and he said it could start implementing an overall economic reform program on Oct. 1. Yeltsin believes Ryzhkov's plan would maintain the central government's command system, which he blames for aggravating the country's economic problems. ``If implemented, it would lead to a collapse,'' he said. He said any plan adopted is doomed to fail unless Ryzhkov and the ministers under him resign. Gorbachev himself is at risk, Yeltsin said. ``Every day the union government takes away from confirming this plan, it diminishes Gorbachev's term,'' He said. After government advisory bodies met for two days to discuss economic reform, Gorbachev said Friday that the government will try to stabilize the faltering economy within six months by cutting off Soviets' ability to accumulate ``hot money.'' That is the term for income derived from black marketeering and other activities. Ryzhkov's initial program, presented in May and rejected by the national legislature a month later, called for drastic price increases on bread and other items whose prices have remained basically unchanged for decades. The program fueled panic buying that left ill-stocked store shelves even barer.

DOC.HEAD: Helsinki Meeting Will Be Gorbachev's 8th With US President
With AM-Gulf Summit Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American presidents have huddled with Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev from the chilly shores of Iceland to the storm-tossed seas off Malta. Next week's one-day summit will be No. 8. Bush met with Gorbachev this year on May 30-June 3 in Washington and aboard a cruise vessel in Malta Bay on Dec. 2-3, 1989. President-elect Bush and President Ronald Reagan met with the Soviet leader in New York on Dec. 7, 1988. DOC.HEAD: U.S. Troops Moving into Positions Farther North

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After three weeks of staying well south of Saudi Arabia's northern border with Iraq, U.S. troops are moving north to bolster defensive lines and vastly improve their offensive capabilities. The movements of several U.S. units last week were described as a logical extension of the American military buildup as more and more U.S. firepower flows into the region. U.S. officials said the movements were noteworthy because they signaled that U.S. commanders are comfortable putting troops a good distance from major supply points. ``If nothing else, it shows we believe we are now capable of sustaining a significant force in forward positions,'' said a senior Air Force officer in Dhahran. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Marine Maj. Gen. John Hopkins said Saturday the Marine force in Saudi Arabia _ now about 15,000 strong _ would be tripled within two weeks. ``We are right where we should be. If the flow continues, we'll be at full combat power in two weeks,'' Hopkins told a visiting delegation of U.S. senators. U.S. officials say more than 100,000 troops, including those aboard dozens of ships, are in the Persian Gulf region or on the way. Until last week, the United States would have been almost entirely dependent on air firepower to counter an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia. Most ground forces were in positions about 200 miles from the Saudi-Kuwait border. ``We needed to have the troops down at the ports and air base, to provide security for the ships and transports (planes) as they arrived in country,'' a top aide to a senior U.S. military official said, also on condition of anonymity. As the airlift brought more and more troops and supplies to the kingdom, U.S military planners began shifting the deployment to the north, with most units setting up initial staging camps about 100 to 150 miles from the border. But last week, Marine and at least two Army units moved even farther north, in the case of the Marines to within 35 miles of the Kuwait border. The Marines, members of the 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigade, have taken up positions behind the Saudi forces closest to the border. From those positions they could defend the north-south highway that Iraqi tanks could use to reach the richest of Saudi Arabia's oil fields. A bit farther south, the mechanized 24th Infantry Division began to establish a forward base for its heavy ground forces, which include M-1 tanks and Bradley armored infantry carriers. The M-1s' arrival last week gave American commanders their first shipment of the United States' heaviest ground power. ``They give us a cushion, make it more comfortable for us to move up because we know the troops have heavy support,'' an Army officer said. To the west of those positions, the 101st Airborne Division's air assault brigade has established its first forward refueling and rearming base, according to brigade officers. Several other potential sites for refueling and rearming camps have been identified, and more forward camps likely will be established in the next few weeks, the officers said. Additional heavy and light Army infantry are arriving in Saudi Arabia or are due to arrive within days. Even more heavy equipment is in the early stages of its sealift, which takes two to four weeks. Still more is waiting in the United States to be shipped here. Although the forces moving north have offensive capabilities, U.S. commanders here said it is unlikely the United States would use Saudi-based forces to initiate combat, if a decision to attack was made. But if hostilities did erupt, regardless of which side initiated them, U.S. forces now are in positions from which they could engage Iraqi ground forces far more quickly than they could have a week ago, they said. ``We're not looking to start anything, but we are looking to be ready when it starts,'' the senior military aide said.

DOC.HEAD: Volunteering to Be a High School Graduation Requirement
DOC.TEXT: Volunteering soon will become a high school graduation requirement for students in the North Kansas City School District. In a pilot program announced last week, the 16,000-student district will require students to complete 36 hours of community service outside the classroom as part of a new social studies class, ``the American citizen.'' ``It's time to put the `me' generation behind us,'' Superintendent Gene Denisar said Tuesday at a convocation for the district's 2,000 teachers and administrators. He declared the North Kansas City district's 1990-91 school year, which begins Tuesday, as the Year of Service. The ``American citizen'' class will first be offered next semester as an elective in a high school to be chosen later. Starting in fall 1992 it will become a required course. Denisar said that as far as he knew, no other school district in the state has such a graduation requirement. Denisar also hopes the course may spur community support. The district has been trying since last spring to pass a capital improvements package to improve and expand district facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Judicial Report: Police Killed Blacks Without Reason
DOC.TEXT: An official commission issued a stinging report Saturday saying police fired without reason on a protest march, killing five blacks and wounding 156. The report recommended a criminal investigation. The report into police conduct at the Sebokeng township March 26 was one of the harshest criticisms of police conduct ever made by an official inquiry. It said the marchers never threatened the police, and officers fired without orders. The attorney general should investigate policemen who fired bullets for possible criminal action, said the report, which was authored by Justice R.J. Goldstone. It gave no indication what charges might be filed if action is taken. Police ``displayed an attitude of unconcern for the lethal nature of their ammunition . . . This is an attitude which no police force should tolerate,'' the report said. It was released at a time when police are under attack from the African National Congress, church groups and others for alleged bias and improper conduct in black factional fighting around Johannesburg. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok, who supervises police, said Saturday that the case would be turned over to the attorney general for investigation. He also said there may be a police investigation. The ANC said at least 12 people were killed in the shootings at the Sebokeng township south of Johannesburg. The march was to protest local housing conditions, rents and other grievances. The report said one officer fired and others joined in when a mostly peaceful crowd tried to march to a police station. ``At most, the behavior of the crowd may have justified the use of tear gas, and then only after a proper warning to disperse,'' the report said. ``There appears to be no credible evidence to suggest that the behavior of the crowd was such that the policemen could have reasonably been in fear of their lives or personal safety. ``There was a complete lack of discipline in the police line. This was the direct cause of the shooting into the crowd.'' A white civilian carrying a pistol joined the police unit and took part in the incident, the report said. But it said no evidence emerged of criminal action on the part of Capt. Du Plooy, the police commander on the scene, who was sitting in a vehicle at the time. Such a finding would make it hard to prosecute other officers involved. President F.W. de Klerk ordered the inquiry following public outrage over the shootings. In another development, Peter Mokaba, leader of the South African Youth Congress, charged Saturday that the government instigated black factional fighting. He called for disbanding the white-led police and army and denounced de Klerk despite his efforts to end apartheid. South Africa can have peace only when the white-led government is removed, he said at a funeral in Tokoza township near Johannesburg for four people killed in black factional battles. Police fired tear gas at protesters who tried to march through Tokoza after the funeral, and protesters hurled rocks. No injuries were reported. Government and police have rejected ANC charges of police bias during fighting last month in Johannesburg between Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC, and Zulus tied to the conservative Inkatha movement. At least 518 people have been killed in the fighting, which began Aug. 12.

DOC.HEAD: Edwin O. Reischauer, Former U.S. Ambassador to Japan, Dead at 79
DOC.TEXT: Edwin Oldfather Reischauer, who served as U.S. ambassador to Japan during the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, died Saturday from hepatitis. He was 79. Reischauer died at Green Hospital of Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation, the clinic said. Ambssador to Japan from 1961 to 1966, Reischauer wrote several books on America's relationship with Japan and Asia. Among his books are ``The Japanese Today: Change and Continuity,'' and ``Japan: The Story of a Nation.'' Reischauer was born in Tokyo to missionary parents on Oct. 15, 1910. He graduated from Oberlin College in 1931. He received a doctorate from Harvard University after studying at universities in France, Japan and China. Reischauer first joined the Harvard staff as an instructor in 1938. He returned after World War II as an associate professor, later a professor of Far Eastern languages. He retired in 1981. He also was a director of the Harvard-Yenching Institute from 1956 to 1961. During World War II, Reischauer served in the Far Eastern Affairs office in the State Department and the War Department, specializing in Japanese language training and intelligence. As ambassador, Reischauer established contacts with opposition leaders, intellectuals, the media and students. He urged America to abandon its ``occupation mentality'' toward Japan as the nation began its emergence as an industrial power. His books included ``East Asia: The Modern Transformation,'' 1965; ``Beyond Vietnam, the United States and Asia,'' 1967; ``The Japanese,'' 1977; and ``My Life between Japan and America,'' 1986. For his work to promote better understanding between cultures, Reischauer was conferred Japan's First Class Order of the Rising Sun in 1968. Reischauer was a resident of Belmont, Mass., and La Jolla. He is survived by his wife, Haru, who is related to Japanese royalty; a son, Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office; and daughters Ann Heinemann and Joan Simon.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Bush Announcement of Gorbachev Meeting, News Briefing
With AM-Gulf Summit Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a transcript of President Bush's announcement Saturday of a one-day meeting next week with Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and of the question-and-answer session that followed. BUSH: We'll have a brief announcement that I'd like to make, and that is that President Gorbachev and I will meet on Sunday, Sept. 9 in Helsinki to discuss international and bilateral matters. I spoke with President Koivisto of Finland this morning, and I believe the Soviets made a similar approach to President Koivisto, to secure the final arrangements. Secretary (of State James A. ) Baker and Foreign Minister (Eduard A.) Shevardnadze have been working out the details of this meeting over the last few days, and we got word this morning that an announcement at this time would be agreeable to the Soviets. So, I wanted to get that out, and I'm looking forward very much to seeing Mr. Gorbachev again. We have many matters to discuss. There is no special agenda relating to the Middle East. Nobody's doing any negotiating or anything of that nature. When President Gorbachev was here, he and I agreed that it would be useful to have periodic meetings without casting them in the vein of a summit, and that's exactly what this meeting is about. And I will be delighted to see him again, and we have many subjects to discuss. Q. Mr. President, this is a little bit sudden. Can you tell us what you hope to _ I mean, it seems sudden on such short notice. What do you hope to accomplish? And also, was this your initiative or his? BUSH: It's not overly sudden. We just haven't been discussing it. And it's _ I believe in this case I made the suggestion that we have this meeting, at this time and at this place.

DOC.TEXT: Miss America 1990 Debbye Turner says giving up her crown this week will be bittersweet, but she conceded she's looking forward to lounging around with no make up on. But after a week of relaxing, it will be back to the books to finish her degree in veterinary medicine. Miss Turner, a 24-year-old who competed as Miss Missouri after losing in years past in her home state of Arkansas, said she has enjoyed the last 12 months. She says Saturday, her last night as Miss America, will be a sad one. ``It is a bittersweet experience. This has been a good year and you always hate to see it end,'' Miss Turner said. ``I'm sure I'll be a little weepy about it.'' Among the highlights were meeting President Bush, Bill Cosby, Oprah Winfrey and jazz great Lionel Hampton. ``I am looking forward to a week to go somewhere and do nothing but lay out with no makeup,'' she said. ``I get tired. I'm on the road seven days a week. Living out of a suitcase has its challenges.'' She said that after taking a week off she will resume her studies at the University of Missouri-Columbia Veterinary School, where she is six months short of her doctor of veterinary medicine degree. Miss Turner said she remains surprised by how much attention she received as Miss America. Among the stranger incidents drawing attention were the loss of her luggage in Moscow, Idaho, and a call she placed to another Turner staying at a New York hotel who was receiving her messages.

DOC.TEXT: American cyclist Greg LeMond kept race officials in suspense Saturday by not checking in for Sunday's finale of the World Cycling Championships. LeMond, the first American to win the Tour de France, was nowhere to be seen Saturday. His absence sparked rumors that he was planning to fly in by helicopter at the last moment in order to lessen the effects of jet lag and media attention. Whatever the reason, organizers said, LeMond would be at the starting line to defend his title in the individual men's professional road race. If LeMond succeeds, he will be the first rider to win both the Tour de France and the world championship two years running. LeMond, who rides for the French professional team ``Z,'' has won the Tour de France three times _ 1986, 1989 and 1990. He also won world championships in 1983 and 1989. In last month's Zurich Classic, however, he was edged out by Frenchman Charles Mottet. Unlike the Tour de France, a grueling, 2,112-mile race spread out in stages over three weeks, Sunday's 162-mile championship will be held on a nine-mile circuit.

A harmonica player who has been jailed in the past for impersonating Grateful Dead guitarist Bob Weir allegedly has been at it again, police say. Oakland police are looking for Randall Delpiano to arrest him on a warrant accusing him of stealing and violating his parole after serving 15 months on fraud and theft charges, Sgt. Stan Bricker said Friday. Bricker questioned Delpiano two years ago after he was charged with bilking a woman out of $4,000. He was accused of gaining her confidence by impersonating Weir. He was paroled in April. Bricker said Delpiano told him ``he gets some satisfaction'' out of pretending to be Weir. Delpiano resembles Weir, who doesn't play harmonica. ``People like him when they think he's Bob Weir,'' Bricker said. Grateful Dead publicist Dennis McNally called Delpiano ``a professional con man who has got an emotional problem.'' ``Bobby obviously objects to him doing so,'' McNally said. ``I really hope he runs into sharper Deadheads who recognize him,'' referring to the nomadic group of fans who sometimes follow the band around the country. Bricker identified Delpiano as the man who allegedly has been impersonating Weir in the community of Discovery Bay in Contra Costa County.

Robert Indiana, an artist known for his block-letter representations of the word ``LOVE,'' was arrested on a charge of hiring a male prostitute, police said Saturday. Deputies also seized nine drawings of naked young men from Indiana's home on Vinalhaven, an island 16 miles off Maine's coast that is known as an artists' retreat, officials said. ``We did not seize anything claiming it was pornographic,'' District Attorney William Anderson said. ``The only reason we seized it was for evidence.'' The prosecutor declined to comment when asked whether two young Vinalhaven men who told investigators that Indiana paid them for sex would face charges. The two men, one 21 and the other 19, told police they were posing for Indiana when the sex acts allegedly occurred. The men claimed they were paid to have sex with Indiana. Indiana was released on $300 bail after being arrested on the misdemeanor charge. There is no phone listing for Indiana and attempts to reach him for comment were unsuccessful. Indiana, 61, was born Robert E. Clark but adopted the name of his home state. His colorful representation of the word ``LOVE'' in a square with the ``L-O'' on top of the ``V-E,'' the ``O'' tilted on its side made him famous in the 1960s. Indiana is to be arraigned Oct. 3 in Maine District Court. Anderson said the maximum penalty for the misdemenaor charge is $1,000 fine and 364 days in jail.

I mean, we've just set these meetings up, and the way I described it from our side to him was that we'd like _ that we'd have no agenda, and that it would be free-flowing discussions. DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief, Iraqi Minister Close to Accord on Peace Plan, Sources Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with talks ending, new quotes, Bush and Gorbachev to meet. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. secretary-general and Iraq's foreign minister appeared close to agreement Saturday on a plan to prevent a clash between Iraqi and U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf, Jordanian sources said. Although Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz expressed only general optimism after ending two days of talks, senior Jordanian officials described substantial progress. If approved by the governments involved, the plan could free all foreigners held in Iraq; deploy an Arab peacekeeping force as a buffer between U.S. and Iraqi troops along the Saudi border; and eventually resolve the status of Kuwait, the officials said. The Soviet Union might help mediate simultaneous withdrawals of Iraqi troops from Kuwait and opposing forces in Saudi Arabia, they said. Before leaving for the airport Saturday night, Aziz said: ``As far as I see it, the talks were very fruitful.'' But he added: ``This situation is complicated and dramatic (and) cannot be resolved by dramatic diplomacy. It needs patience. It needs time and people to understand exactly the positions.'' Perez de Cuellar scheduled a news conference for Sunday. Also Saturday, the White House announced that President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet in Helsinki, Finland, on Sept. 9. Jordanian officials close to the talks here said the U.N. chief and the Iraqi minister worked on how to immediately lessen tensions in the region. One official, who like the others spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity, said Perez de Cuellar delivered ``a peaceful message'' from Bush to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Aziz said of his talks with Perez de Cuellar: ``I listened to him very carefully and told him about our situation and the ways and means to reach the common goals we share . . . which are peace and stability in the region.'' Bush demands that Iraq leave Kuwait and restore the deposed royal government. Saddam wants to link his withdrawal from Kuwait with an Israeli pullout from the occupied territories and a Syrian pullout from Lebanon. Perez de Cuellar's talks with Aziz lasted far longer than originally scheduled. They took place as Jordan's King Hussein was in Germany on the eighth stop of a 10-nation tour to seek peace. Both Perez de Cuellar and Aziz met with Prince Hassan, Hussein's brother and regent, to discuss Jordan's initiatives for an Arab buffer force and a negotiated solution principally among Arabs, a palace official said. Perez de Cuellar and Aziz met privately, then with aides on Friday, and decided to meet again Saturday. At a news briefing Friday night, the secretary-general described Saddam's promise to release foreign women and children as ``an important step forward.'' But he added, ``From my point of view this is not enough.'' Aziz said all foreigners could leave, men included, if the United Nations could produce guarantees that the United States would not attack. Iraq's ambassador to the United States made a similar offer last week, but Washington said it rejected any conditions for releasing hostages. Iraq has detained about 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans, since overrunning Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: KENNEBUNKPORT, Maine: that changed?
DOC.TEXT: BUSH: Well, I haven't seen any flexibility on the key point, which is the operating within the United Nations mandate. I've listened carefully and follow up as carefully as we can on various conversations that Saddam Hussein has, and what the world community has said is to get out of Iraq, and to ... out of Kuwait, and to restore the rulers. And now you see the Arab League acting and calling for reparations, but on _ for Saddam Hussein to make good on reparations _ but I don't see any willingness on his part to undertake what the world community is looking for. So I'd like to be optimistic, and I think it's fine to have these talks going on. I encouraged Javier Perez de Cuellar, and told him I wished him great success, but I don't want to mislead the American people by saying that I think there's some breakthrough at hand or some flexibility that is clearly going to be required on his part to live within the mandate of the United Nations. Q. Sir, what do you make about _ of the piecemeal approach that Saddam has been taking releasing a few women and children. BUSH: I don't like that. Yeah. I don't like it. I don't like it. I don't think the world likes it. I'm glad when any American comes out of there, but there's a certain brutality, a certain tawdry performance in all of this. Q. What do you think his motive is in handling it that way? BUSH: Well, I can't anticipate his motive, but it is just turning off world opinion. It is so base and so outrageous that I think most people in the Arab world are very embarrassed by this, and I think that's certainly true of others around the world. I've talked to so many leaders, and they all agree that this is _ this is just a despicable performance. Q. How long can you let it go on, sir? BUSH: Well, I don't _ I've not wanted a deadline. I don't ... deadlines. I've got to ... Q. Mr. President, can you tell us when you first broached this idea of a meeting with Mr. Gorbachev? BUSH: Over a week ago, maybe, or something like that.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Seeks Summit to Allay Concerns About U.S. Buildup in Gulf
With AM-Gulf-Rdp, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's desire for a U.S.-Soviet summit next Sunday stems from concern about the buildup of U.S. troops near his borders and his desire to bolster his country's flagging superpower status. Gorbachev says he is campaigning for a diplomatic rather than a military solution against Iraq not because his country has become weaker, but because it conforms to his ``new thinking'' _ the approach that underlay arms agreements he has signed with the United States. ``Some people think we lose our prestige and reputation'' by advocating peaceful means to force an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, he told a news conference on Friday. ``It is not so. I think that everything will depend on whether we are successful in using political measures,'' he said. By pushing for a peaceful solution, said Angela Stent of Georgetown University, Gorbachev is calculating that the Soviets ``will emerge from this with a stronger international position, even in the Middle East,'' where the Kremlin has lost ground to the United States over the last decade. It remains unclear what led to the decision to hold a summit at a time when the Soviets seem to be sitting on the superpower sidelines. The announcement came after a visit to Moscow last week by White House chief of staff John Sununu. Ostensibly, he was in town as part of a long-scheduled program to impart U.S. management skills to the Soviet executive branch. Soviet cooperation with Washington in the current crisis has reduced the dangers for the Bush administration, vastly diminishing the threat of a global war resulting from any conflict involving the U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. Overall, however, Gorbachev seems poised to gain more than Bush from the summit. He is swamped with political trouble at home, and he has come under public pressure from his military for guarantees that U.S. troops will be withdrawn from the gulf once the crisis has passed. The Soviet commander of the Warsaw Pact, Gen. Vladimir N. Lobov, was quoted last Thursday by the state news agency Tass as warning that the presence of so many U.S. troops in Saudia Arabia, less than 700 miles from the Soviet border, could alter the strategic balance. He said the buildup could derail talks in Vienna aimed at reducing troops stationed in Europe by the Warsaw Pact and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Deputy Foreign Minister Alexander Belonogov told a parliamentary committee that because of the military buildup, ``the situation is becoming more and more explosive. And there are no guarantees that the United States will leave Saudi Arabia after the crisis is settled.'' Gorbachev responded Friday that ``I don't think that the U.S. leadership, after political solutions to this conflict have been found, will preserve'' its force in Saudi Arabia. ``I believe that when a solution has been found, we will be able to provide guarantees,'' he said. ``And I believe that the sooner we have a military detente after that, the more calm we all will feel.'' Gorbachev and his generals clearly would feel better if Bush stated such guarantees publicly in Helsinki, where the Sept. 9 summit will take place. The benefit may be greater for Gorbachev in the short term than in the long term, as the Soviets become increasingly preoccupied with their crumbling economy and ethnic unrest that is altering the shape of the nation. The world has changed greatly since the Middle East War of 1973, when the White House ordered a nuclear alert, opening U.S. missile silos to demonstrate support for Israel against Arab nations, including Iraq, which were armed and backed by the Kremlin. Since then, the Soviets have lost their empire in Eastern Europe, signed arms control pacts with the United States, mended fences with China and taken steps to open diplomatic relations with Israel. ``They are in retreat,'' said Adam Ulam of Harvard University. ``If we had had this crisis four or five years ago, the Soviets would have been prudent, but they would have been issuing grave warnings to the United States.'' Although the Soviets are siding with the United States, their support has been lukewarm. The Kremlin has backed a U.N. Security Council resolution that Iraq withdraw its invasion forces from Kuwait, stopped its own substantial arms shipments to the government of Saddam Hussein, and said it expects to lose $880 million in trade for its actions. But so far, the Soviets have balked at joining the American naval blockade against Iraq. And although the Kremlin halted its arms shipments to Iraq, it has not withdrawn 193 Soviet military specialists and 5,000 construction workers stationed there. It also pulled its diplomats out of Kuwait rather than keeping there in defiance of Saddam Hussein's order to leave.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Bryan Brumley has covered Soviet affairs for The Associated Press since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Say Trial of Paratrooper Could Cause Hesitation in Combat
DOC.TEXT: Although he was acquitted, the trial of an Army sergeant charged with killing a civilian during the U.S. invasion of Panama has left some soldiers with doubts about using deadly power. ``It would make me hesitate,'' Sgt. Gina Nixon said Friday after the military jury announced the verdict. ``Just look at the all the things he's gone through to prove his innocence.'' Master Sgt. Roberto Enrique Bryan, 43, a paratrooper with 19 years in the Army, was found innocent of unpremeditated murder, or voluntary manslaughter, in the death of a wounded, unarmed Panamanian. Ted Sampley, publisher of U.S. Veteran News and Report, said the court-martial has caused ``irreparable damage to the morale of combat soldiers. Combat soldiers must not hesitate in the face of the enemy.'' The publication set up a defense fund for Bryan. ``The message is one of confusion,'' Sampley said. ``What is a combat soldier's exact role now? Should he be a police officer and worry about human rights. Or is he a soldier conditioned to inflict deadly casualties on the enemy?'' In the Dec. 23, 1989, episode, Bryan's unit stopped a carload of five Panamanians at a roadblock. A grenade was tossed and the soldiers opened fire, killing four of the men; 10 American soldiers were injured by the grenade. The fifth Panamanian man was injured. Bryan shot and killed him a short time later under circumstances that were at issue in the trial. The prosecution's case rested on the testimony of 1st Lt. Brandon Thomas, who said Bryan shot the man without provocation to avenge the soldiers injured in the grenade explosion. A prosecutor, Capt. Charlie Luckey, called it ``a battlefield summary execution.'' Witnesses supported Bryan's contention that the man made threatening moves and testified that Thomas did not see the shooting. Luckey said the defense witnesses who testified they saw the Panamanian make a threatening motion ``all missed something.'' ``We're all soldiers and we all know we kill the enemy (but) we're all soldiers and we all know when the enemy is shot up and wounded and no longer a threat, we all know he's no longer a combatant,'' Lucky told jurors. Bryan's unit, along with most of the 82nd Airborne Division from the base, has been deployed to Saudi Arabia. The soldiers still on post Friday said they would have reacted as Bryan did. ``Probably under the same circumstances, I would have done the same thing,'' said Master Sgt. Don Gouldsmith. Bryan proved by his actions that he was ``willing to put his soldiers' welfare first, regardless of what the outcome was. You don't find that everyday. It's indicative of a good leader,'' Gouldsmith said. Sgt. David McLean said he could only hope that the court-martial didn't cause soldiers in a combat situation to hesitate. `Stop and think (about shooting), and you might not be around,'' he said. At least three other U.S. soldiers have been prosecuted for their actions during the Panama invasion. One was convicted of unpremeditated murder and two others were found guilty of lesser charges.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Visit Troops, Support Saudi Arms Sales
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A delegation of U.S. senators on Saturday brought mail and words of support to U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, and two said the Middle East crisis had changed their views on sales of U.S. arms to the Saudis. The 14-member delegation received a 30-minute briefing from the commander of American forces in the Middle East, Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, before heading to a number of American base camps in northeast Saudi Arabia. ``We're going to get rid of Saddam Hussein, and then we'll bring you guys home,'' Carl Levin, D-Mich., told one group of soldiers. Senator David Durenberger, R-Minn., said that the longer the standoff dragged on the greater the risk for the Iraqi president. Senator Alan Cranston, D-Calif., said Schwarzkopf told the senators the U.S. mission remained a defensive one and that no attack on Bagdhad is planned for now. Cranston, a strong supporter of Israel who has opposed past sales of high-tech U.S. arms to the Saudis, said the current crisis had convinced him ``we should make available what they need.'' ``I was the leader of the opposition, but not any more,'' Cranston said of military sales to the Saudis. ``Now they are allied with us, they are sitting on the front lines, they will take the first casualties.'' Another fierce defender of Israel in the Senate, New York Democrat Daniel Patrick Moynihan, said he too was convinced the Saudis now are deserving of further U.S. military equipment. Several senators said they wished more nations would join in the multinational defense force. ``I would like to see some of the Western European nations being more supportive,'' said Senator John Glenn, an Ohio Democrat. Glenn, the former astronaut, rode in the cockpit of a C-130 Hercules transport plane for one leg of the trip. The senators took notes from soldier constituents and promised to contact families back home. They also brought boxes of mail and words of support. The leader of the delegation, Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell, arrived with three boxes of mail. Aides said the boxes contained 600 pieces of mail from Pell's constituents in Rhode Island. The Saturday visit was the second by a congressional delegation _ eight senators came earlier in the week _ and a third is due Sunday. A group of U.S. congressmen visited sailors Saturday aboard the USS La Salle. If the troops were looking for word on when they might be coming home, they were disappointed. Glenn said the ``international squeeze play'' was taking its toll. ``But how long it takes, nobody knows _ anywhere from six weeks to six months and beyond.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Gorbachev to Discuss Middle East, Other Issues in Helsinki Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 13th graf to include Bush on Egyptian debt, ``He said xxx''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Saturday that he and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet next Sunday in Helsinki, Finland, for a ``free-flowing'' one-day summit on the Middle East crisis and other issues. The third summit between the two leaders was announced simultaneously here _ where the president was wrapping up a 25-day vacation _ and in Moscow. ``We have many matters to discuss,'' Bush said, adding there was ``no agenda'' for the meeting. He said he proposed the meeting and Gorbachev accepted. While Bush sought to lower expectations that the summit might help resolve the Middle East standoff, the meeting was portrayed by administration aides as symbolically important if only as a show of U.S.-Soviet solidarity against Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Moscow has been Iraq's chief arms supplier and there are currently Soviet military advisers there. Bush said he and Gorbachev ``seem to be in general agreement'' over the crisis, even though Soviet support for military action in the gulf has been lukewarm. He said he did not see the Soviets acting as a mediator in seeking to persuade Saddam to withdraw his troops from Kuwait. The president asserted several times that matters other than the Middle East would be discussed at the summit. He said that among a ``wide array of questions that could use consultation at this time'' is progress on an agreement to reduce conventional forces in Europe. Both leaders have voiced a hope that the treaty can be signed later this year at a 35-nation summit. However, administration officials have said that while the talks are on track in terms of reducing troops, there have been recent hangups on artillery and aircraft reductions. Bush said he would take his wife Barbara to Helsinki and that Raisa Gorbachev was expected to accompany the Soviet president. The trip also is expected to give Bush a chance to try out a new Air Force One, a modified version of a Boeing 747 that was delivered just last week. Bush has had two previous meetings as president with Gorbachev: last December on the Mediterranean island-nation of Malta and in late May and early June in Washington. Gorbachev also met five times with former President Reagan. Dressed in a light tweed sports coat, Bush answered reporters' questions on his way to a round of golf. The president was to return to Washington on Monday. He said it was his ``gut instinct'' to ask Congress to forgive some of Egypt's $6.7 billion military debt to the United States as a gesture of appreciation for its support in the current crisis. Asked what he hoped to accomplish at his summit with Gorbachev, Bush said: ``Being sure we're together. ... It is my view that it is just important that we have good, free-flowing discussions about this.'' The Soviet Union voted in favor of a U.N. Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force to impose sanctions on Iraq, but it has voiced reservations about the U.S.-led naval blockade. Moscow has stopped arms shipments to Iraq but nearly 200 Soviet military advisers and 5,000 construction workers remain there. Although Bush has spoken by phone with dozens of world leaders about the Middle East crisis, he has not talked directly to Gorbachev since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. He said this is because he had hoped he would be meeting the Soviet leader. Bush was to spend Saturday night in Helsinki in advance of the all-day Sunday session. Aides said that Bush did not plan to visit any other countries on the trip. Although Bush stressed several times that there was ``no agenda,'' press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said: ``They both know what they want to talk about.'' ``A lot has happened since the two of them met before, not only in the Persian Gulf,'' said national security adviser Brent Scowcroft. He mentioned Cambodia and Afghanistan as other areas that needed superpower attention. As for the Soviets acting as mediator in the crisis, Bush said, ``I don't see a mediating role at all and I don't think the Soviets see themselves as having a mediating role. There are a lot of mediators out there trying hard.'' He mentioned U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar as ``being in the forefront of this.'' Perez de Cuellar conferred Saturday with the Iraqi foreign minister in Amman, Jordan. Senior Jordanian officials said the meeting produced some progress toward reaching an agreement that could free all foreigners held in Iraqi, deploy an Arab peacekeeping force as a buffer between U.S. and Iraqi troops along the Saudi border and eventually resolve the status of Kuwait. As he had done before, Bush voiced pessimism over chances for a diplomatic breakthrough. ``I haven't seen any flexibility'' on Saddam's part, he said. Asked about Saddam Hussein's piecemeal release of some women and children, Bush said: ``I don't like it ... I'm glad when any American comes out of there, but there's a certain brutality, a certain tawdry performance in all of this.'' ``I've talked to so many leaders and they all agree that this is just a despicable performance.'' Aides said Bush suggested a meeting last week in a diplomatic cable to Gorbachev. That was followed by two phone conversations between Secretary of State James A. Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, Fitzwater said. Fitzwater said that the very fact that Bush and Gorbachev were meeting to discuss the Middle East could increase pressure on Saddam. ``Once again, it shows world unity in opposition to Saddam Hussein,'' he said. Earlier Saturday, Scowcroft had refused to confirm an Associated Press report about the upcoming summit. As Scowcroft answered questions at a briefing, Fitzwater took two urgent phone calls _ one from Bush and the second from Baker. He went to the podium, scribbled a note to Scowcroft, and whispered to him. Turning back to reporters, Scowcroft said, ``Stay tuned, we'll have an announcement at 1 o'clock.'' At his briefing, Scowcroft said: _Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and a handful of diplomatic personnel would remain in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait as long as possible to assist the 2,500 Americans there. ``Where would they (citizens) turn? They are there to try to help Americans,'' he said. _Saddam is playing a game with hostages in which ``the ground rules change daily and sometimes hourly. We demand that he release all innocent civilians detained against their will.''

DOC.HEAD: Comparison of Soviet Economic Plans
With AM-Soviet-Economy
DOC.TEXT: Here is a comparison of two Soviet economic plans, according to the newspaper Trud and the Sept. 2 edition of the weekly Moscow News. One plan was being prepared by the government of Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov, and the other from a working group headed by Stanislav Shatalin, a member of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Presidential Council advisory group.

PRICES: RYZHKOV PLAN: Prices would be raised at once _ perhaps by as much as two to three times _ by administrative decree, with a later, gradual transformation to market prices. Hardest-hit groups, such as the elderly and non-working mothers, would get compensation. SHATALIN PLAN: The market, not administrative decree, would determine prices on many goods. There would be gradual increases in wholesale prices of energy. Prices would be frozen on about 100 to 150 basic goods and services for the entire transition period. After that, the prices of 70 percent to 80 percent of the goods would be free-floating. Rationing is not ruled out and social assistance would be provided.

PRIVATIZATION OF BUSINESSES AND PROPERTY: RYZHKOV PLAN: Long-term denationalization of businesses and property; the state would control at least 50 percent of shares in most industries. SHATALIN PLAN: State control over businesses and property would end, with the private sector prevailing in most industries. Some property would be sold at low or symbolic cost to labor collectives. Leasing might be possible, as would be private family property, but the republics would determine some forms of ownership.
BUDGET, FINANCING: RYZHKOV PLAN: Reliance on taxation for income. SHATALIN PLAN: Strict control on state spending, measures for a sounder ruble, reform of the banking system.

CENTRAL CONTROL= RYZHKOV PLAN: Strongly resembles the present system in that the central government still would maintain major control, determining what its own powers should be and leaving residual powers to the republics. The central government could reduce its powers if so inclined. SHATALIN PLAN: Economic union would be on a voluntary basis. The sovereign republics together would decide what powers the central government should have.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Told Aides of Summit in Call From His Boat
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES throughout with Bush call from boat. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A red-faced national security adviser Brent Scowcroft, who usually does not preside over news briefings, should have followed his instincts Saturday. As the White House aide was on camera refusing to confirm press reports of a new U.S.-Soviet summit, presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater was on the telephone at the other end of the room, being told by President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III that the summit was on. Fitzwater hustled up to where Scowcroft was still saying he would not be able to confirm that a summit was in the offing. Scowcroft interrupted himself as Fitzwater hastily scribbled a note. ``Stay tuned,'' Scowcroft told reporters. ``We'll have an announcement at one o'clock.'' Then wryly, ``You know, I knew I shouldn't have done this.'' Reports of a possible summit between Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had been on news wires for more than 12 hours when Scowcroft opened the briefing for reporters. ``I'm not aware of any plans, but I can't rule it out,'' Scowcroft told reporters at Bush's vacation retreat here. That's when the phone in the back of the room began to ring. The first call for Fitzwater came from Bush, who was fishing on his powerboat in the Atlantic. The second was from Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Afterward, Fitzwater told reporters that both Bush and Baker had called to inform him that final details of the summit had fallen into place and that it could be announced officially later that day. ``The president asked me, `Where are you?' I said, `I'm on camera,''' Fitzwater said. ``There are certain issues of comity when you're making arrangements for these things, and an agreement on when it will be announced,'' he responded, ``and there's usually a desire to have a simultaneous announcement.'' At 1 p.m., Bush made the official announcement of a one-day meeting in Helsinki, Finland, a week from Sunday. A simultaneous announcement was made on the Soviet television show, ``Vremya,'' and transmitted by the state Tass news agency.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Fugitive Commits Suicide When FBI Knocks
DOC.TEXT: A fugitive who once faked suicide to escape trial fatally shot himself when FBI agents arrived at his apartment to arrest him, the bureau said. Agents acting on tips from television viewers of ``America's Most Wanted'' were poised Friday to arrest Richard Allen Sturdy, but he shot himself when they knocked on his door, said Richard S. Swensen, the FBI's top agent in New Orleans. Sturdy died at a hospital soon after, Swensen said. The Fox Television Network on Aug. 26 broadcast a segment about Sturdy, who was accused in a multimillion dollar fraud scheme. Several Metairie viewers called in with information about Sturdy, Swensen said. As the operator of Strawn Crossing Grain Co., a small grain elevator in Jacksonville, Ill., Sturdy allegedly recruited other elevator managers to create records for nonexistent loads of corn and soybeans, Swensen said. The fake records were used to defraud large grain processors of up to $10 million over about 20 years, he said. Sturdy was arrested and indicted in 1988 on federal charges of mail fraud, conspiracy and defrauding the Internal Revenue Service. About two weeks before his trial was to begin in January 1989, a suicide note was found in Sturdy's motel room and his wallet and jacket were found on a bridge over the Illinois River in Peoria, Ill. Authorities discounted the ``suicide'' and issued a warrant charging Sturdy with failing to appear for trial.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Faces Uncertain Future If Saddam Goes
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: America and its allies may wish to see Saddam Hussein go, but Iraqi exiles say no one is in sight to replace him and without a strongman in charge, Iraq could explode into an orgy of bloodletting. ``Saddam has managed to crush any successor and any opposition out of existence. There are no charismatic leaders waiting in the wings to take over if something happened to Saddam,'' a senior member of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan in London said in a telephone interview. For years, Saddam has moved against the opposition in Iraq and outside. The rebellious Kurds are still active, but they have been badly mauled by the Iraqi president's legions. ``You could call it the Romania of the Middle East,'' one London-based Iraqi emigre said. But no one expects a popular Romania-style uprising in Iraq, and a palace coup presents its own problems. After years of maneuvering himself to a position of power, Saddam knows how to guard his flanks. Since he invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, reports from Baghdad say Saddam has been moving constantly between underground bunkers. Reports from Stockholm a week ago said a Swedish company had built 14 installations under Baghdad, equipped with filters against nuclear radiation and poison gas, during Iraq's 1980-88 war with Iran. For years, Saddam has systematically removed anyone who opposed him or appeared to be gaining power. His inner circle is made up mostly of relatives from his home village of Takrit in northern Iraq. All became wealthy supporting him. ``They know that when Saddam goes, they go,'' said a former Iraqi army officer now living in London. ``So who's going to pull the trigger?'' Like all Iraqi political exiles interviewed by The Associated Press, he spoke on condition of anonymity, citing fear of reprisals against his family in Iraq. Estimates of how many Iraqis have fled in the past 20 years range from 500,000 to 3 million. They represent all shades of political opinion, but all keep a low profile, fearing Saddam's long reach. His wrath has been felt by dissenters and members of ``enemy'' groups _ Communists, pro-Syrian members of the ruling Ba'ath Party, Kurds and pro-Iranian Shiite Moslems. Saddam is a Sunni Moslem, the minority sect which dominates Iraqi politics. Iraqis took refuge in dozens of countries. One of the largest communities was in Kuwait before the invasion. Iraqis in Western Europe say hundreds of exiles were quickly rounded up and taken to Baghdad. What befell them is still a mystery. Like the Romanians when Nicolae Ceaucescu fell, Iraqis might see the end of Saddam as a signal to exact revenge on thousands of informers and militiamen. ``There will be a bloodbath. These people have been subjected to so much brutality, it is beyond anger,'' said an exile from a small village in northern Iraq. Exiles say a military coup would be the only way to get rid of Saddam. But Saddam has ousted senior officers who became too popular or voiced dissenting opinions, and has reportedly crushed several coup attempts. ``Even if there were a coup, it would be hard to find an Iraqi face presentable to the people and the West,'' said an Iraqi engineer living in Paris. ``Everyone's been tainted by Saddam.'' Possibilities include Nizar Hamdoun, a deputy foreign minister and former ambassador in Washington; Taha Yassin Ramadan, a member of the ruling Revolution Command Council; Izzat Ibrahim, Saddam's chief deputy, and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, the only Christian in Saddam's Cabinet. The fear is that a dictator will emerge to replace Saddam, possibly armed with nuclear weapons produced by the ambitious arms program now under way.

DOC.HEAD: Scottish Refugee: My Husband Smuggled Me Out
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A fair-skinned, redheaded Scottish woman arriving in Jordan on Saturday with thousands of Arab and Asian refugees said she was smuggled out of Kuwait by her husband, a professor at Kuwait University. Patricia Fido, a native of Edinburgh, Scotland, is the wife of professor Abdullah Fido. She stood at the Ruweishid border post Saturday, as sharply defined as a lighthouse, in fashionable European dress, surrounded by a mass of robes, sarongs and dhotis at the once-sleepy border post _ now a sprawling refugee camp. ``I was smuggled out by my husband,'' she declared. Fido had accompanied his wife and three sons, ages three to 11, on a 36-hour voyage across the desert from Kuwait, through Baghdad, to Ruweishid. He did not reveal how he got his redheaded wife out of Iraq. He also did not specify his own nationality. A senior border official said Mrs. Fido was the only Westerner among the 10,000 people, mostly Arabs and Asians, who came through the frontier Saturday. Fido acknowledged relief at finally escaping Iraq. ``We were lucky to get out, but many of our friends are suffering,'' he said. His wife, asked whether their friends in Kuwait City were in hiding, said, ``No, but they are keeping a low profile, very low-key, staying in their homes and not going out.'' The family's large green Mercedes was piled high with belongings. Hundreds of cars with white Kuwaiti plates streamed through the border post at a steady rate. Most had piles of luggage balanced on the roof, with more bundles and families of up to seven or eight people crammed inside. Thousands more people _ Egyptians, Indians, Bangladeshis, Pakistanis, Filipinos and Thais _ camped under tents made of bedsheets, amidst growing piles of litter. The stench from garbage and poor sanitary arrangements is such that many evacuees walk around with pieces of cloth tied around their faces, like surgical masks. Most are waiting for their embassies to complete arrangements for their journeys home. ``We are doing the best we can under the circumstances,'' said the border official, who spoke on condition he not be identified. He said the flow of refugees had slowed considerably since early in the week. Many of those arriving Saturday appeared to be more affluent people, with a goodly number traveling in expensive cars. Those in private vehicles were quickly cleared and continued to Amman. Many penniless families have waited up to five days for clearance to enter Jordan, only to wait again for evacuation to their homelands.

DOC.HEAD: US Report Says Jordan Being Used To Defy Iraq Sanctions
RETRANSMITTING a0589 to add writethru designation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs with Bush comments after 10th graf pvs, bgng: Administration officials. Picks up 11th graf pvs, The one-page
DOC.TEXT: Despite President Bush's assertion that the amount of goods reaching Iraq through Jordan has been reduced to a ``trickle,'' a new State Department report says there is still heavy traffic using that route in defiance of United Nations sanctions. ``Food supplies and other goods still are transiting Jordanian highways, obviously destined for Iraq,'' the report said. ``Numerous tractor-trailers and other trucks were moving east from Jordan to Iraq.'' State Department officials said the report was completed Thursday, the same day Bush told a news conference that commerce between Jordan and Iraq ``has come down to a bit of a trickle.'' At another point, Bush acknowledged that he was unable to give the precise quantity involved in the cross-border traffic.
