During their meeting two weeks ago, Bush said Jordan's King Hussein offered him assurances he would comply with the embargo. But The Washington Post in its Saturday editions said the Bush administration was sending a special envoy to tell Hussein not to expect any emergency financial aid from the international community until he cuts off the remaining cross-border traffic. At the same time, administration officials said they were considering forgiving Egypt's $6.7 billion military debt to the United States. Egypt is one of a handful of countries which has sent troops to Saudi Arabia in support of the U.S. military buildup. The New York Times said in Saturday editions that officials were considering providing Israel with F-16 and F-15 fighters, Apache anti-tank helicopters and Patriot ground-to-air missiles that could be used against attacking missiles. The package also could include M-60 tanks. Administration officials said no final decisions have been made. Bush would not comment on the possibility of forgiving Egypt's debts when asked Saturday in Kennebunkport, Maine. But he told reporters ``his gut instinct'' was to make such a recommendation to Congress. Bush said he wants to work with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak to alleviate Egypt's ``grave financial problems.'' The one-page State Department report on compliance with sanctions, made available to The Associated Press, was an update on efforts to circumvent the economic embargo that the United Nations authorized against Iraq early last month. The report said Syria has not prevented some smuggling of agricultural products into Iraq but that truck traffic via Iraq's northern neighbor, Turkey, was very limited. The report also said Iraq was continuing to shop actively on the West European market for other goods, including military and military-related equipment. There were reports Friday that Iraq has offered the Philippines an oil-for-sugar deal. Bush has staked the success of his policy on an effective global economic embargo against Iraq, contending that widespread deprivation in Iraq eventually will force Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his forces from Kuwait. An earlier State Department update on the sanctions said Libyan planes have flown a number of cargo aircraft into Baghdad, an indication that Iraq ``may increasingly rely on air transport as a means of avoiding interception of sea shipments.'' Yemen also has been cooperating with the Iraqis, unloading Iraqi oil at Aden 10 days ago in violation of the sanctions, the report said. The Washington Post said Saturday's that Iran also was being eyed by smugglers as a potential conduit for sending goods to Iraq. Iran is on record in support of the sanctions but would have difficulty policing the long border between the two countries. The Washington Times reported this past week that Cuba and North Korea are flying military-related equipment to Iraq. Still, the administration is pleased with what it regards as the widespread international compliance with the embargo. Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson called the international compliance ``unprecedented.'' Georgetown University economist Clyde Hufbauer described it as ``amazing.'' One measure of the effectiveness of the sanctions is that Iraq reportedly introduced a rationing system on Saturday. Coupon books entitle each Iraqi to a monthly allocation of 13 pounds of flour, 3.3 pounds of rice, 2.2 pounds of sugar, 3.5 ounces of tea, 1.1 pounds of oil, 17 ounces of detergent and one bar of soap, sources said. Children under one year of age receive three cans of powdered milk each month, but older children receive none. Fresh fruit and vegetables from summer crops remain plentiful, the sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Border Post is Refugees' Heartbreak Hotel
DOC.TEXT: Traffic has slowed to a trickle at the main Kuwait-Saudi Arabia border post, a new heartbreak hotel for poor refugees with no place to go. ``We have been here four days and we haven't seen a refugee,'' said Dr. Rapia Mohammed, one of the four doctors and five nurses at a tent hospital of the Red Crescent relief group. The Saudis set up the hospital following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait to care for dehydrated and sick refugees. At the seedy, fluorescent-lit waiting room at the Saudi customs post, Bangladeshi and Afghani workers who fled Kuwait sleep on the floor or outside on blankets. The Saudis give them food every day, and they pray in the mosque at the post. ``The Iraqis take all our things from us: watch, money and my shoes. My shoes are new so they take that. They are very bad people,'' said Mousafer Al-Lahgul, 33, an Afghan mason, who has been living at the border post for three days. He doesn't know how long he'll stay. In the weeks following the invasion, the border post 60 miles from Kuwait City along a paved road was frantic with activity. About 70,000 Kuwaitis alone are now in the Saudi eastern province. About 100 Americans, many married to Kuwaitis, crossed the line here to freedom. Many stayed at the Khafji Beach Hotel on the Arabian Gulf before moving on. But the Iraqis have dug up the road with bulldozers, making it impassable even to four-wheel-drive vehicles, said a U.S. State Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Now, the only escape routes from Kuwait are across the treacherous and scorching desert. ``It's completely different'' from the situation in mid-August, said the U.S. official. At the border post, bored Saudi customs agents say only one or two cars a day have passed through recently. Al-Lahgul and two friends were injured early last month when their car crashed while fleeing Kuwait. They each spent five days in a Saudi hospital near the border. He said the Saudis promised to take him to Riyadh, the capital. After that, his life is up in the air. ``They (Saudis) told me maybe they come today,'' he said Saturday as he gingerly stood up with the help of a cane.

DOC.HEAD: Memorial, Rally Mark World War II Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: A memorial to Nazi war deserters was unveiled in Goettingen on Saturday while activists gathered on the former ``death strip'' in Berlin during events to mark the anniversary of the outbreak of World War II. Ironically, the day noting the 1939 Nazi invasion of Poland also coincided with tougher rules for Poles and other former East Bloc citizens seeking to visit West Berlin. In one of the few events to acknowledge the anniversary, the first official West German monument to those who fled the Nazi Army was dedicated in Goettingen, about 110 miles northeast of Frankfurt. Goettingen Mayor Artur Levi said men who deserted the Nazi military were unfairly forgotten and whose ``love for the fatherland knew no limits.'' The granite memorial contains a mutilated swastika, a symbol of the Nazi regime. In Berlin, several hundred church, environmental and peace activists gathered on Potsdamer Platz, a former main square in pre-war Berlin that was reduced to the barren ``death strip'' after the Berlin Wall was erected. The group laid the cornerstone of a building they hoped would be called ``European House,'' devoted to peaceful cooperation between European nations. A small group of peace activists also rallied in the East German city of Weimar, the center of German culture in the 18th and 19th centuries. The Weimar Republic, named for the city, governed Germany from the end of World War I until the rise of Nazism in the 1930s. On Saturday, tougher West Berlin visa requirements for Eastern European residents went into effect. Visitors now must have a written invitation from somebody living in the city, a hotel reservation and adequate amounts of Western currency. West Berlin has been the only Western city where Poles could travel with no restrictions. They converge on the city in large numbers to buy goods scarce in their country. ``We are going to protest and defend Polish citizens' rights with all means we have,'' said Polish Foreign Ministry spokesman Witold Gruszka in Warsaw on Saturday. The rules were approved by the United States, France and Britain, which still have final say over many of the laws passed in West Berlin. The German states are scheduled to be united Oct. 3, when the former World War II allies are to give up their special rights to Berlin. Also Saturday, East German Defense Minister Rainer Eppelmann was quoted as saying that Soviet troops should leave the country more quickly than the four-year timetable agreed to by the Soviets. Eppelmann, quoted by the East Berlin newspaper Berliner Zeitung, said four years is too long.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Cambodia Plan Raises New Hopes, Despite Past Failures
DOC.TEXT: A new U.N. peace plan for Cambodia has again raised hopes for ending the civil war, but many past efforts have failed after initial optimism. The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council on Tuesday proposed a U.N. interim administration in Cambodia until a new government is elected. They envisaged deploying up to 20,000 U.N. personnel, including a peacekeeping force, to bolster a truce and guide the nation to democracy. The Vietnamese-installed communist government of Premier Hun Sen is battling a guerrilla coalition composed of the communist Khmer Rouge and two non-Communist groups, one headed by former head of state Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the other by former Premier Son Sann. All sides welcomed the U.N. plan and signaled willingness to hold talks to discuss it in detail. But they have made no concessions on long-standing differences. Meanwhile, fighting has increased as both sides have reported big battles for control of western and central areas during the current rainy season. One diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, called the proposal a breakthrough because it was endorsed by Britain, China, France, the Soviet Union and the United States, which back different parties in the war. They are the permanent members of the security council. China, the guerrillas' main backer, said conditions had been created for a political settlement ``and the time is right for a settlement.'' U.S. officials at the United Nations tried on Friday to persuade Vietnamese diplomats to back the U.N. plan. The same day, the Vietnamese government said the new plan went ``in the right direction in the search for an overall, fair and reasonable political solution.'' But outside efforts cannot succeed without the approval of the Cambodian factions. Each time they have neared breakthroughs in the past, they later retreated to their old positions. In Tokyo in June, Sihanouk and Hun Sen signed a document saying they wanted a Supreme National Council formed that would arrange the first truce in the war and act as an interim body before elections. The council would comprise representatives from the government and rebels. But the agreement collapsed quickly. Fighting continued, and the Khmer Rouge insisted it have the same number of council seats as the Hun Sen government. Both sides expressed willingness to attend talks that Indonesia is trying to arrange for this month. Indonesia has played host at three rounds of Cambodian peace talks since 1988. The U.N. plan calls for five key ministries to be placed in U.N. hands. But the government and the guerrillas have long disagreed on the extent of the U.N. mandate. Phnom Penh wants to retain power in the interim period. The guerrillas want either the United Nations or the Supreme National Council to have interim power. Phnom Penh's deputy prime minister, Hor Nam Hong, welcomed the U.N. plan but did not indicate his government would concede on the issue of interim power. However, in remarks quoted by the official news media on Saturday, he accepted the ``major role played by the United Nations during the transitional period, notably the right to organize free and fair elections.'' ``Certain important ministries may be supervised by the United Nations so that the elections can take place in a neutral political environment,'' he said. Phnom Penh previously rebuffed the United Nations because it recognizes the guerrilla coalition as Cambodia's government. In July, however, in a major policy shift, the United States said it would no longer back the guerrillas' U.N. seat. Washington also said it would consider opening direct talks with the Cambodian government. The civil war began after Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978, ending a rule of nearly four years of the Khmer Rouge. Under the Khmer Rouge, hundreds of thousands of people died of famine, in executions and slave labor camps.

DOC.HEAD: Government Seizes Computers In Search For Secret Files
DOC.TEXT: Government agents seized computer equipment from a businessman's office Saturday in a search for a federal prosecutor's secret computer files that were mistakenly sold for $45. Charles Hayes, owner of Challenger Ltd., said federal marshals and staff from the U.S. attorney's office in Lexington seized nine computer terminals, a computer memory device and other equipment from his office in Nancy, about 70 miles south of Lexington. Hayes said he bought a broken computer system from the U.S. attorney's office in Lexington. After he took possession of it, the government realized a technician failed to properly erase the computer's memory. As a result, sensitive details about FBI informants, federally protected witnesses and sealed grand jury indictments and court records were released inadvertently to Hayes. Hayes said he was trying to find the records the FBI wanted and would have turned them over anyway. He called the nine-hour search of his offices that ended early Saturday ``the action of desperate men.'' Hayes' company buys government surplus equipment for resale to the public. Some of the computer equipment was sold and Hayes said he's trying to get the customers to return the items. But he has refused to identify the customers, which made government investigators suspicious. Officials with the U.S. marshal's office in London, Ky., the U.S. attorney's office in Lexington and the U.S. Justice Department in Washington, D.C., could not be reached Saturday for comment. The Justice Department filed suit Thursday in London, demanding Hayes return the computers immediately. The government also wants Hayes to testify about who purchased the equipment or had access to the data. If made public, the seven-year's worth of secret files could ruin ongoing criminal investigations and cause ``great harm and irreparable injury'' to the work of federal prosecutors, according to the lawsuit. U.S. District Judge Eugene Siler Jr. granted the government's request in a temporary order and scheduled a hearing Tuesday. Siler also signed the search warrant executed Friday evening, said Hayes. Hayes contends he doesn't know which computers came from the U.S. attorney's office because the equipment was mixed in with similar inventory.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Supports Landlord in Case Over Rental to Unmarried Couple
DOC.TEXT: A sharply divided Minnesota Supreme Court has ruled that a landlord did not violate the state's Human Rights Act when he refused to rent to an unmarried couple. The court, on a 4-3 vote that reversed a state Court of Appeals decision, ruled Friday that Layle French did not discriminate on the basis of marital status when he refused to rent to a woman who planned to live with her fiance, whom she eventually married. ``It is simply astonishing to me that the argument is made that the Legislature intended to protect fornication and promote a lifestyle which corrodes the institutions which have sustained our civilization, namely marriage and family life,'' Associate Justice Lawrence Yetka wrote for the majority. ``Before abandoning fundamental values and institutions, we must pause and take stock of our present social order: millions of drug abusers; rampant child abuse; a rising underclass without marketable job skills ... and children growing up with no one to guide them in developing any set of values,'' Yetka wrote. The landlord French, 34, of Marshall, contended that the ruling against him violated his constitutional rights to freedom of religion and to due process of law. His attorney argued that French upheld a state law against fornication. In the ruling, Yetka said, ``at the very least, before the state imposes sanctions on French, it must repeal the fornication statute.'' However, Chief Justice Peter Popovich wrote in dissent that ``this is not a case involving discrimination against fornicators, rather it is a case involving discrimination against single people living together.'' Popovich also questioned the constitutionality of the fornication law. The state claimed that because French was a landlord in a secular setting, his religious beliefs were subject to the state's prohibition against housing discrimination. In June last year, an administrative law judge ruled that French violated the state's anti-discrimination law when he reneged on an agreement to rent a house to Sue Parsons in February 1988. Parsons intended to live in the house with her boyfriend, whom she later married. French said it would violate his religious beliefs to rent to the couple before they wed. French said he paid Parsons $348 because he broke an oral contract to rent her the house. He later paid a $700 civil penalty in $1 bills, as a protest. A three-judge panel of the state Appeals Court last October unanimously upheld the discrimination finding. It said the government may subject the practice of religion to ``reasonable'' regulation if there is an ``overriding compelling interest.'' In French's case, the panel said, the interest was eliminating discrimination.

DOC.HEAD: Unity Breathes New Life into Germany's Historic Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 23-24 pvs bgng `A platform...' to CORRECT spelling of Potsdamer; pickup graf 25 `Foreign countries...'
DOC.TEXT: Berlin, so long divided by an ugly wall, is being made whole again to resume its historic role as the capital of a united Germany. Scaffolding covers the Brandenburg Gate, symbol of German unity, for a facelift expected to take two years. There are plans to rebuild the Hotel Adlon, which sat on the Pariser Platz in front of the towering gate, joined to the American and British embassies in a sort of three-cornered sandwich. Hitler's brass, diplomats, foreign journalists, and everybody who was anybody in the Berlin of the 1930s mingled at the fabled Adlon. Bodo Freyer, one of East Berlin's leading city planners, is reponsible for rebuilding old Berlin. Until the wall came down in November, Freyer's world ended at Pariser Platz and the gate, which stands on the line dividing the city. ``We never had to worry about what happened over there,'' he said pointing at an empty white area denoting West Berlin on his wall map. ``Now our task is to get the city to grow together again.'' To Freyer's delight, his job often takes him to the once-forbidden zone to work with West Berlin planners on reviving the central district, much of which is in East Berlin and went to seed during four decades of communism. Less than 10 months after the wall opened, Berlin is booming. An influx of 1.3 million East Germans has brought its population to 3.4 million. Planners don't know how many billions of dollars will be needed to rebuild the city, but expect the process to last a decade. Between the world wars, Berlin was one of Europe's most dynamic cities: an artistic mecca, a political and financial powerhouse, and home to refugees escaping Communist upheaval in the east. In the 1920s, Marlene Dietrich electrified audiences in the musical show ``Something's in the Air.'' Great minds were drawn to Berlin. Albert Einstein taught physics here, Jean-Paul Sartre came from Paris to philosophize, Vladimir Nabokov wandered the streets in exile from Russia and wrote novels. The rise of the Nazis in the 1930s changed Berlin forever. Most of the Jewish community, the largest in Germany, fled or perished in the Holocaust, and the world identified the city with evil. When the Nazis cracked down on nonconformists, Berlin's artists and independent intellectuals deserted the city. After the war, divided and desolate, Berlin became a backwater. West Berlin was an outpost of democracy in a sea of communism. So many people fled to it from surrounding East German territory that the Communist regime built the Berlin Wall in 1961 to keep them in. The wall builders disregarded streets and subway lines, creating an artificial strip through the city. ``It's a unique situation,'' Freyer said. ``A building boom will occur to fix what happened due to the division.'' During World War II, bombs razed the Adlon and most other buildings in the city's historic center. Potsdamer Platz, Berlin's most famous prewar square, was cut in two by the wall and became a vast no-man's land. A platform at Potsdamer Platz where U.S. presidents once peered into East Berlin was an early Cold War symbol. It has been taken down. Daimler-Benz, the industrial giant, wants the choicest piece of real estate on Potsdamer Platz for a new headquarters. Foreign countries hope to recover embassy sites confiscated by East Germany after the war. ``We have the right to the land where our embassy was before the war,'' a senior French diplomat said. ``We would have to entirely rebuild because it's grass now.'' The French Embassy was across the Pariser Platz from the U.S. Embassy and the Adlon. On the West Berlin side of the Brandenburg Gate, the Reichstag waits silently. On Dec. 2, the two German legislatures will decide whether to return a united German parliament to its original home. On Sunday mornings, groups of soccer players gather for pickup games on the green expanse in front of the Reichstag, where Hitler once addressed throngs of supporters. An army of rabbits that lived in the deserted area behind it has invaded the meadows of the Tiergarten across the street.

DOC.HEAD: Cancer-stricken Candidate Fired by Opponent He Beat
DOC.TEXT: Two days after defeating his boss in the Democratic primary for county commissioner, a cancer-stricken road worker lost both his job and medical insurance. Newton McWilliams, who suffers from a deadly type of skin cancer, was fired Thursday from his job as a Grant County road worker by the man he beat in Tuesday's primary, County Commissioner Kenneth Boyer. McWilliams received 61 percent of the vote. McWilliams, 32, of Lamont, said Boyer ``told me it was time to pay the piper and that I could go campaign full time and to get off the premises.'' Mounting medical bills have left him in debt and he's worried about finding another job in his condition, said McWilliams, who for seven years helped maintain roads in this rural, northern Oklahoma county. ``If you've got cancer, you can't afford to be without insurance,'' he said Friday. Boyer, 59, denied any malice in firing McWilliams, although he said Friday that he was upset about being challenged by an employee. ``They probably ought to have a law where a person has to resign when they run against an incumbent or their boss,'' he said. McWilliams' campaign for November's general election would have interfered with his work, said Boyer, who acknowleged that he had had no plans to resign while running for reelection as county commissioner. Boyer, who served one four-year term, said he allowed other county employees to give unused sick days to McWilliams, who missed a week of work a month for cancer treatments. Before that, McWilliams was allowed six days of sick leave a year. ``I feel sorry for anybody who has cancer,'' Boyer said. ``It could even happen to you or I. I did everything I possibly could.''

DOC.HEAD: Magistrate Orders Marine Objector Jailed Pending Trial
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Marine who refused to go to the Persian Gulf, saying he was a conscientious objector, will be held at the Pearl Harbor brig until his military trial, officials said. Cpl. Jeffrey Paterson, 22, faces charges of violation of a lawful order, missing movement and unauthorized absence for refusing to board an airplane with other members of the 1st Marine Expeditionary Brigade, who shipped out Wednesday night, Marine officials said. The military equivalent of a preliminary hearing will be scheduled for next week to look into the charges, said Capt. Leonard Ryan, a spokesman for Kaneohe Marine Corps Air Station. If convicted, Paterson could face maximum punishment of imprisonment for five years and one month, dishonorable discharge, reduction in rank and forfeiture of all pay and benefits, Ryan said. Paterson, of Hollister, Calif., filed for conscientious objector status Aug. 17, about two weeks after Iraq invaded Kuwait, citing his opposition to U.S. ``interventionist'' policies in the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Non-Westerners Fleeing Kuwait Complain of Abuses by Iraqis
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi authorities have pressed into service elderly Iraqis to patrol Kuwait City and blown up public buildings to instill fear in Kuwaitis, said an Indian refugee who arrived in Amman on Saturday. Meanwhile, a New York-based human rights monitoring group, Middle East Watch, issued a statement expressing concern about the conduct of Iraqi troops toward Kuwaitis and non-Westerners inside occupied Kuwait. The group said it had interviewed scores of Kuwaitis, Arabs and Asians who had fled to other Middle East countries following the Aug. 2 invasion. Middle East Watch said hundreds of people arrested by Iraqis shortly after the invasion remain unaccounted for, including Kuwaiti army officers, government officials and Iraqi dissidents. The group also said Iraqi troops fired on peaceful demonstrations opposing the occupation, killing or wounding several Kuwaitis. But Middle East Watch said it could not provide the number of casualties. Harinder Pal Singh, an Indian national who ran an air conditioning business in Kuwait for 13 years, said he had witnessed abuses by Iraqi troops. Singh fled Kuwait earlier in the week and arrived in Amman on Saturday. Singh said uniformed and armed Iraqis at least 70 years old were patrolling the streets of Kuwait City. ``I don't know whether it works or not, but with a gun everyone is afraid,'' he said. ``In Kuwait, there is no law and order,'' he said. Middle East Watch said the Iraqis were using members of the Popular Army, a poorly trained government militia, for occupation duty in Kuwait. After the Aug. 2 invasion, the Iraqis moved some regular army units into positions near the border with Saudi Arabia, where a massive U.S. troop buildup is under way. The refugee said officers had little apparent control over their troops, and he described incidents in which Iraqis kidnapped foreign women. ``They are especially interested in Filipino girls,'' he said. ``It happened in front of my friends.'' Singh said soldiers manning roadblocks routinely steal personal items from the occupants of cars. ``If he sees your watch, he will ask for it, and you can't do anything about it,'' he said. He said the Iraqi soldiers apparently do not have enough food or water and were foraging wherever they can. Middle East Watch said the widespread looting that marked the early days of the invasion has been curbed in part by the swift and well-publicized punishments meted out to suspected looters. Some people taken into custody for looting have reportedly been executed. Singh said that some days gunfire could be heard in Kuwait City as the Iraqis skirmished with Kuwaiti resistance fighters. He said the Iraqi occupiers regularly destroyed public buildings with artillery and tank fire. ``They'll go to an important place and destroy it with a tank as if they want to put their stamp on each and every position,'' he said. At the Turkish border outpost of Habur, a Pakistani refugee who arrived with his wife and two children Saturday complained that Iraqi soldiers were robbing departing foreigners. Ashfaq Ahmed, who worked in a factory in Kuwait, said his family and hundreds of other Pakistanis in cars had to wait for 10 days at the border before being allowed by the Iraqis to cross into Turkey. Ahmed said the Iraqis took most of his belongings, including a camera, television set and a radio. ``They stole everything, everything. All our money, cigarettes, and even my trousers,'' he said, pointing to the long robe he was wearing. ``We had to bribe the officials at the border to let us through,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: South-central U.S. Stays Hot; Rain in Gulf Region
DOC.TEXT: Labor Day weekend started off hot in the south-central United States as a massive high pressure system continued to dominate the region Saturday, while showers and thunderstorms were scattered in parts of the Gulf Coast region. Temperatures again soared into the upper 90s and above the 100-degree mark in Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas. Wichita, Kan., hit 103 degrees. Temperatures were mostly in the upper 80s and lower 90s in the Southeast, and readings were generally in the upper 70s and 80s from the northern Plains to the northern Atlantic Coast. A few showers and thunderstorms were scattered over central Texas, central Alabama, and from southwestern Nebraska to northern Iowa. Thunderstorms along the western Gulf Coast produced strong winds around Galveston Island Saturday morning, with gusts to 46 mph reported. Sunny, dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation. The nation's low Saturday was 33 degrees at Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Controllers Take Major Step in Returning Troubled Probe to Normal
DOC.TEXT: Commands radioed 152 million miles across the solar system Saturday made the errant Magellan spacecraft easier to control as it orbits Venus, NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory said. Engineers have not determined why the spacecraft has suffered two long communications blackouts but were hopeful that its $744 million mission to map the planet with radar would begin this month. Controllers began sending commands to Magellan early Saturday to awaken it from a so-called deep-safe mode and put it in a state called random access memory control. Nearly six hours after beginning the series of orders, the lab received Magellan's confirmation of the new configuration. Radio signals take 27 minutes, 10 seconds to travel from Earth to Venus and back. Venus is Earth's closest planetary neighbor. Magellan appeared to be stable, its solar panels were properly pointed at the sun and its batteries were charged, the lab said in a statement. The new condition will allow flight controllers to more easily program Magellan's computers. In addition, data from Magellan can tell engineers more about the spacecraft's condition, said JPL spokesman Jim Doyle. Next week, engineers will do more to normalize the spacecraft's operation. If that goes without a hitch, Magellan would be ordered on Sept. 12 to send home radar data already stored on its tape recorder and its radar sensor would resume operation two days later. Magellan was launched from the space shuttle Atlantis in May 1989, and made a looping, 15-month, 948 million-mile journey to Venus. The spacecraft entered orbit around the cloud-shrouded planet Aug. 10, and things began to go wrong. The radio link from Magellan to Earth failed for 14 hours starting Aug. 16 and for 17{ hours beginning Aug. 21. Controllers put Magellan into deep-safe mode, which kept its solar array pointed toward the sun so its batteries would stay charged. Other spacecraft have passed near Venus, but they returned images far less detailed than Magellan can produce. Images of Venus sent by Magellan after an Aug. 16 test of the radar-mapping system showed extensive seismic faults, enormous flows of solidified lava, cinder cones, a meteorite impact crater filled with lava and innumerable valleys and mountain ridges. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration had originally planned for Magellan to begin its mapping survey by the end of August.

DOC.HEAD: American Woman Describes Foiled Escape Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Debby and Jerry Willis of Parkman, Maine, nearly succeeded in their escape across the border from occupied Kuwait into Saudi Arabia. But Iraqi soldiers caught them in the desert. Now, Mrs. Willis is finally released, but her husband remains behind in Iraq as a hostage at a military site to deter a possible U.S. attack. Trapped in Kuwait by the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion, the Willis' lay low and then sought refuge in the U.S. Embassy. After two weeks, with Iraqi troops closing in, they decided to make a run for the border. ``Friends had told us to get false passports and go out with Poles, or other foreigners, but we did not want to do that,'' Mrs. Willis said on Saturday at the Baghdad airport, finally on her way home on a flight with hundreds of other Western women and children. In their attempt to escape, the couple had headed out across the desert for Saudi Arabia in a four-wheel drive vehicle. However, they could not find any local guides willing to take the risk to help them. Instead, on their own, they tried to follow an old water course. Nearly at the border, they passed an abandoned vehicle, but an Iraqi patrol leaped out of it and ordered them to halt. ``We did not resist,'' said Mrs. Willis, one of the Western women allowed to leave after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said only foreign men would be detained. Mrs. Willis was a lawyer in Kuwait. Her husband, who is originally from Johnson City, Tenn., had come looking for a job just before the Iraqis invaded. They were captured on Aug. 25, more than three weeks after the invasion. ``Iraqi officials stole everything from us _ cameras, jewelry, even jeans and tennis shoes from the men,'' Mrs. Willis said. But she said she wasn't afraid until they took away her husband. Willis remains in Iraq, apparently housed at a potential military target along with other foreigners.

DOC.HEAD: Helsinki: From Human Rights To Peace Venue
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen years ago, the Cold War began to defrost when 35 world leaders met in this capital to sign the Helsinki Human Rights Accords. Now, the leaders of the two superpowers will use the city as a site to try to solve the latest threat to world peace _ the Persian Gulf crisis. Washington and Moscow confirmed Saturday a summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be held in Helsinki on Sept. 9. Finnish President Mauno Koivisto said, ``Finland is ready to host the meeting'' and he welcomed the two world leaders. Since the 1975 Helsinki Accords, foreign leaders have found this city a useful stopover to hear Finnish leaders' views on Soviet affairs. Koivisto was the first Western leader to meet Gorbachev after he became Soviet Communist Party leader in 1985. Previously, Koivisto had held talks with three other Soviet leaders: Leonid Brezhnev, Yuri Andropov, and Konstantin Chernenko. He has now met Gorbachev more than 10 times. U.S. leaders also have shuttled through Helsinki numerous times since Gorbachev came to power. In May 1988, President Reagan paid his respects to Finnish diplomacy in a speech at Finlandia Hall, the site of the signing of the Helsinki Final Act. ``America respects Finland's neutrality ... and we salute the creative statesmanship that has been Finland's gift to world peace,'' Reagan said before meeting Gorbachev in the Soviet capital. During a three-day state visit in October 1989, Gorbachev also made a long-awaited gesture by acknowledging Finnish neutrality more explicitly than any Soviet leader before. But Finland's position has not alway been understood by the rest of the world. After 100 years of Russian rule and two bitter wars against the Soviet Union from 1939-44, Finland adopted a cautious, neutral foreign policy that is now being held up as a model by reformers in the Baltic states and others in the Soviet sphere. That policy, sometimes derogatorily called ``Finlandization'' to indicate subservience to a larger power, is now paying off. Finland retained its independence unlike its southern neighbors _ Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania _ which the Soviet Union annexed in 1940. Finland is the only nation to have soldiers in all U.N. peacekeeping duties worldwide and has contributed the most troops overall.

DOC.HEAD: Bush-Gorbachev Meeting: Hope for Middle East, European Arms Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES 13th graf, For John, and SUBS one graf for 16th graf pvs, Senior U.S., to remove references to Sununu being involved in arranging summit; SUBS one graf for 14th graf pvs, For James, for transition
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Whatever the agenda, the specter of next weekend's snap U.S.-Soviet summit underscores the isolation of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and serves as a dramatic diplomatic move that could bring the Soviet Union deeper into the embrace of the non-communist world. ``We have many matters to discuss,'' President Bush told reporters in Maine. He held out hope for agreement with Mikhail Gorbachev on a long-awaited conventional forces treaty to cover troop and tank reductions in Europe. Bush sought to dampen expectations that the meeting could somehow break the hostile impasse in the Middle East. He put the Gulf crisis somewhere in the discussions but not necessarily at the center. Be that as it may, there's something in Helsinki for everyone among the nations involved in the Middle East face-off, with the notable exception of Saddam Hussein. _For Bush, it is a key step in sealing the remarkable international coalition that has developed to reverse Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and protect the Middle Eastern oil fields from Iraqi piracy. The meeting would restore an element of the post-Cold War amity that had been rolling across the globe before Iraq sent its tanks into Kuwait on Aug. 2. _For Gorbachev, still struggling to tame the Soviet economy and the restless Soviet republics, it provides a spectacular stage to practice the safer craft of foreign diplomacy. In his continuing bid for Western aid, he can send a signal that Moscow can be a reliable partner in crisis management. There were reports from Amman that Moscow might mediate the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait. Before the invasion of Kuwait, Moscow was a longstanding ally of Saddam, providing Iraq with its most sophisticated weaponry, and military advisers to make it work. Bush seemed to dismiss that out of hand. ``I don't see a mediating role at all'' for Moscow, he said. Gorbachev is leery of the U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia and presumedly would relish an agreement that would return everyone's military to their own borders. It can't make Red Army generals happy to see U.S. troops deployed side-by-side Arab troops in the Saudi desert. Whatever role Gorbachev may play, his role in the anti-Iraq coalition is a far cry from the Brezhnev era, when the Soviets began large-scale military support for Saddam and could be counted on to blast any American-led military or diplomatic initiative. _For Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Syria and other Arab nations involved in the anti-Iraq effort, Soviet participation provides cover from criticism that they are too willing to do American bidding. Soviet acquiescence in the anti-Iraq effort has been important all along, but the fact is that Gorbachev himself has pretty much kept his distance. In the midst of the military crisis in the Gulf, Bush said Thursday that events in the Middle East might lead to a new post-Cold War world order. He might have been referring to hopes to keep intact the anti-Iraq alliance that includes almost all the states of the United Nations _ including nations that have been enemies for years. _For James A. Baker III it promises a sort of resurrection. He's been on vacation while national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney took center stage on U.S. policy in the gulf crisis. But a distinct success has slowly emerged from this crisis _ the diplomatic efforts to forge an international opposition to Iraq _ and vacation or not, Baker has to have been a central figure. Senior U.S. officials said only Baker and Scowcroft worked on the Bush-Gorbachev meeting. Asked why Bush and Gorbachev would get together, Scowcroft said: ``A lot has happened since the two of them met before (in Washington in May and June), not only in the Persian Gulf,'' he said. He mentioned Cambodia and Afghanistan and added, ``There is no lack of things for the two of them to talk about.'' Notably, there is arms control. In fact, two big treaties continue to wave in the winds _ the conventional forces (CFE) agreement for Europe and a pact that would cut back strategic nuclear missile levels. ``We've just set these meetings up, and the way I described it from our side to him (Gorbachev) was that ... we'd have no agenda, and that it would be free-flowing discussions. ``But I know that we'll have discussions of -- as I mentioned, CFE, and a CFE agreement.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Jonathan Wolman is Washington bureau chief of The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Say They Have a Dozen Suspects
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with suspect's `crush' on one of victims, edits to tighten; picks up 11th graf pvs, `Brevard County...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XGVL1, XGVL2
DOC.TEXT: An emotionally troubled University of Florida freshman under scrutiny in the grisly murders of five college students had a strong attraction for one of the slain women, a former neighbor said. Edward Lewis Humphrey, who was arrested Thursday for beating his grandmother but is a suspect in the murders, lived briefly this summer at the Gatorwood apartments, where the bodies of Tracy Paules, 23 and her roommate Manuel Taboada, 23, were found. Humphrey had a ``major crush on Tracy,'' said Rachel Olivier, 22, who also lived at the apartments. ``He'd fall over himself to be near her or to help her. He'd go and sit by the pool and watch when she'd come out.'' Humphrey also lived for a short time at Tolbert Hall, a dormitory where victim Christina Powell, 17, lived during summer school. The other stabbing victims were 18-year-old Sonja Larsen, and Christa Hoyt, 18. Four of the victims were students at the University of Florida, Taboada at Santa Fe Community College. Humphrey, 18, of Indialantic, ``continues to be a very good suspect for the moment,'' said police spokeswoman Lt. Sadie Darnell. But ``we have other good suspects,'' about a dozen in all, she said. Darnell cautioned that the killings might not all be linked to a single suspect. The killer may still be at large, she said, and people should remain on guard. ``We cannot say the killing is over. We don't know. We don't have anyone in custody for the murders,'' she said. Among other suspects, she mentioned Warren Virgil Tinch, 58, an Ohio fugitive wanted for the mutilation stabbing death of a woman in that state. Someone matching his general description stole cars in Gainesville and Ocala a week before the murders. Humphrey remained jailed Saturday in Brevard County, central Florida, on $1 million bond on a charge of assaulting his 79-year-old grandmother. Authorities have interrogated him at length about the Gainesville murders and taken blood samples, but no additional charges have been filed. Brevard County Sheriff Jake Miller and neighbors described Humphrey as a troubled youth who suffered an auto accident two years ago in which he fell or threw himself from a car moving at over 60 mph. He has been taking the mood-stabilizing drug lithium, said Randy Moore, chief felony attorney with the Brevard County public defender's office, which is representing Humphrey. Lithium is often used to treat schizophrenics. ``I think there is a question about his sanity,'' Moore said. ``He acts like he is out of it.'' Both prosecutors and Moore's office have said they likely would seek a psychological evaluation of Humphrey this week. Police sealed off the youth's Gainesville apartment and questioned anyone entering the complex. But Darnell said no attempt has been made to obtain a search warrant and examine the apartment itself _ a move that would require investigators to convince a judge there was good reason to suspect Humphrey. ``That would be the normal course of any investigation, and we have not reached that point yet,'' she said. Most of the University of Florida's 34,000 students took advantage of the long Labor Day weekend to head for the beach or home, said school spokesman Larry Humes. Between Top 40 hits, radio stations kept broadcasting the latest news on the killings and urged people ``to have a fun Labor Day _ but also a safe one.'' One station asked people to tie white ribbons in front of their homes to remember the dead.

DOC.HEAD: California Lawmakers Reject Early Presidential Primary
DOC.TEXT: California lawmakers rejected a proposal to move up California's presidential primary from June to March after stumbling over the issue of whether the primary ballot should be stripped of voter initiatives. The planned shift would have put California's primary in the first week of March, hard on the heels of the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary. It failed to go to a vote late Friday when Assembly members rejected a constitutional amendment that would have stripped all other ballot measures from the presidential primary ballot. A fragile compromise worked out by supporters of the early primary depended on legislative approval of both the amendment and the main bill, but it fell apart just hours before the end of the 1990 legislative session. ``They may try to bring it back next year, but I doubt it,'' said Sen. Ken Maddy, the Senate's GOP Leader and the author of the proposed amendment. ``Frankly, I don't see a groundswell of support for it except from some insiders and political reporters.'' Supporters say the shift would change the California election from an afterthought into the nation's dominant early primary. Now one of the latest in the nation, the California primary hasn't had a real impact on a presidential nomination race since 1972, when George McGovern's victory here cleared the way for his Democratic nomination. The early primary proposal would have left a separate primary for congressional, legislative and other races in June. But under California's constitution, voter initiatives that were ready would have to go on the same ballot as the presidential primary. Both parties were concerned that a one-sided primary, or one that drew especially strong voter interest for one party, could skew the results of ballot proposals. Since initiatives in recent years have included major issues like the Proposition 13 property tax cuts, a cigarette tax hike and major insurance, education and environmental measures, that raised the possibility of major policy issues being decided principally by voters of only one party. To avoid that, Maddy tied the early primary bill to enactment of a constitutional amendment that would bar initiatives from the presidential primary ballot. But while the early primary bill required only a simple majority vote of the Senate and Assembly, Maddy's constitutional amendment required a two-thirds majority. After several Assembly roll calls, the vote for Maddy's bill was 47 to 25, seven short of the required majority in the 80-seat lower house. Maddy said lawmakers were unsure about the effects of moving to a March primary. Even if his amendment had passed the lower house, Maddy said, the Assembly may have wanted to sit on the bill until next year. The early primary proposal faced stiff opposition in the Senate, where the Democratic leader, President Pro Tem David Roberti of Los Angeles, opposed Madden's constitutional amendment. ``The problem is what to do with the initiatives,'' Roberti said. He said he prefer leaving them on the ballot in March and November ``because that's when we will have the biggest turnout.''

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Troops Move In at Mohawk Settlement in Canada
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Mohawk negotiator denouncing military action, troops digging in for night; ADDS new details, BACKGROUND on cause of factional fighting; other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Canadian troops backed by armored vehicles and helicopters Saturday swept into a Mohawk community where armed Indians and authorities have stared at each other across barricades for 53 days. Gen. Armand Roy, commander of the Canadian Forces 5th Brigade, said he decided to send in his troops after two Mohawk men were wounded in factional fighting behind Indian barricades set up in a land dispute with government officials. ``I decided to move my troops so as to guarantee the security of civilians and my soldiers,'' Roy said. The military action came after efforts failed to reach a negotiated settlement in the dispute. The Mohawks have been trying to block a golf course extension on land they claim is theirs, but they have also raised other grievances. One shot was fired into the air by a Mohawk after the troops moved in, the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. said. But there were no reports of casualties. Defiant Indian militants stood their ground and screamed at Canadian soldiers to get away as troops pushed to within 100 yards of the Mohawks' main barricade Saturday afternoon. The troops moved into an area where the army had estimated at least 50 armed members of the militant Mohawk Warrior's Society were located. Later in the evening, Lt.-Col. Pierre Daigle said the army was digging in for the night around two other barricades. ``I'm willing to die for this,'' one Warrior screamed at a soldier approaching the main barricade. ``Are you ready to die? But before I die, I'm going to take out 50 of you. ...'' Ellen Gabriel, a Mohawk negotiator, denounced the army action as illegal. She said some Mohawk children had been caught in the path of the advancing troops. ``The army move was so fast they didn't have a chance to get the children out ...,'' she said in a radio interview from behind the barricades at the settlement. Journalists were not being allowed into the Kahnesatake Indian settlement overlooking the village of Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal. The troops, backed by provincial police, had also surrounded the Mohawk community center, where about 75 Indian civilians were gathered. The center has been used to house a food bank run by the Indians. Provincial authorities Monday had given the military the go-ahead to end the armed standoff that began July 11, when the Quebec provincial police attempted to storm a Mohawk barricade at Oka. One officer was killed, but it is still not clear by whose gunfire. Later that day, fellow Mohawks set up a blockade in sympathy at the Mercier bridge, a major link between Montreal and its southern suburbs. The ostensible reason for the Mohawk uprising _ expansion of the golf course _ was settled when the federal government purchased the land and said it would turn it over to the Indians. But militants seized the situation to publicize a much wider range of Indian grievances against the government, including demands for sovereignty. Quebec provincial police identified the two wounded Mohawks as Chief Francis Jacob and his son Corey. The two were severely beaten with baseball bats by four or five members of the Warrior's Society early Saturday morning, police said. Jacob, who had two black eyes, and his son were later released from the hospital. Dan David, a journalist who lives in the Mohawk settlement, said the factional fighting was sparked by an incident Friday evening in which several masked Warriors ransacked and looted the home of veterinarian Rejean Mongeon. He said some members of the Warrior's Society took offense after moderate Mohawks were quoted in the media as denouncing the attack on Mongeon's home. The militant Warrior's Society has been vying with elected native officials for authority within the Mohawk community. On Friday, Mohawks from the Kanewake reserve south of Montreal allowed troops to remove the main barricades they had set up on routes leading to the Mercier bridge. Quebec Transport Department officials said it would take several days before the bridge can be reopened to traffic. The bridge blockade has forced thousands of commuters on the south shore of the St. Lawrence River to make long detours to Montreal, which is on an island. Angry residents have protested and thrown rocks at Mohawks.

DOC.HEAD: Klan Dons Masks for Rallies
DOC.TEXT: About 200 white supremacists gathered in northeast Georgia Saturday, and a SWAT team broke up a smaller Ku Klux Klan rally in Louisiana that drew vocal opposition. In Lawrenceville, Ga., 200 people rallied at the old Gwinnett County Courthouse, where Klansman Shade Miller last year was arrested in a one-man protest of the state's 1951 law prohibiting wearing a mask in public. Klan leaders said this year's rally in part was a celebration of the state's decision not to enforce the mask law, which a state judge ruled unconstitutional after Miller's arrest. An appeal to the state Supreme Court is pending. About 40 marchers wore traditional Klan robes and open-faced hoods and 15 concealed their faces with masks attached to the hoods. About 100 Klan members and white supremacists marched also through Gainesville, Ga., about 30 miles way, carrying a banner reading ``Stop Colored Immigration.' Meanwhile, in Shreveport, La., the Caddo Parish Sheriff's Department SWAT team stepped between robed Klan members and about 40 opponents when a shouting match threatened to escalate into violence. A crowd including blacks and whites jeered as J.W. Farrands, an imperial wizard from Sanford, N.C., led 16 other Klan members to the Caddo Parish courthouse, where he spoke to about 40 supporters. David Duke, a former Klan leader and state senator who is running for the U.S. Senate, was not mentioned at the rally. Thomas Cochran, head of Duke's campaign office in Shreveport, said Duke supporters asked the Klan not to march ``because any imbecile knows that's not good for our campaign.''

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto to Be Charged With Corruption
DOC.TEXT: The caretaker government will file corruption charges against ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto this week, an official said Saturday. Ms. Bhutto was dismissed Aug. 6 by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan. He accused the 37-year-old prime minister of corruption, incompetence, and abuse of power during her 20 months in power. Ms. Bhutto and leaders of her Pakistan Peopel's Party deny the charges. ``The corruption charges will be based on solid material that can be proved in a court of law,'' said Interior Minister Zahid Sarfraz at a news conference. ``These cases will prove how blatant the corruption was and how large was it magnitude.'' Mrs. Bhutto has called her opponents ``a bunch of crooks.'' She also said Ishaq Khan acted at the behest of the armed forces. She had been at odds with the military over policy and personnel appointments since she took office on Dec. 2, 1988. High court judges will try the corruption case against Mrs. Bhutto and others in her government, and convicted politicians will be banned from participating in the elections set for Oct. 24. Ms. Bhutto and her supporters have threatened to boycott the polls if she is barred from the contest. ``No one should fear the special courts, as these will providee everyone an opportunity to prove his or her innocence,'' Sarfraz said. ``But in case some one refuses to appear in the courts or boycotts the polls, the election and the democratic process will go on unhindered,'' he said. ``The democratic process cannot stop if it does not suit a particular leader or a party.''

DOC.HEAD: Haitian Election Date Postponed
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Election officials Saturday postponed general elections that had been planned for November, delaying efforts to bring democracy to Haiti. A statement by the independent Electoral Council said the Nov. 4 election date was ``washed up.'' It cited a shortage of money and equipment. The council did not set a new election date but said it would be held in time to inaugurate a president by the Feb. 7, 1991. That date, previously planned for the inauguration, will be the fifth anniversary of the flight of dictator Jean Claude Duvalier. ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier, son of Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier, was swept from power in a popular uprising and fled to France in Feb. 1986. His father ruled from 1957. The statement said the opening date for a three-week voter-registration period had been moved from Sept. 3 to Oct. 5 due to lack of funds and materials. The statement was signed by Council president Jean-Robert Sabalat. The last attempt at free elections in Haiti in 1987 collapsed when thugs supported by the army killed at least 34 voters. ``We have already set up the district bureaus and most local bureaus. But we cannot begin registration insufficiently prepared,'' Electoral Council member Emmanuel Ambroise said. ``The Nov. 4 date for elections is just impossible.'' Many of the 12,000 registration bureaus have not been set up. The council has said that it has only received $400,000 of the $2.6 million it needs to complete registration. In past statements, the council has said it would call off the election if not enough people register to give credibility to the next regime. Electoral Council executive secretary Patrick Tardieu said the postponement had nothing to do with a standoff between President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot and the Council of State, which governs with her. On Thursday, the Council of State asked election officials not ``to rush headlong into elections,'' saying minimal security conditions had not been established by the executive branch. On Aug. 14, the Council of State broke off relations with Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot because of alleged abuse of power and refusal to satisfy demands for administrative reform, law and order, and economic relief. Seven of the 12 political parties that appointed Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot provisional president in March have called for her resignation. They have asked the Electoral Council to postpone registration until the conflict has been solved. On Sept. 11, the United Nations will consider a Haitian government request for technical and security assistance for elections, including supervision of voter registration and balloting.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Launch Off Until Late This Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to move up background on NASA problems, mention latest Magellan developments, adds details on Astro component replaced by workers; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronomy mission is off until late this week so NASA can fix a link to one of the telescopes aboard the shuttle. The space agency had hoped to launch Columbia and its $150 million Astro observatory as early as Wednesday, but engineers determined Saturday that the problem could not be corrected as easily as hoped and said the earliest date would be Thursday. The communication problem between Astro's X-ray telescope and launch control was the latest in a series of flaws that have dogged NASA for months. NASA has not launched a shuttle since April, when Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. That is the largest gap between flights since after the 1986 Challenger accident. At NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., scientists have been working to control the errant Magellan spacecraft, in orbit around Venus. Commands were radioed across the solar system Saturday to improve control of the Magellan, which has suffered two long communications blackouts. At Cape Canaveral, NASA officials said the latest Columbia delay was not viewed as serious. ``One day is not going to make that much of a difference to the team. It's not the first time it's happened,'' said Lisa Malone, spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``There's always a chance you're going to have some kind of delay, whether it's weather or something on the orbiter or something on the payload, which is what we have here,'' she said. The countdown for a Saturday liftoff was halted Thursday night after contact was lost with Astro's X-ray telescope. Workers entered the cargo bay Friday to examine a unit linking the instrument with the orbiter and launch controllers. Controllers need to be in constant touch with the X-ray telescope before launch to monitor the pressure and temperature of argon, a chemical used to keep the scientific instruments cool. Engineers decided Saturday they could not restore communications by installing a new cable in the unit, a sort of electronic box, but would try replacing a component inside the box that channels signals between the telescope and launch control. If that doesn't work, the whole box will be replaced. Workers on Saturday also replaced an instrument that measures acceleration and vibration. The instrument failed to activate properly during the countdown. Four of the crew members are astronomers who will operate Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes during the nine- to 10-day flight, probing some of the hottest objects in the universe. The X-ray telescope will be managed by ground controllers. The observatory will remain aboard the shuttle. The Astro mission was first scheduled for March 1986, but the Challenger disaster two months earlier put the flight and all others on hold. After a series of minor delays, the mission was rescheduled for May 30. Excessive amounts of hydrogen leaked during fueling, however, and the flight was called off. Another shuttle, Atlantis, was found to have similar leaks a month later, prompting NASA to ground the entire three-shuttle fleet. New fuel lines were installed in Columbia, and the shuttle was moved back to the launch pad last month. Atlantis' launch has been rescheduled for November. Columbia must lift off before Sept. 14 or will have to wait until after Discovery's flight in October with the sun-probing Ulysses satellite.

DOC.HEAD: Three Homes Destroyed at Mountain Lake
DOC.TEXT: A small brush fire destroyed three homes and damaged five others Saturday in this mountain resort, authorities said. Flames consumed about 18 acres of brush, said San Bernardino County Fire Department spokesman Paul Nyerick. There were no reports of injuries. ``It was total chaos for a while, with people wandering around and the Highway Patrol blocking roads,'' Nyerick said. ``There are a lot of families here on vacation for the weekend.'' Lake Arrowhead, in the San Bernardino Mountains 70 miles northeast of Los Angeles, has a mixture of residential and vacation homes.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Says Military Solution Could Worsen Gulf Situation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with pope's comments on AIDS and refugees; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Saturday rebuked Iraq for its occupation of Kuwait, but said military action by U.S.-led forces could bring ``more evil'' to the Persian Gulf. ``Everything possible must be done to avoid a bellicose solution,'' the pope told reporters on a flight from Rome to Tanzania at the start of a 10-day African tour. The pontiff said Kuwait's existence and rights ``must be respected.'' In other comments in Tanzania, the pontiff opened his seventh trip to Africa by urging the world community to help solve two of the continent's gravest problems: AIDS and the crush of refugees. ``The life-giving functions of human sexuality, and the blood which epitomizes health and life itself, have become a roadway to death,'' he said. In his remarks on the gulf crisis, the pope expressed concern about the possibility the United States and its allies might resort to armed confrontation against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, whose troops invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. ``Naturally every war creates worry in its various aspects,'' the pope said. ``Many things in history have been resolved through war. But on the other hand, war brings with it more violations of human rights and more evil than good or solutions.'' The pope would not say whether the Vatican would formally condemn a military strike against Iraq. The pontiff encouraged a diplomatic settlement, citing the United Nations as the best forum. ``We try not to lose hope. We pray for this and there are talks going on about this,'' he said. ``It would be reasonable for the Iraqis to understand this approach by the international community and to collaborate,'' said the pope, who noted there are no plans or proposals for the Vatican to act as a mediator in the crisis. Last Sunday, in his first direct public comments on the gulf crisis, the pope decried the ``grave violations of human rights and of the U.N. charter.'' He did not mention Iraq by name. In his other remarks, the pope called for a global effort to wipe out AIDS. But he also made clear the church rejects the use of condoms as a means of checking the spread of the deadly disease. In a speech to diplomats, John Paul described AIDS as a ``terrible evil'' which threatens all of humanity. ``The AIDS epidemic calls for a supreme effort of international cooperation on the part of governments, the world medical and scientific community, and all those who exercise influence in developing a sense of moral responsibility in society,'' the pope said. He warned that the AIDS crisis could be aggravated by indifference, discrimination against AIDS sufferers, and rivalries among scientists seeking a cure. John Paul also directed his attention to the plight of Africa's millions of refugees. Most are ``innocent victims of ethnic conflict, power struggles or failed development policies,'' he said. ``The situation cries out for urgent intervention on the part of the international community.'' The pope will spend five days in Tanzania before traveling to the tiny neighboring countries of Burundi and Rwanda. He ends his tour Sept. 10 in the Ivory Coast.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Order EPA to Act
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Friday refused to order the Environmental Protection Agency to install new curbs on the precursors of acid rain to benefit Canada. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia said the EAP could study the issue further. The case could be close to moot, since Congress is expected to order new measures against the precursors of acid rain _ chiefly sulfur and nitroggen oxides emitted by utility and other smokestacks _ in revisions to the Clean Air Act expected to pass this fall. The United States and Canada have begun negotiations on a treaty to deal with the issue. Half of acid rain falling in eastern Canada originates in the United States, much of that from the industrial areas of the Midwest and central Atlantic states. The province of Quebec sued EPA more than two years ago in an attempt to force the EPA to act. Canada contents that 14,000 of its lakes are endangered by acid rain, which can turn lakes in sensitive soil areas so acidic that no fish can live. Just before President Reagan took office, outgoing EPA administrator Douglas Costle wrote Secretary of State Edmund Muskie that the U.S. pollution in question was harming Canada. Quebec, supported by New Brunswick, Ontario, nine northeastern U.S. states and several environmental groups, argued in court that Costle's letter constituted a determination under U.S. law that required action against offending pollution sources. The U.S. environmental agency countered that it was not trying to stall a pollution cleanup, but needed more time to identify specific remedial actions and sources. A three-judge panel of the appeals court agreed, and said the agency had the right to wait until the completion of a massive scientific study on acid rain commissioned by Congress 10 years ago. The hundreds of scientists involved in the study are expected to release their final report in December. ``The EPA's delay in action on the (plaintiff's) petitions has been neither arbitrary, nor capricious, nor contrary to law,'' the court said in its ruling. In U.S. federal administrative law, courts generally may overturn decisions in an agency's area of expertise only if those decisions can be shown to be arbitrary, capricious or otherwise contrary to law.

DOC.HEAD: Florida A&M Helping Search for Veterans Who Worked on Alaska Highway
DOC.TEXT: The 3,600 black soldiers who endured frostbite, mosquitoes and the unsetting summer sun to build the Alaska Highway nearly 50 years ago also were never recognized for their work, two professors say. Now a reunion is being organized for the soldiers _ who made up about a third of the force that built the highway _ and it will take place in the far gentler Florida clime. ``We're going to try to have a conference here so that all those black troops that want to stay warm and be comfortable instead of going to Alaska (can) celebrate their part of the construction,'' said James N. Eaton, curator of the Black Archives Research Center and Museum at Florida A&M University. But first Eaton and Lael Morgan, a journalism professor at the University of Alaska in Fairbanks who contacted Eaton for help, have to find the soldiers, who were ignored in accounts of the highway's construction. They've put the word out through military and construction magazines and black newspapers, and interviewed their first two veterans Thursday. ``I think that it's a very interesting project,'' Alexander Powell, one of the two vets, told reporters Friday. ``Maybe we'll get our due recognition.'' Powell, a soft-spoken 68-year-old man born and raised in Quincy just west of Tallahassee, was shipped to Alaska in April 1942. Before the Army transferred him to the South Pacific 16 months later, he had lived with winter temperatures that dropped to 70 degrees below zero, a summer sun that never set, mosquitoes, black bears, almost no recreation and a lot of hard work. But he was chuckling as he talked about his part in building the road. ``It was a nice healthy country,'' Powell said. ``I didn't have a cold, the sniffles or anything while I was up there.'' Other soldiers weren't so lucky. Most units reportedly lost at least one or two soldiers, Morgan said. ``With all that cold, it would come back up to 30 or 35 below (and) it would actually feel warm to you then,'' Powell said. Morgan has been researching the eight-month construction of the 1,200-mile Alaska Highway for two years. She said she was amazed to learn that about a third of the 10,000 soldiers who built the highway, which is still the only road that links Alaska to the rest of the United States, were black. ``You go through all the souvenir books of the Alaska Highway and all the old news clippings, you never see a single black face,'' Morgan said. ``Nor did any historian know the whereabouts of any of these people. So I started looking.'' She turned for help to Eaton because many of the black soldiers were believed to have come from Florida and south Georgia and because of the reputation of the archives at Florida A&M, the state's only historically black public university. Eaton said they'd like to hold a reunion at the school in late 1991 so that it can be taped and taken to Alaska for the 50th anniversary. He and Morgan also want to make a traveling exhibit of photographs and memorabilia.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Charged With Murder of Children Found in Trunk
LaserPhoto CX7
DOC.TEXT: A suburban Chicago couple were charged with beating their two children to death while disciplining them and hiding the bodies in a steamer trunk for much of the last four years, police said Friday. Sheila Jones, 24, and Andre Jones, 27, of Riverdale each were charged with two counts of murder and two counts of concealing a homicidal death, said Dan McCullough, a spokesman for the Cook County state's attorney's office. Ms. Jones walked into a police station Thursday night and told detectives where the children could be found, said Chicago police Cmdr. Robert Beavers. Police seized the trunk containing the bodies of Luther Magee, 2, and Jessica Wilkens, 1. ``The mother decided it was too much of a burden to handle,'' Beavers said. ``It was a continuing series of abuses. The kids got weaker and weaker and weaker until they both just expired. He said they were undisciplined and unruly children, and he was trying to discipline them, and the mother said the same thing,'' Beavers said. Both the children's stepfather and their mother confessed to the killings, Beavers said. The couple were being held until a bail hearing Saturday. The bodies were discovered sealed in black plastic bags locked in a trunk, Beavers said. Initially, the children were wrapped in a blanket and hidden in the trunk of the couple's car, the parents told police. After a year, the smell became overpowering and the parents decided to wrap the bodies in plastic and store them in the steamer trunk, he said. The couple told police Luther died on Nov. 13, 1986, and Jessica on Nov. 27 of the same year, Beavers said.

DOC.HEAD: Animal Rights Protesters Arrested in Circus Ring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead, overline to CORRECT style to protesters sted protestors
DOC.TEXT: Three animal rights protesters, dressed as clowns and shouting slogans, were arrested in the center ring of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus after chaining themselves to a high-wire support rope. Circus workers used bolt cutters to snip the protesters' chains Thursday night. The clowns were taken to the San Mateo county jail and booked on charges of trespassing, disturbing the peace and conspiracy, police said. Those arrested at the Cow Palace were identified as Alden McElrath, 41, of Oakland; Lillian Carswell, 21, of Berkeley; and Damien Pierce, 26, of Albany. The disruption of the circus, shortly after intermission of the opening night performance, was brief. Before the performance, members of animal rights groups demonstrated outside the arena and passed out leaflets accusing the circus of animal abuse.

DOC.HEAD: Del Monte Recalls Some Canned Green Beans
DOC.TEXT: Del Monte Foods said Friday that it is recalling 843 cases of canned French Style green beans because about 50 cases of the vegetable were not cooked. The company said it is recalling 16-ounce cans of French Style green beans shipped in July to 140 Pathmark food stores in eastern Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Delaware, New Jersey and the New York City metropolitan area. The cans have a one-line code 0201J6F82 printed on their bottom end. Pathmark has already removed from its shelves all recalled cans it still has, Del Monte officials said. Del Monte said it has received no reports of illness from people who may have eaten the product. Harmful bacteria could grow in the uncooked beans. The San Francisco-based company said consumers who bought the beans should return them to the place of purchase. People with questions can call Del Monte at 800-543-3090.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Lundgren's Request for Jailhouse Visit With Wife
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a religious cult, facing a possible death sentence for murdering a family of five, lost an appeal Friday for a jailhouse visit with his wife. Lake County Common Pleas Court Judge Martin O. Parks, who presided at the trial of Jeffrey Lundgren, 40, ruled against the request filed on behalf of Lundgren by his attorneys. He gave no explanation for his decision. Lundgren's wife, Alice Lundgren, 39, is serving a life prison term for complicity to commit aggravated murder and kidnapping. She claimed during the trial that she was afraid of defying her husband. Lundgren was convicted Wednesday of five counts of aggravated murder and kidnapping in the April 17, 1989, deaths of Dennis and Cheryl Avery and their three daughters. The jury will reconvene Sept. 17 to decide whether to recommend the death penalty. Lundgren was a lay minister for the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints who was defrocked and formed his own sect. The Averys were killed in what Lundgren described to church-members as a cleansing ritual.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Pleads No Contest to Molestation Charge, Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The mayor resigned after pleading no contest Friday to one felony charge of molesting a boy he met through the Big Brothers program. Mayor Brian O'Toole faces a maximum of eight years in prison for lewd and lascivious conduct with a child under 14. Sentencing was scheduled for Dec. 5. Officials said he could get probation. O'Toole, out on $5,000 bail, is accused of molesting the boy from the time the youth was 9 until he was 13. The boy is now 15. The Sunnyvale City Council has 120 days to call a special election to replace the mayor after officially declaring the seat vacant, according to the city charter. It's too late for the election to be put on the November general election ballot, however. Vice Mayor Richard Napier has provisionally taken over the mayor's duties in this city of 106,000 people near San Jose.

DOC.HEAD: Florida-based Telephone Company Indicted in California
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf: ``A guard,'' with one graf bgng: ``In a,'' company denies allegations; ADDS two grafs quotes from company
DOC.TEXT: Harris Corp. and two executives of its digital telephone division were indicted Friday on charges of conspiring to pay bribes to Colombian officials for help obtaining government telecommunications contracts. Harris Corp., which makes telephone switching equipment at its Digital Telephone Systems division in Novato, Calif., was named in the five-count indictment returned by a federal grand jury in San Francisco. The indictment also charged John D. Iacobucci, vice president and general manager of Digital Telephone Systems, and Ronald L. Schultz, the division's human relations director, with violating the bribery provisions of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. In a statement issued at its Melbourne, Fla., headquarters, the company denied the allegations and said the two employees were innocent. The indictment charged that in 1989 the Iacobucci hired New York consultant Robert D. O'Hara to pay a member of Colombia's national legislature for help getting a telecommunications contract. According to the indictment, DTS paid O'Hara $22,835 with the understanding that some of the money would be used to pay bribes. Iacobucci an Schultz are accused of preparing false invoices to disguise the fact that some of the money would be used by O'Hara to pay bribes. O'Hara, named as an unindicted co-conspirator in the indictment, represented himself as having connections with Colombian officials, the indictment said. The indictment charged that Iacobucci agreed to pay money to a Colombian legislator in return for help obtaining contracts. The member of the the Camara de Representantes that Harris Corp. sought to influence was not identified. But the indictment charged that the company and Iacobucci agreed to pay a commission to a local Colombian firm partly owned by the official if Harris obtained a contract. The commission would be equal to 5 percent of any contracts Harris obtained from Telecom, the government-owned company that operates international and long distance telephone services in Colombia, according to the indictment. If convicted Harris Corp. could be fined up to $9 million. The charges against Iacobucci and Schultz each carry maximum prison terms of 30 years and fines of up to $1.55 million. ``We believe that these charges are based upon a distorted view of the facts, and they represent a radical departure from existing enforcement policies,'' said the Harris statement in the name of John T. Hartley, chairman and chief executive. ``We have cooperated fuly with the Justice Department in its investigation of the allegations, providing clear evidence refuting the charges.''

DOC.HEAD: Company Recalls Condoms Distributed by Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Some of the thousands of condoms distributed in a student newspaper at the University of Arkansas prior to spring break may be defective, the newspaper says. Safetex Corp., which provided the condoms, is recalling the Saxon Ultra-Thin variety latex condoms it distributed between June 1989 and July 1990.
