The variety was among three provided free with a special issue of the newspaper on Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome published March 14. Steve Wilkes, editor of the Arkansas Traveler, said a letter from Safetex stated that condoms from one inventory lot given to the student newspaper ``may have been below government standards.'' The condoms were glued to a piece of paper in a special edition of the newspaper, along with a note that read ``The Arkansas Traveler asks you to have a safe spring break. This could save your life. Please be careful. Condoms donated by the Safetex Corporation Lyndhurst, N.J. You can purchase these condoms at your local drug store.'' The standard implemented by the Federal Drug Administration allows only four failures of out 1,000, according to the letter with the recall notice. Wilkes said the condoms in the lot failed more often than that. He did not say how often they failed. The newspaper reported the recall in its Thursday edition. Safetex President Kiyohide Okuyama said in a telephone interview that the company wanted the condoms returned. But when told how they'd been distributed, he said, ``In that case, it's probably impossible to get them back.''

DOC.HEAD: Peruvian Writer Riles Mexican Ruling Party
DOC.TEXT: Peruvian writer and politician Mario Vargas Llosa said Mexico, ruled by one party for 60 years, is ``the perfect dictatorship,'' newspapers reported Friday. A spokesman for the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party claimed the novelist had ``lost touch with reality'' during his years of residence in Paris. ``The perfect dictatorship is not communism, is not the Soviet Union, is not Fidel Castro, it is Mexico,'' Vargas Llosa told a conference of intellectuals Thursday evening in the Mexican capital. ``It is the dictatorship camouflaged in such a way that it can seem not to be a dictatorship. But in fact it has ... all of the characteristics of a dictatorship, not of a man but of a party,'' added Vargas Llosa. The novelist, who ran a strong but unsuccessful race this year for the presidency of Peru, was referring to the party that has ruled Mexico since 1929. He said the party was ``immovable, a party which concedes enough space to criticism on the level at which that criticism serves it, because it confirms it is a democratic party.'' But Vargas Llosa said the party suppresses ``that criticism which in some way endangers its permanence.'' His remarks were carried by the government's Notimex news agency, as well as by several leading Mexico City dailies. The conservative El Heraldo and the leftist La Jornada carried the story on the front page. The government's El Nacional included the remarks in the fourth column of a story on page 16 of its arts and culture insert. Vargas Llosa said that the ruling party's leftist rhetoric, stemming from the 1910-1920 revolution, was the most efficient in Latin America at recruiting intellectuals, but he said Mexico's suffered from the same social injustices as most countries in the region. Later Friday, the party's secretary for international affairs, Romeo Flores Caballero, ripped back at Vargas Llosa in a statement carried by the independent Excelsior news agency. The official said Vargas Llosa had lived in Paris so long he had lost touch with his own country's history, as well as Mexico. ``If he knew the history, he would have won in the recent elections in Peru,'' Flores said. The agency quoted another party official, parliamentary deputy Augusto Gomez Villanueva, as claiming Vargas Llosa was seeking notoriety because of his failure in the Peruvian elections.

DOC.HEAD: Court Blocks Release of Therapists' Tapes
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court has blocked the release of tape-recorded conversations between a psychotherapist and two Beverly Hills brothers charged with murdering their wealthy parents. Erik Menendez, 19, and Joseph Lyle Menendez, 22, are accused of the August 1989 shotgun slayings of Jose Menedez, 45, and Mary Kitty Menendez, 44. Recordings of the brothers' October and November 1989 sessions with psychologist L. Jerome Oziel were to have been released to prosecutors and the public Sept. 4. But on Thursday, the court ordered the tapes sealed until it decides whether to grant a hearing on the disclosure issue, a decision that could take three months. Prosecutors want to use statements in the tapes as evidence against the brothers, who have denied the murders. Conversations between patients and therapists during treatment normally are confidential but can be disclosed in some circumstances when a patient has threatened another person. Los Angeles Superior Court Judge James Albrecht ruled Aug. 6 that the tapes could be released because Oziel had concluded that the brothers were dangerous to himself and two other people to whom the therapist had disclosed the brothers' statements. Lawyers for the brothers argued that Oziel's limited disclosures had taken care of any danger that existed and that full disclosure was not justified or authorized by law. After a state appeals court let Albrecht's ruling stand, defense lawyers appealed to the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Consultant Gets 21 Months in Jail
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4th graf: ``In an,'' about unrelated Fla. case
DOC.TEXT: Former defense consultant Mark Saunders was sentenced to 21 months in prison and fined $5,000 Friday for his role in funneling military procurement data to a defense contractor. Saunders was sentenced by U.S. District Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr. for his role in the Pentagon procurement scandal that is the subject of a longrunning Justice Department investigation dubbed ``Operation Ill Wind.'' The investigation has resulted in nearly 40 convictions of Pentagan officials, consultants and executives of defense firms as well as several corporations. In an unrelated case, the Justice Department announced Friday in Washington that a subsidiary of Baltimore's Martin Marietta Corp., Martin Marietta Electronics and Missiles Group of Orlando, Fla., had paid an additional $2.56 million to settle allegations of overcharges for government use of the firm's computers. The company earlier paid $898,000. Saunders, 56, was convicted June 5 of conspiracy to defraud the government, wire fraud and conversion of government property. U.S. District Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr. ordered that Saunders, 56, be placed on two years of supervised release after completing the prison term. The former Navy procurement official who became a defense consultant was convicted of participating in a scheme to funnel secret Pentagon bid information to another defense consultant, who sold it to Norden Systems, according to trial testimony. Saunders obtained the information from former Navy procurement official George G. Stone, who pleaded guilty to participating in the scheme, and passed it along to defense consultant Thomas E. Muldoon. Muldoon then sold the bid information about the sophisticated Marine Corps radar and communication system to Norden Systems, one of several companies competing for the $100 million contract, according to testimony. Three Norden executives have already pleaded guilty to taking part in the operation. Muldoon, who was convicted last year of unrelated defense fraud charges, was indicted along with Saunders. But the charges against Muldoon were dismissed by a judge who ruled that prosecutors may have indicted him as punishment for appealing the earlier ``Ill Wind'' conviction. Stone testified that he kept Norden in the competition for the contract at the request of Saunders. Norden dropped out of the competition after the ``Ill Wind'' investigation became public two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds Restrictions on Supplemental Security Income
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Gill in penultimate graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court upheld the government's right to restrict payments of Supplemental Security Income to aged and disabled people who have received overpayments from other programs. By a 3-0 vote, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overruled a decision by a San Francisco federal judge who threw out the restrictions in nine Western states. The court agreed with four other federal appeals courts that have upheld the same rules in the last four years. The ruling stems from a suit that challenged rules passed by the Reagan administration in 1982. Under those regulations, if an agency discovers it has overpaid someone, it normally would seek to deduct the money from future checks. Under the 1982 regulation, the amount of the monthly deduction _ money the recipient is not actually getting _ is counted as income in deciding whether the person is eligible for Supplemental Security Income to the aged, blind or disabled. Velma Martin, a San Leandro railroad worker's widow who filed the suit, had been collecting survivor's benefits from the Railroad Retirement Board since 1978, and was told by the board in 1985 that she had been overpaid more than $8,500 over four years because she had failed to report additional income. Under its rules, the board said it was deducting Ms. Martin's entire check of $268.14 a month for 34 months. Left with only her $386 monthly Social Security payment as income, she applied for SSI benefits but was turned down because the deducted $268.14 was counted as income, putting her over the eligibility limit. Ms. Martin then sued and won a ruling by U.S. District Judge Thelton Henderson that the 1982 eligibility rules violated federal law. That law defines income as ``payments received'' in the form of various benefits; Henderson said both the law's language and intent required actual receipt of the money, and excluded money that was being withheld. Henderson applied his ruling to the entire circuit _ California, Arizona, Nevada, Oregon, Washington, Idaho, Montana, Alaska and Hawaii, plus Guam and the Northern Marianas. But the appeals court disagreed with his reading of the law. Under Henderson's ruling, ``SSI funds will be used to partially subsidize a claimant's debt to an outside program,'' said the appellate opinion by Judge Cecil Poole. He said Congress would have made its intention clearer if it had meant to put such a serious limitation on the government's ability to define SSI applicants' income. Poole also said Ms. Martin and others whose overpayments came from the Railroad Retirement Board could ask the board to spread the repayment over a longer period by reducing the monthly deductions. Regardless of that option, the restrictions cause hardships, said Ms. Martin's lawyer, Gill Deford of the National Senior Citizens Law Center. ``These are people who are receiving welfare benefits,'' he said. ``If the amount is less than they're entitled to under federal law, almost by definition it's working a hardship.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Man Who Threatened President
DOC.TEXT: A man who sent a threatening letter to President Bush and said he would ``punch his lights out'' if the president visited the Northwest has been convicted on three counts and could face up to 15 years in prison. Defense lawyer Robert Leen on Thursday chastized prosecutors for trying 43-year-old Eugene Hains instead of ordering him to get mental health treatment. Leen said Hains suffered post-tramautic stress syndrome after serving in Vietnam and never intended to carry out the threats he voiced in the letter and in a conversation with a Secret Service agent. A federal jury convicted Hains Wednesday on two counts of threatening the president and one count of sending a threatening communication. He faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison on each count, although the judge was expected to be lenient. Hains was upset over bills from an Anaheim, Calif., technical school he briefly attended and said in a letter to Bush that he would get a gun from Mexico and kill those responsible, according to testimony. The letter prompted a visit from a Secret Service agent, whom Hains told he would punch the president if Bush ever came to Seattle or Oregon. Assistant U.S. Attorney Angelo Calfo cited a 1981 incident in Illinois in which Hains, upset over being laid off, returned to his job site with a 12-gauge shotgun and an ammunition belt slung around his chest. He was convicted of aggravated assault in that episode.

DOC.HEAD: Balancing the Budget in Five Years
DOC.TEXT: Congress, says the professor, is a bit like a person in possession of a credit card on which the issuing bank somehow forgot to put a limit. ``Credit limits on bank cards are there to protect you from bankruptcy,'' he says. ``While you, perhaps, are sensible enough not to spend yourself into the poorhouse, not everyone is.'' Congress, he laments, seems to be in that latter category. It talks about cutting the budget deficit, he says, but it has already raised spending plans 11 percent beyond the president's proposals. The professor, William Dunkelberg, is an economist, but he says the budget deficit is almost solely a political issue. Everyone understands the need for government to live within its income, but then politics obliterates reason, he says. History demonstrates that America needs to put a cap on federal spending, just as certainly as those caps are needed on credit cards. History proves it, he says. Congress chooses to raise taxes instead of cutting spending. Whenever taxes are raised, he continued, you may be sure that spending also will be raised. And when spending is raised, just as certainly you can expect taxes to be raised. But, the elected official alibis, government needs more money because of inflation. Not so, says Dunkelberg. He explains: If the tax rate is 10 percent and you earn a dollar, the government gets 10 cents. If inflation raises your salary by 10 percent, you will get $1.10 and the government will get 11 cents, or 10 percent more. However, he says, government spending keeps growing as a percent of total income, and that requires higher tax rates - or lots of new taxes. That's what has been happening, he says. ``Why should government get more of our output?'' he asks. He suggests everyone consider that question and make a political decision: ``We must simply decide if we are getting our money's worth from the dollars being spent by government. ``If we are, we shall be happy to pay. If not, we should cut spending and send those dollars back to the people who are supposed to be the beneficiaries of the governmental system _ the taxpayers.'' Dunkelberg is not just an abstract thinker; he is a practical person who understands budgets and has to live within one as dean of Temple University's school of business. ``We must cap federal spending,'' he declares. He suggests we consider proposals such as that advanced by the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry, which would put a 5 percent annual cap on government spending increases. And if inflation ate that up, so be it. ``It has a happy side effect of making government interested in keeping inflation low,'' he observes. If we did that, he promised we would produce a balanced budget within a few years, and then surpluses to reduce outstanding government debt or to provide funds for new federal tax cuts. Note, he says, this 5 percent cap would not deny government an annual increase. Each year it would still have about $50 billion in new spending to allocate as it saw fit. All that we're doing here, says Dunkelberg, is making it possible to eliminate the deficit. As matters stand, he explains, ``spending is now programmed to grow by more than revenues every year.'' Put a 5 percent cap on spending growth, he argues, and with today's tax code we would achieve in five or six years what has eluded us for two decades, a balanced budget. And after that, a surplus.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Lessons, Sweet Crude, and Waiters for McDonald's
DOC.TEXT: Stocks have lived up to their reputation in the Persian Gulf crisis, but the dollar and gold clearly have not. You'd expect stock prices to gyrate in a situation like this. And they have. You'd likewise expect the dollar and gold to attract the smart money. But they haven't. If this worldwide emergency has taught us anything new about the way the financial markets work, it's that some safe havens have lost their traditional allure. The explanations offered sound like those used to describe the political plunge of the Soviet Union. The end of the Cold War has changed the natural order of things, the market experts say. That has reduced the urgency of the so-called flight to safety by investors. In the political arena, the United States has been an obvious beneficiary of these changes. In the financial world, though, the dollar has had to make room for other superpowers, principally the German mark. Gold, too, has become an also-ran, moving briefly over $400 an ounce in the early stages of the Gulf crisis, then retreating. In both cases, part of the explanation is that they don't make world crises like they used to. With the Soviet Union leaning toward the West, the chances for world peace look better than the chances for world war, no matter who America's enemy of the moment may be. Even outside politics, recent global shocks have dissipated quickly. The stock market crash of 1987, for instance, was rapidly erased by a revived bull market. Persian Gulf worries also shall pass. Traders may rush to safety at the first signs of trouble, but exit just as swiftly on the expectation that even the worst problems will be temporary.
DOC.HEAD: GULF BUSINESS: Firms Shine Beneath Storm Clouds
DOC.TEXT: Temporary or not, the Gulf crisis was prompting some businesses to make hay while the storm rumbled. Artesia Waters Co. of San Antonio, Texas, was rushing to supply 17,000 gallons of water to the troops in Saudi Arabia. Quaker Oats Co. shipped 20,000 cases of Gatorade. Tyson Foods Inc. received orders for 240,000 pounds of frozen chicken. Circus Circus Enterprises Inc. of Las Vegas said it would donate 10,000 decks of cards to the Air Force. None of the firms getting an unexpected windfall from the crisis was brash enough to advertise it. But they were finding ways to get the word out. ``We didn't initiate this thing,'' said Artesia President Rick Scoville. ``. . . But once it got snowballing, we took advantage of it.'' Meanwhile, desert camouflage was selling out at Army surplus stores around the country. It's a fashion statement for some; others traveling to the Middle East were scarfing up the gear, including gas masks, to scalp on the black market.
DOC.HEAD: OIL: It's Light Sweet, Not WTI
DOC.TEXT: With all eyes on the oil markets, the New York Mercantile Exchange took the opportunity to renew its long-ignored case for a semantic change. The U.S. benchmark crude traded on the futures market is ``light sweet,'' not West Texas Intermediate, the Merc told its members. The WTI label stuck in the 1980s when the Merc first began trading oil futures. It was the most common of several similar grades on the market. No one much cared what the label was until some buyers, paying for WTI, later discovered they were getting a different grade. So, please, it's light sweet _ light for its high hydrogen component and sweet for its low sulphur content. Stay tuned for ``sour'' oil, which the Merc said it will begin trading in about a year.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Trade News Is Lone Bright Spot
DOC.TEXT: The only good news on the economy was that the trade picture brightened in the second quarter. The government said the spring deficit was the smallest in 6{ years. But the improvement was based on a steady drop in oil prices, which have recently reversed thanks to the tensions in the Gulf. Analysts were not optimistic about future reports as long as the oil outlook remained uncertain. In other reports, the government said the leading economic indicators were flat in July, home sales fell, and factory orders grew slightly. Mideast pressures could push all lower in August.
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: McDiner, IBM Train, and a GM Target
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp. surprised the fast-food business by opening a '50s-style diner in Hartsville, Tenn., complete with waiters and a menu ranging from Salisbury steak to lasagna. It's an experiment aimed at small-town markets, the company said. IBM said it would make its biggest product announcement in years next week when it unveils a line of mainframe computers. The expected publicity rush, large even by IBM standards, prompted the company to hire a train to cart reporters to the press conference in upstate New York next Wednesday. Steven Jobs said his Next Inc. would roll out new products later in the month, including a souped-up workstation and spreadsheet software. Analysts said Jobs, who founded Next after splitting with Apple Computer, needs a homerun to deflect criticism that his new company has produced next to nothing. The United Auto Workers headed into Labor Day by targeting General Motors Corp. for pattern contract negotiations. The goal is to get a standard contract covering workers at GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. by Sept. 14. Separately, GM announced it would install air bags in future U.S.-built cars, following the lead of Chrysler's Lee Iacocca, who has been pitching air bags for months.
DOC.HEAD: NEW PRODUCTS: Non-fat Treats On the Way
DOC.TEXT: Two snack makers gave hope to the overweight with fat-free versions of old standards. Eskimo Pie Corp. said it would test-market a frozen pie featuring Simplesse, a fat substitute. If it's crackers you want, Nabisco Brands Inc. said it would put fat-free Premiums on store shelves by mid-month.
DOC.HEAD: RETROPHOBIA: Another Shock to the System
DOC.TEXT: First there was Iraq-nophobia, the fear of what the Gulf crisis would lead to. Now, the Economist magazine reports the emergence of ``retrophobia.'' A British psychologist identified the new malady as the irrational fear of going back to work after a long break.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Filing Expected To Further Sober Buyout Business
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 29-31, beg ``Congress was out'' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with House Judiciary Committee hearing planned, picks up 32nd graf, Treasury Secretary; also SUBS 22nd graf, beg ``PaineWebber officials'' to fix typos.
DOC.TEXT: When Campeau Corp.'s department stores sought bankruptcy court sanctuary, it didn't surprise Wall Street dealmakers who months ago saw the takeover business punctured by the failure of the company's record retailing buyout. But Campeau's latest problems seem to have driven another stake into the heart of the once-raging market for corporate buyouts. Bankers and investment firms have become even warier. And, ``it's made investors more cautious,'' said Perrin Long, a securities industry analyst with Lipper Analytical Services Corp. Campeau's department store divisions, Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., filed for protection from their creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law. The divisions have a combined $7.7 billion in debt. Much of it was borrowed through high-interest junk bonds to finance the purchases by Campeau, a Canadian real estate developer, of Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. The takeover business, which boomed in the '80s on the back of junk bond financing, had to shift quickly into low gear after Campeau revealed its troubles last September. Financing for several deals, including Ramada Inc.'s restructuring and Coniston Partners' acquisition of TW Services Inc., had to be revamped because of junk bond market gyrations. Furthermore, big banks made cautious by the Campeau mess refused to back a planned employee-management buyout of United Airlines' parent UAL Corp. Suddenly, takeover financing appeared to be drying up. Wall Street reacted by throwing a tantrum _ the collapse of the UAL deal helped send the Dow Jones industrial average plunging 190 points on Oct. 13. By the time Federated and Allied headed into court last week _ as many observers had expected would happen _ investment bankers and dealmakers already were coping with a changed environment. But experts say the Campeau filing has helped to subdue the buyout market further. Companies still will be bought and sold, but finding bond investors will be difficult, said Long. ``We're in a transitional period because junk bond financing kind of has a dirty name,'' he said. Norman Weinger and Michael Metz, two Oppenheimer & Co. analysts, agreed in a report last week that mergers and acquisitions will involve bigger commitments of equity by buyers. Investors simply don't want to leave themselves open to the kinds of losses that Campeau's creditors are facing. Investment firms were listed among Campeau's biggest creditors. The firms own or hold for others billions of dollars in Federated and Allied bonds, and also put up millions of their own dollars for short-term bridge loans to help Campeau complete the Federated deal. First Boston Corp., Campeau's lead adviser in the Federated deal, could lose as much as $293 million, according to Fred Garcia, a First Boston spokesman. Of that amount, $43 million is from junk bonds owned by First Boston, Garcia said. The remaining $250 million is from a bridge loan. First Boston already has provided for any losses by charging them against its 1989 earnings, Garcia said, adding that the company still showed a profit for the year. Another of Campeau's more than 50,750 creditors is PaineWebber Inc., which put up a $95 million bridge loan in the Federated buyout. A PaineWebber spokesman, Jeffrey Taufield, said the company's losses on the loan have been offset somewhat by fees it collected on the Federated deal. Like First Boston, PaineWebber has adjusted its 1989 earnings to reflect any losses from the unpaid loan. Publicly, the companies portrayed any losses as a fact of investment banking life. ``We remain committed to the merchant banking business, understanding _ as has been demonstrated very clearly _ that it is a high risk and high reward business,'' said Garcia. PaineWebber officials will continue looking at opportunities ``in companies where they believe there is long-term potential,'' Taufield said. But investment bankers have been chastened somewhat by the Campeau filing. ``It would be foolish for us not to consider current market conditions in any transaction,'' said an employee at one Wall Street firm. ``We're not backing away _ but we've got our eyes open.'' Long predicted investment firms would move to reduce their exposure to bridge loans, which generally are refinanced with bond sales. The firms and other creditors are lining up to see how much they can recover from Campeau. Long speculated the firms might get 20 cents back for each dollar they lent. Besides their own balance sheets, dealmakers are also concerned that Campeau's troubles may revive anti-takeover sentiment in Washington. A year ago, after the record $24.53 billion leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. but well before Campeau's problems became public, congressional committees held hearings on possible ways of curbing debt-financed buyouts. House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jack Brooks has already announced that his committee will hold hearings on the Campeau filing and and look into the consequences of leveraged buyouts. Brooks said he feared the Chapter 11 filing was ``only the beginning, and that we will see the takeover trophies of the 1980s become the bankruptcy case names of the 1990s.'' Another I-told-you-so came from Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, whose state is home base for Federated and Allied. ``Campeau represents the merger mania of the '80s, when companies were more interested in devouring one another than producing a better product,'' Metzenbaum said. Congress was out of town last week and spokesmen for the Senate Finance and House Ways and Means committees said there had been no discussion of those panels holding new hearings in the wake of the Campeau filing. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady _ who last year testified that investors could be ``left holding the bag'' if debt-laden buyout targets ran into trouble _ has not commented publicly on the Campeau filing. Brady last year did not advocate any limits on takeovers, saying market forces should be allowed to determine the future of the buyout process. Congress passed some minor restrictions on the deductibility of interest from debt-financed buyouts last year. Jim Jaffe, an aide to Ways and Means Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., said the committee was unable to garner enough support for more substantive changes because of a lack of guidance from the Bush administration. ``That is really what people are waiting for,'' Jaffe said. ``They figure it's not worth doing anything if the administration isn't going to ultimately sign on.''

DOC.HEAD: Jobs Data Seen As Key to Financial Outlook
DOC.TEXT: As they go back to their jobs after the Labor Day weekend, many government officials and Wall Street investment managers will be focused on the latest trends in the American work force. A monthly report due Friday on the employment situation may well give financial policymakers their first late-summer signal on the economic outlook for the rest of the year. The data could serve as an early litmus test in the debate over whether a recession lies in wait. In addition, some observers think the figures may play a pivotal role in determining the Federal Reserve's next move in setting its monetary policy. Of course, veteran statistics-watchers always caution that numbers for any single month shouldn't be asked to carry too much weight. But any weakness that shows up in the report for August would come on the heels of a set of decidedly downbeat readings for July, when the unemployment rate increased to 5.5 percent from 5.2 percent the month before. ``July's employment report indicated a much weaker economy, with heavy job losses in construction, services and manufacturing,'' notes the current edition of the Merrill Lynch Market Letter. The July report showed a drop of 57,000 in nonfarm payroll employment, excluding workers employed in connection with the federal census, Merrill Lynch analysts observe. They project a further 30,000 decline for August, again after adjusting for short-term distortions involving the census. If there were another sizable increase in the unemployment rate, it could represent the signal the Federal Reserve has been awaiting to relax its credit policy, seeking to foster a drop in interest rates. But some analysts warn against making the assumption that interest rates would automatically fall as evidence accumulated of a business slump. One widely publicized x-factor in the equation is the August surge in world oil prices, which has intensified fears of inflation in many of the industrialized countries. In this kind of environment, said Paul Boltz, financial economist at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, ``easing may redouble the market's concerns about the Fed's willingness to fight inflation.'' The pressure on oil prices eased in the past week, permitting stock prices to rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed Friday at 2,614.36, up 81.44 from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 5.92 to 176.97; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 13.88 to 381.21, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was up 7.10 at 323.39. Volume on the Big Board came to 127.88 million shares a day, down from 189.86 million the week before. Even with cooperation from oil prices, a good many observers say they have reservations about the interest-rate outlook. The U.S. credit markets face stiff competition these days from interest-bearing securities in other countries such as Germany, where rates are comparable and reported inflation is less. There are worries, too, about worldwide demand for capital, given intense needs for investment in Eastern Europe. ``It also appears that demands to maintain a military presence in the Middle East will absorb capital the Middle East could have invested in foreign economies and markets,'' said Greg Smith at Prudential-Bache Securities. ``We want to be somewhat cautious about assuming interest rates will come down any time soon,'' Smith concluded, ``even if the economy does prove to be as weak as people expect.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheap Fares Equals Customer Crush Equals System Overload
DOC.TEXT: Airline industry officials say they're not sure what can be done to assure customers get faster ticket service than what they encountered earlier this week in a last-minute rush for discounted air fares. When many travel agents around the country tried to lock in tickets for airline customers on Wednesday, their computers spit back this message: SYSTEM UNAVAILABLE. A deadline for cheap autumn fares combined with a new charge for higher jet fuel costs threw the nation's airline reservation system into what agents and airlines described as an unprecedented gridlock. As tens of thousands of Americans jammed phone lines seeking to book tickets, computers were so slow that getting reservation information often took 30 minutes or more rather than the usual few seconds. Some systems crashed. And would-be passengers who tried calling airlines directly wound up on what seemed like permanent hold. ``The system's not built to handle Armageddon, and Wednesday was Armageddon,'' Dexter Koehl, spokesman for Minneapolis-based Carlson Travel Network, said Friday. ``People simply got shut out.'' It's unknown how many customers couldn't buy the discounted tickets, but airlines said passengers had plenty of advance notice and shouldn't have waited until the last minute. Industry officials mostly threw up their hands and said there was little that could be done to avoid such days in the future. They said increasing the capacity of airline reservation systems has never been discussed because the computers never faced such large demand. But some agents said two prior extensions by airlines of the midnight deadline Wednesday may have encouraged travelers to take a chance and hope for another extension before making plans. That also may have added to the burden. The double whammy was a deadline for special fares _ described as among the best deals in recent years, with prices discounted 40 percent or more _ and a 5.3 percent fuel surcharge on all tickets. Travel agents worked well into the night to meet demand, and airlines including Northwest Airlines, American Airlines and Trans World Airlines, extended the deadline. ``We ended up hand writing a lot of tickets,'' said a West Coast travel agent who asked not to be named. ``I'm sure we missed a lot of calls where we could help people.'' USAir spokeswoman Susan Young said the airline received about 330,000 telephone calls on Wednesday, about 100,000 more than normal. It refused to extend the deadline. ``We gave people plenty of time and plenty of notice,'' Young said. ``There was adequate time. People who did hang on the line were able to make reservations.'' American's Sabre airline reservations network with 125,000 terminals handled 100 million entries requesting information on Wednesday, about 25 percent more than the previous single-day record. The airline added a midnight to 6 a.m. shift of agents after realizing that thousands of callers probably weren't getting through, and it honored the cheap rates until that time. ``I don't know what else we could have done in this case,'' American spokesman Tim Smith said. ``The fares were there for almost three weeks. We always urge people to plan ahead.'' Northwest spokesman Doug Miller said the airline extended the cheap fares for 24 hours because ``people who under normal circumstances would have had plenty of time to make the booking weren't able to.'' ``Our computer reservation system was overloaded. We were experiencing delays in getting bookings accomplished,'' he said. The fares were good enough to fight for despite busy signals and on-hold elevator music. A midweek roundtrip flight between New York and Charlotte, N.C., was $158 under the special fare, compared to $251 now. A New York to Los Angeles ticket was $318 until Wednesday, now $449. Carlson Travel Network, which has 1,300 offices nationwide, said its air sales in the first three days of the week as the deadline bulge grew were $39 million, compared with $30 million for the previous seven days. At one Carlson agency in midtown Manhattan, the manager stayed until 3:30 a.m. Thursday processing tickets. The company is busy calculating its overtime costs for the week. ``It's like when you flip on every switch in the house,'' Susannah Knight, owner of Knight Travel in Charlotte, said of the overload. ``They more or less blew a fuse.''

DOC.HEAD: High Gasoline Doesn't Deter Labor Day Drivers
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices have surged to their highest levels in years, but they aren't keeping many Americans home this Labor Day weekend. Fuel-addicted motorists seem willing to pay whatever they must, even though the inflated prices have some folks grumbling at the pump. ``It's like being in jail,'' said Bud Case, a builder from South Charleston, W.Va. ``If the bail is $10,000, someone will dig in and get that money. Gas prices are the same way.'' As Case shelled out $26.13 to fill up his Chevy S-10 camper Friday in Charleston, he said he'd spend $5 a gallon if that was what it took to get away for the holiday. Prices aren't nearly that bad amid the oil crisis caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, although a road trip this weekend will cost a few dollars more than it did last Labor Day. The American Automobile Association reported that gasoline prices were averaging $1.307 for a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded just before the long weekend. That's up from $1.084 over the July 4 holiday and $1.062 on Labor Day last year. The AAA predicted a 2 percent decrease in Labor Day travel, but it said higher gasoline is not to blame. ``We think it has more to do with just the general doldrums of the economy,'' AAA spokesman Geoff Sundstrom said. ``Historically, people tend to curtail their travel if they're concerned about their economic livelihood. High prices by themselves don't seem to cut into travel that much.'' Motorists interviewed around the nation agreed they are pretty much hooked on fuel, so they're using it even if they don't like the price. ``It ought to be back where it was before they started all this foolishness,'' said Jacob Rogers, 84, of Belgrade, Maine, as he filled his station wagon at North Augusta Texaco on Friday. ``I think it's terrible, but what are you going to do?'' asked Lewis Ashley of Raleigh, N.C. ``Gasoline is a necessity. People are going to drive even if hits $2 a gallon. They don't have much of a choice.'' Ashley said he had started riding city buses more in the last month because of the increased gasoline prices. Driving 303 miles from St. Louis to Chicago would take $19.80 worth of gas at current prices and an average 20 miles per gallon, compared with $16.42 on July 4 or $16.09 last Labor Day. Cars with better gas mileage would cost less, but gas guzzlers would cost more. ``If people realize that on a relatively short trip that we're not really talking big bucks, it shouldn't stop them from going,'' said Bern Rotman, spokesman for the New York state Department of Economic Development. His department estimated a Labor Day round trip of 600 miles will cost just $5.32 more than it did last year. ``People have planned their Labor Day trip and they're taking it,'' said Frank Eastvedt, spokesman for the Automobile Club of Southern California. The club has noticed changes in the types of vacations people are taking. ``We're doing more short trips than longer ones,'' he said. ``They're taking maybe trips just within the state rather than going further.'' A survey in Alabama found motorists are avoiding the full-service lanes and pumping their own gas. Often, they switch to cheaper grades.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Chrysler Hourly Workers Punch Out for Last Time
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of union workers at Chrysler Corp. have accepted buyouts designed to reduce the No. 3 automaker's need for layoffs. The workers punched out for the last time Friday. Chrysler spokesman Lee Sechler estimated about 600 people had signed up for the buyout program. ``It's a positive alternative to layoffs,'' he said. The reduction in the company's work force comes as Chrysler negotiates a new national labor contract with the United Auto Workers union and as the financially struggling company seeks ways to cut costs. Meantime, negotiators for the UAW and General Motors Corp. continued meetings Friday in subcommittees that focus on particular contract issues, such as wages, benefits and job security. Last Tuesday, the union picked GM as its bargaining target, intending to reach an agreement that it can then bring to the other two automakers. Contracts covering more than 450,000 active workers for GM, Chrysler and Ford Motor Co. expire Sept. 14. GM and UAW officials said they planned to meet during the Labor Day weekend. Negotiations began in mid-July. Sechler said it won't be known until late next week or perhaps later how much money the automaker is spending on the buyout. He declined to provide details of the plan, which is contained in a 1988 national UAW-Chrysler contract. The payout formula is based primarily on an eligible worker's seniority with Chrysler. There are about 60,000 UAW-covered employees at Chrysler, but company and union officials said they didn't know precisely how many of them would be eligible for the program. The plans is not open to workers in some Chrysler factories, such as its Jeep assembly plant in Toledo, and some job classifications within plants, such as skilled trades. Chrysler is involved in a cost-cutting program launched last October to slice $1.5 billion from its $26 billion annual budget by the end of this year. The automaker's second-quarter earnings were down 47.2 percent, and Chrysler has acknowledged that the company will post a significant loss during the third quarter, mainly because of production interruptions at its profitable minivan plants. Production at the minivan factories in St. Louis and Windsor, Ontario, was stopped for about four weeks to retool for 1991 models. Since reaching its 1988 contract with the UAW, Chrysler has shut down two assembly plants in Kenosha, Wis., and Detroit, resulting in more than 7,000 layoffs. Chrysler plans to close its St. Louis car plant Nov. 9. Meantime, an unidentified UAW official was harshly critical of Chrysler in a story in Friday editions of The Detroit News for reinstating merit pay for executives while pleading poverty to hourly workers. Sechler said an in-house magazine distributed to employees in April noted that the merit-pay program had been reinstated after being suspended last October when the cost-cutting program began.
